author: 26229f9d-12ec-56ad-a40e-7b09c100b4d4
content:
tl;dr: beat up monsters for the equivalent of 5 USD and spend it all on food and soda to heal your party hee-ho

Strikers is my first musou/hack n' slash game, I decided to pick this up after finishing P5R. I don't hate it. Sure, feels a bit tedious and the story is not nearly as good as in the mainline titles, but it's actually quite fun beating up crowds of bozos when you get into it. Boss fights aren't a breeze on Normal, but they aren't too difficult or unfair from my experience. The game kind of drags out the tutorials through the first Jail, but I don't mind it as a newcomer to the genre. 

If you are expecting all the Persona-related systems to be fleshed out, I'm sorry. Fusion is terribly neutered and I don't bother messing with it very much. Most of the items you buy are going to be healing items for your team as they get bodied by boss fights. The main draw is the combat, and if you're a player who enjoys time management and day to day life within the world, you'll be sorely disappointed.

It's definitely extremely linear and doesn't seem to have much meaningful replayability. But so far, I've logged about 12 hours on my save and I'm pretty sure I'm only half way through the game, so there's still plenty of value-for-money to be had here. If you're a Persona 5 fan then you'll at least like the character interactions outside of the gameplay. 

If you're looking for something to hold you over until Persona 3 Reload or Persona 6 arrives, this ain't a bad time investment.

author: 4aae31ba-d50a-5a1f-96cb-6bf5191dc75f
content:
Bad tutorial, but once you actually figure out the mechanics this is a very good game. 

Early game tips:

- You can change your party even when not at a checkpoint (go int Stats in the menu)
- You are expected to go out of the jail multiple times to refresh your SP.
- Items refresh when you go out of the jails (if you've stayed in the jail a certain duration). Buy up healing and SP items every time you go out of jail
- Get the shop bond skill early, 60% off bandages will help a lot
- You can trigger elemental attacks without using SP by using a specific combo (light - light - light - heavy for most characters, some characters just need 2 lights before the heavy)

author: cf7234b3-edc2-55cb-98fb-9d33d7d7cc13
content:
As spin-offs go Persona Strikers is superb! If anything it comes off more as an expansion pack of old. In other words,it picks off right where P5 left off whilst dealing with similar paranormal,psychological,and societal issues.

As a musou fan I love the action based combat but in trying to adopt mechanics from P5's systems it excels in certain areas and falters in others. This time you have to be much more aware of enemy weaknesses with certain more formidable foes requiring you break their defenses before you can prod at their soft tender underbellies with your attacks.

 Additionally there's a clumsy attempt at "stealth" and "surprise ambushing" that frankly does not carry over well for this kind of genre. Imagine Devil Mat Cry 5 having aspects of Metal-Gear randomly thrown in just for the heck of it. It would make for a rather disjointed stop and go affair wouldn't it? The same applies with Persona Strikers. "Fortunately" future unlockable abilities begin to circumvent this problem and everything else from the exploration to the boss-fights is still platinum mint!

The story-telling,character interactions,and sound-track also deserve praise with even the new characters fitting in as opposed to sticking out like sore thumbs.

Well,"mostly". We finally get an adult persona user thrown into the mix but because he's a cop and initially has ulterior motives the main characters constantly dog on him by calling him gramps. Instead of handling the roasting stoically with a wry smile he whines about it incessantly. You know that meme "How do you do,fellow kids?". That's  Zenkichi in a nut-shell! Fortunately he eventually moves beyond this annoying first impression by revealing himself to be a more likable person later on. (Thank goodness)

As for Sophia? I have no problems with her what so ever. Persona 3 already presented the idea of having artificially intelligent robot companions with Aigis so Sophia being an "ap" that can manifest a more physical form in the meta-verse makes perfect sense within this continuity. She manages to be innocent and curious yet learns quickly whilst always being helpful.
 
I also appreciate how Strikers seems more about helping flawed people towards their personal redemption arcs and forgiving them as opposed to simply pursuing them as the bad guys then destroying their livelihoods. Don't misunderstand me,the antagonists in Strikers are still formidable adversaries. It's just this time we get to see the more positive application of "stealing hearts" expanded upon similar to how it was used to save Futaba and Sae Niijima.

Yet there is an underlying problem with "Modern Persona" that permeates Strikers as well. That being that the mundane socializing aspect which is wonderful for character building also undermines the high stakes of the over all meta-plot.

To me Persona is still apart of the Mega-Ten/Shin-Megami-Tensei brand. That means gods,goddesses,and other mythological beings are "real". There are dark uncaring cosmic forces from neighboring dimensions that creep their tendrils into our world to usher forth Armageddon. The only reason we are still here is because the heroes and heroines in these ongoing titles reset reality every so often to ensure humanity as a whole will continue to survive.

But hey,gotta go to the bad-bad bathhouse with the boys,amirite? Gotta throw some darts,exchange "gamur speak" with Futaba, or sing some karaoke to ensure the fans can  immerse themselves in the "totes believable" post-modern-pop-culture setting!  Again,I don't want to come off as a grouch. When I first played through Persona 3 and Persona 4 I really did appreciate the social-bonding system as I grew to truly care about even a few of the more insignificant side-npcs. "But" when you go about mundane routines within an environment that is not remotely surreal or remotely frightening the whole "We're under-dogs fighting scary apocalyptic deities in a cosmic horror setting" part of the SMT formula is watered down significantly.
     
Strikers does not have as much of this normie-simulation-filler as its' predecessor "but" there is still a lot of dialogue and down time compared to the typical musou outing. No doubt certain people will appreciate this but others will forget they are fighting with dark-forces from beyond the pale as the road-trip-monotony sets in. Strikers would have benefited from a greater sense of urgency. (Same with P5 as well.)  

Now back to the good news! Persona fusions,leveling up,unlockable bond bonuses,and acquiring increasingly better equipment sets are still present. Better yet,you can take control of EVERY Phantom Thief directly. (Save for Futaba and that's a pity. Oh well. She served as the oracle in P5 so it makes sense she's relegated to the roles of hacking and support! I still see it as a missed opportunity though.)

Of all the spin off Persona games I rate "Strikers" as the best one thus far even if the transition from turn-based rpg to action combat did not go off entirely smoothly without a hitch. 

Pros

+The combat,press-turn-system,fusions,and Persona spell-casting carried over surprsingly well into the hack n slash/beat em up format!

+A decent continuation that expands upon the concepts presented in its' predecessor.

+ New characters fit in with the rest of the cast.

+Good soundtrack coupled with the VAs doing a servicible job in their respective roles.

+The exploration and platforming break up the monotony of the battles.

+Objects in the environment can be exploited to give you a more direct advantage during fights.

+Good message about forgiveness and having empathy for others.

Cons

-Cannot decide if it is a lighthearted road-trip OVA or a tense paranormal/supernatural/mystery thriller.

-Dialogue and down-time between missions can be very dense,especially if you compare Strikers to other musou games. 

- The stealth and "surprise attack " mechanics that complimented the dungeon/palace infiltration in Persona 5 come off as a hindrance in Strikers. 

-RPG inspired roots ensure there is an intense level of grinding. No,it's not as bad as a gacha game but be ready to commit regardless!

-Where's Katsumi?

-Would have been rad if Goro Akechi made a guest appearance. Oh well,perhaps next time!

author: e5fce5b8-6bdd-5476-966d-e3823af73180
content:
If you are playing on a PC with an AMD processor that uses simultaneous multi-threading (SMT) make sure you download Ryzen Master and disable SMT when you play this game. It seems to prevent the myriad of menu freezes that people have experienced. 

I spent over 2 weeks going back and forth with a customer service rep from Sega support about the issue, which didn't result in any helpful information whatsoever. I was able to finish the game using this fix at least and I wouldn't expect a new patch.

As for the game itself, I would highly recommend it for fans of Persona 5. Definitely play P5R first though.

Just know going in that this is mostly a pretty standard action RPG. I was expecting Persona 5 Dynasty Warriors and it doesn't really feel like either of those games in terms of the core gameplay.

The day-to-day life sim elements of P5R are mostly gone, but there is still plenty of the classic fun interaction between the characters (except Yoshizawa I guess, booo). Many of the other features that you'd expect from Persona are there, like persona fusion, just in a similarly stripped-down fashion.

Despite not being a full-on Persona entry, Strikers is still a lot of fun. If you want more Phantom Thieves, definitely give this one a try.

author: 5ad6faaa-90a1-5859-b9e9-b9fd9ff186ce
content:
Summary: If you love the Persona series but wish it was less turn based and more live action, this game is for you.

GASH review (Gameplay, Achievements, Story, Hate)

[b]Gameplay[/b]
I absolutely love the gameplay. Some may say it's basically another musou game, but I disagree strongly. There is so much respect to the Persona series gameplay that it essentially feels like the devs just took that and added a musou twist, rather than a musou game with Persona sprinkled in. 
To really succeed, you need to have strong personas and can't simply treat it as a beat-em-up. You have elemental weaknesses/strengths, almighty damage, critical stun states for stronger enemies, and basically everything in mainline Persona games including persona fusion/execution to make your personas stronger. 
The usage of personas is extremely fluid, allowing the player to choose a persona using a semi-paused popup menu and executing attacks based on what combo you use. Overall, great gameplay and feels like the expected quality of a mainline game.

[b]Achievements[/b]
There's nothing particularly noteworthy of the achievements, and if there were any that were painful, I don't really remember them, indicating that even difficult/tedious ones weren't that bad.

[b]Story[/b]
The story is somewhat lacking but still holds water. It feels like they took a sequel plot to Persona 5 and watered it down. However, the new character is absolutely charming and adds so much to the story by virtue of being such a great character, but I wish the game could've had a story as deep as the mainline game. What it does instead is take a very light approach, which is acceptable considering it's enough to keep your attention, putting the gameplay first and foremost.

[b]Hate[/b]
There's not much to actually hate about this game, and I really implore anyone to buy it even if it's not on sale. I wish there was more story, more to be explored, and just more overall, but the experience was absolutely worth every penny.

author: da52407d-14cf-5807-baec-a9221105b059
content: This is a great continuation of a fantastic story. While it came out before Persona 5 Royal and thus none of that version's content is mentioned, It continues the story in typical Persona 5 fashion ... except now it's an action RPG, and it lacks all the confidants and life sim elements you might expect from the series. This makes it a much faster journey, but one which is still absolutely worth undertaking. The music might even be better than the Persona 5, and the story, though more light-hearted does a great job expanding the Phantom Theves' powers. So if you enjoyed these characters and want to see where they go next, absolutely give this a try.

content: This was a solid sequel to Persona 5, and it flows well whether you played the vanilla version or Royal. The music is great, and while I was initially worried I wouldn't like the new playstyle, I got used to it quickly and found a lot of the new mechanics to be really fun! As usual, the storyline is excellent, with some brand new characters I got quite attached to and some twists I did not expect. The boss fight was awesome and challenging. Also, Ryuji finally gets to say "f*ck" as a voiced line, so there's that. My only gripe is that I wish it was longer, but at the same time, the game makes it seem like it's going to end a lot earlier than it does and then goes on for a bit longer.

character personalities changed for the WORST and became so cheesy and "shounen like" if you know what i mean, which pissed me off so much because the difference was too big that it's immediately noticeable. soundtracks are great.

the gameplay was great too (for the beginning at least), but it becomes repetitive and annoying halfway through (it's literally just dodge and button mash). joker, arguably the most important character in the set, is the weakest and most boring to play with for some reason. and worst of all replay value is ZERO especially because merciless=hell and hard=heaven, even with NG+.

Persona fusion is EXTREEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEMELY GRINDY it's HORRIBLE.

difficulty is so imbalanced. mini bosses can be impossible while a main boss may be too easy. villain characters are trash, and the "plot twist" could be seen the moment the traitor was introduced.



If you're a fan of P5. i suggest you only buy it on a major discount.

and lower your expectations before you play.

5/10. if i wasn't a persona fan i'd definitely give it a solid 4 on a good day.

author: dd67c6ff-8f48-5ff9-b6dd-1d8077cc4cc4
content: I loved P5 Royal, I loved P5 Strikers. I finished Royal and went straight into Strikers and was not disappointed. The gang getting back together and going on a road trip to save the world was a novel idea, and for me it worked. It's missing some characters I liked in the previous game (no mention of the events of Royal here, including Yoshizawa and Maruki), but the story doesn't suffer from their absence. Check it out if you can. PS: I saw a bunch of reviews talking about glitches and such. I personally didn't experience glitches or slowdowns, although the complete change in controls from Royal did throw me off, and sometimes detection was wonky (at one point I had a hell of a time ambushing an enemy because the reticule kept pointing me at another Phantom Dash target, ugh).

author: bfbada8c-e1eb-59f2-822c-84aa5ba1c9c3
content:
Full playtime: 66 hours.

Full recommendation to those that love Persona 5.

Feeling very sentimental now.

I waited years to finally play Persona 5 Royal, then as I considered it not only good, but full of content well beyond its asking price on Steam, I bought Persona 5 Strikers as well. And played it after finishing the original game.

In short, Strikers takes after the events of Persona 5 and brings the team back together in a new case, against a new foe, in a new mystery, which takes them all across Japan.

I just finished it and now it really is over. As the credit roll, I am brought back to all of the moments in the original and in this one that I have enjoyed over 250 hours.

名残惜しい


Is it worth it? The games is more of a Dynasty Warriors type game with many elements of the Persona games. It is not turn based and is more live action.

Other than that, if you loved Persona 5 and its characters, then this game is definitely worth it and is quite fleshed out, especially for a Persona 5 spin-off game. The game provides massive amounts of fan service as well as general knowledge about Japan and its different regions.

Some tips: Don't let the first part of the game turn you off, it does get better and easier from then. I finished the game on hard mode.

author: 336d852d-7b41-53da-8471-68383db7bdae
content:
I held out on this for a long time, due to thinking it was just a spin-off capitalizing on the popularity of Persona 5. I was simply not interested in a Musou game (think, Dynasty Warriors) since that style of gameplay seemed too grindy and repetitive, and if it wasn't going to be a JRPG then why bother.

I'm so glad I finally played it.
Let me make one thing straight: it did _not_ make a believer out of me when it comes to Musou games. In fact, I played this on Easy difficulty to reduce the grind.
But, it was absolutely worth it. The story is a direct continuation from Persona 5, and it brings all the style and themes from the orginal, including the grandiose Palaces (called "Jails" here), a fantastic soundtrack of both remixes and new songs, and all the crew from the original game. Some new characters are also introduced and they mesh very well with the old cast, which have grown so comfortable with their company to the point where lots of hilarious shenanigans take place on a regular basis. Together with the new well-written story, it was an absolute blast.
Yes, the game feels a bit like it lacks polish or there have been corners cut here and there compared to the full package that was Persona 5, but honestly you won't mind it if you're mainly here for the story.

If you completed and loved Persona 5, you should definitely get this. If you're not a fan of Musou games, play it on easy and just enjoy the story and spectacle. It's worth it, and the game goes on decent sales from time to time too so you can snag it for cheap if you want.

author: 64271531-dba8-5922-b50c-f44b4b58c871
content:
As a musou game, it's a disaster. As a Persona game, it's also a disaster. God, I didn't have high expectations for this game, but somehow they managed to make me hate it outright. You know, you don't have to fill a game with mini-bosses and bosses with absurd amounts of HP. Even if you play as the game tells you, you're stuck in a boss fight with the same boring, unresponsive combat that has ever graced this genre. It's just awful. The dodge mechanic might as well not exist; what's the point if you're not going to add something to make us actually use it? The punishment is way too high if you miss it, with no real rewards for dodging perfectly. And what's with the ridiculously high amount of damage the mobs do compared to the damage you do? Even when applying debuffs to the enemy, you can barely notice that you're doing damage. It's so weird that the only thing that actually does some damage are your personas, but here's the catch: they have so little SP that by the time you manage to lower 10% of the boss's health, you'll just get absolutely drained of SP.

And what's with the world in this game? I just can't understand how we went from a great introductory palace like Kamoshida's to a really dry, generic, and soulless half-baked "city". Almost every part of that first jail looks so bland and uninspired.

I won't even talk about the voice acting; it's mostly due to the awful job from the mixing team not doing their jobs properly. Morgana's voice is way too loud in comparison to Yusuke's, and it's just baffling. Again, good job to the voice actors, it's a shame they got let down by the audio mixing team.

The game difficulty might be too hard even for newcomers, even on easy mode, I presume. Anyway, I just can't recommend this game. Just stick to P5R. Even though it's a JRPG, you'll probably have more fun than whatever they tried to cook up with this one.

author: 9639aa16-b409-5b57-b860-aaa6bc39c2d1
content:
if you have a Intel 12th gen cpu or later DO NOT BUY THIS GAME. The game will barely run at about 3 to 17 fps no matter your settings with severe stutters that lead to crashes. This is likely due to Denuvo DRM embedded in the game but customer support has been of no help and says that "Unfortunately since the game has not been tested on newer gens we cannot guarantee that you will not encounter these type of issues". 
The game has not gotten an update in 2 years even though there is a discussion board (made by Atlus themselves) with more than 1.864 comments about issues with the game (https://steamcommunity.com/app/1382330/discussions/0/3118150513192496504/?ctp=125)

The game also stutters a lot even when played on a 8th gen cpu which I can only assume is due to shader compilation.

On Steam Deck using proton 7 or 8 the game will not boot.
It should be noted that on Steam Deck with proton-ge50 (modified Valve's proton) this game is playable but the video cutscenes have no dialogue audio which is very important in a Persona game like this one....

To sum up this game is not worth the technical hassle/bad performance and not even close to being worth the 60 euro price tag.

author: 37d1a5bd-005a-5a3b-b771-d8c8d238887e
content:
The Good: I think this is the only Persona spinoff I've played where everyone actually feels in character without having their quirks philanderized, and the music is fantastic as always. My desire to keep playing is being fuelled by these things and the plot, which is intriguing enough so far.

The Bad: Gameplay could have used another pass or two in my opinion. The core action is fine, but the compulsion to cram every mechanic from the main series in here makes for about 10 subsystems too many. The tutorials (while exhaustive) throw pretty much everything at once at you. There's no way (for me) to keep it all straight so I typically end up cruising on the basics instead of getting fancy like the game clearly wants me to do (also I'm 10hrs in and haven't really felt the need to fuse personas at all???).

EDIT: Depending on the day, it also runs like an epileptic tortoise. I've been running it in windowed mode since the start of the 2nd dungeon which helps a bit, but given that loads of people are having similar problems, I'd definitely take this into consideration before buying.

Here is a tip for users, with "stuttering and lag" issues, who are using intel 12th and 13th gen cpu or any future cpus that has big and little cores.

author: 300963db-3c2a-5459-95ed-394c652d82d2
content:
Although Persona 5 Strikers had been available on PC for a long time, because [b]just minutes inside this title would be enough to spoil most of Persona 5[/b], I saved it until after I could experience Royal.

Credit is due to the developers for their ability to recreate Persona 5 in a different engine and genre. If I didn't know otherwise, I would have assumed it was the original team behind this spin-off. [b]Every step of the way I could feel the love put into this game.[/b] Starting from the story to gameplay and the new music tracks which will enter my playlists!

[b]The story[/b] of Strikers is a lot simpler and, while captivating, whereas in the original you obtain new companions and help them through their hardships, this is a bit less connected to the main characters of the game. Compared to the original very black-and-white story with clear villains and heroes, Strikers is a morally greyer story with a unique outlook on its villains. 
It's worth noting that although Strikers is technically a sequel to Persona 5, [b]the events of Royal are never mentioned[/b], but they are not incompatible on a story level.
Although justified, sadly the player doesn't get to keep the powers from the original title.

[b]Gone is the turn-based combat, replaced with a new action-based combat system[/b], and, while it's wildly different genres, the combat feels very familiar.
[b]The game is a musou[/b], which literally translates to "unmatched" and the main focus of this genre is cutting through hundreds of enemies that are nowhere near your level.  Because of my interest in the characters I went into it knowing it was not necessarily my cup of tea. Regardless, I can see it's one of the best musous out there, with all the faults that might come with the genre.
[b]This makes fighting fun, but repetitive[/b], especially with smaller enemies. Because this game is still a Persona, [b]in-between fights there's a lot of story dialogue demanding your attention after waves and waves of enemies that don't[/b]. This is followed by the very peculiar choice of having the first 3 dungeons of the game be almost copy pasted, only to add some variety towards the end of the game. 

When it comes to [b]exploration[/b], compared to the other Personas, [b]this is an extremely linear title [/b]that leaves little to no freedom to the player. The gameplay loop consists of going through cutscenes or braindedly cutting through waves of enemies when exploring a dungeon that often follows a very specific progression pattern. Rarely it's possible to explore the city and move freely, which is really just a jog around stores to see if something interesting is for sale. 
While the game is more linear, one very positive note compared to the original is that [b]almost all dialogues are dubbed[/b]. Because there were physically fewer dialogues, more could be voice-acted.

The title suffers a bit from all this repetition in my opinion, but it definitely ramped up in the second half keeping me hooked!

Just like in the original, [b]Requests are back, but[/b] because of the absence of Mementos, [b]it's only fetch quests that instead of adding to the experience, gatekeep abilities and what-not behind their completion.[/b]

[b]The difficulty[/b] was also a weak point for me, because as it often happens in these titles, [b]it's just numbers, making the fights longer instead of more challenging.[/b]

To me, [b]Strikers was like when your favorite anime releases a filler movie that doesn't really add anything, but it's still more of the thing you like.[/b] It's a delightful, post-main story of the original, adventure with all the characters I grew to love.  
After reading all this, if you're still convinced in getting it, go ahead. The small repetition in gameplay won't wipe out the charm and a story worth the Persona name!

[b]6.5/10[/b]

author: 5559d727-c2d9-5ac1-92b4-963bc030a6e6
content:
(very, very mild spoilers. People might miss them completely)

4.5/10 game review, done about 1/4-1/2 the way through the game

Game Play: 3 (controls messy out of the box, camera can be janky), game balance is whacked
Game Mechanics: 4 ( a good nod to the original but it clashes with the main theme of the combat and it lacks 'soul')
Graphics: 7 (good, true to original)
Sound/Dub: 7 (good, true to original)
Plot: 5 (neither good nor bad, little reference to original but doesn't mess with it either)

For some reason, some of the cut scenes lag. I suspect a porting problem.

Combat is odd. Do you like kicking puppies? Be prepared to kick puppies dozens at a time, because that's the feeling I get taking on a million trash mobs that are no threat with so much happening on the screen that hardly matters, so my brain shuts down and I don't much care. I get this is a type a brand of game on it's own, but it doesn't seem interesting or well done.

The story does make references back to P5 in a fashion. Slight ones. After all, we know the police aren't fond of joker because of the whole "No we are the Power and you will BOW to our Awe-Thor-itay because if you don't Society will CRUMBLE" mindset the japanese have as an excuse for their brand of fascist government and law enforcement (99% conviction rates in court, that's some bull). Heaven forbid there be a hero anyone else look up to that's not them, or anyone else with any real power.

They added the cute little ballerina, a twisted character I didn't approve of but came to enjoy in PS5R. Then replaced her with an AI in this game. Disappointed.

It has been done in a way that doesn't mess with the original, lets you go back and enjoy some nostalgia and a different type of game play. I still greatly prefer the original. Dubbing/voices, and artwork are a great match for the original at least, and characters so far have been true to the source material.

I like being able to main as the other character in game play, but game play differs so much from the original and there's so much 'emptiness' to things like not being able to 'live' in the game and develop relationships naturally like in the other game. Also they did just write some other support characters out, and I miss having them around.

I'd almost have rather had an add on for PS5R, that expanded the phantom theives little den to include interactions and little slice of life stories so that it was like adding one of those story book games or "choose your own adventure' type books. The 'gameplay' is just janky and I havent figured out how to re key the controls into something sane that doesnt annoy me yet. TBH this is a game for either die hard fans or people clueless about PS5 that just like mind numbing mass slasher games. I feel something like Soul Worker or Diablo clones and hybrids would make people happier than this.

author: 8b643edd-90a4-56e6-90c3-528a59ca4cbd
content:
The Phantom Thieves are back! This is basically Persona 5 Part 2. Takes place a few months after the events of the Persona 5.

This game is not a turned based RPG like most of the other Persona games, instead it is a an action hack and slash JRPG. It takes a little getting use to, especially if you just played Persona 5, but I think it works well overall.

The cast and characters are like your old buddies you got to know in the previous game and still has that certain charm about it.

It's much shorter than Persona 5 at roughly half the play time, but I do feel that they cut out a lot of the useless time wasting stuff from Persona 5 and really streamlined the game. So overall I think this is fine.

It's not too difficult on normal difficulty and I think most players should easily be able to beat the game on that setting.

Only real complaint is on a 12 Gen Intel chip the game does not run correctly. I needed to change the game to run as high priority on my processor in order to stop the game from stuttering like crazy. Some people might run into this issue, in this case I recommend using a program like Process Lasso to set the game to always run with high priority.

author: bc5b166c-6039-5a86-9795-ac42fa84d94e
content:
(NO SPOILER REVIEW)

After completing the story playing New Game Plus on Merciless Difficulty and attaining all the achievements on the game i could clearly say that this has to be one of the greatest sequel games I have played so far. 

Coming out of playing Persona 5 Royal -> Persona 4 Golden -> Persona 3 Portable & FES this game felt like a breath of fresh air.
Going back to Shibuya as Joker seeing how the other phantom thieves are doing in life really felt like meeting your old friends again back in the day. And thats where this game shines it takes all of whats in persona 5s story and world building and adds upon it. Using the same rules not breaking it but also adds upon it to the point that it feels natural is one of the greatest ways to make a sequel. Another thing that I enjoyed is the dialogue of each characters every single dialogue didn't feel out of place, every line of each character has meaning, each banter among all of the characters is nothing but entertaining to watch (props to the voice actors as they did a phenomenal job never in my entire life have i heard such great voice acting their performance in P5R was great but this was a major step up). 

Overall 10/10 for writing and direction 

Gameplay wise it is similar to a warriors game but may it not stop you from actually trying the game out the combat is smooth and the combos are satisfying to pull off and are greatly animated. Each character are uniquely made to suite every play style and not one character was ever useless or unplayable. Gameplay loop of smashing buttons is fun as heck.

Overall 10/10 for Gameplay 

Now on the the graphics and animation, it may be in a different game engine and was made by a different team but the graphics and animation never fell off furthermore it feels more of an upgrade at times. So in short if you love the original Persona 5 aesthetic you will love it all the same with this game

10/10

Now music. 
Its a no brainer 10/10 
Lynn went ham with the signing remaking most of the songs from the original persona 5 and making them into rock was a move no one expected but everyone enjoyed. From past music to new music everything on this games track was banger after banger never disappoints.

Addition to what i said about the writing of the game all the new characters mesh well with the phantom thieves group and are all well made.

The only con I have with this game is that after finishing and experiencing it means less persona games i have left until persona 6 or another persona 5 spin off is released.

author: 80b69f5e-6214-57dc-ba36-bf4f3086515e
content:
A short and honest review of PERSONA 5 STRIKERS

“Strikers” has the “Persona 5” (P5) DNA all over it. The Persona universe and P5 characters are nicely used and new memorable faces join the action. It all makes the game feel like a true sequel! The “musou” action genre works great too, implementing Persona-like elements for even better. Nonetheless, it can get repetitive, so I’d advise playing in short sessions. The only thing I didn’t like -at all- is the “jails” (dungeons) music. It feels off! And left me wishing there was an option to change it, as there is with battle music. Also, no gallery to watch images or cutscenes nor new game+, bummer! In the technical aspect, I had a problem where pre-rendered videos would stutter for the first seconds, delating the game was loading in the background. Also, a crash that costed me hours of progress (no auto-save! Which doesn’t make sense, as the game doesn’t have branching paths or anything alike). That said, I would sincerely recommend “Strikers” to any P5 fan. It will help with the post-game depression the original leaves you with and present new amazing (canon) situations for you to enjoy! Just don’t expect the “depth” a traditional Persona game can have.

author: 4ba95fd9-77ff-54ff-bc3b-6ded12a80e53
content:
I was really looking forward to having more of the P5 cast, but Strikers is way too unfocused to be enjoyable. 

I initially thought Strikers was going to be a more action oriented take on the Persona formula and im aware that it was drawing inspiration from Dynasty Warriors type of games. The movement and combat itself feels very clunky. Mid-PS2 era clunky, those years where devs were still grappling with having a lot more freedom of movement in 3d space and better tech to support it. They also didnt blend mechanics or gameplay styles, theyve simply jammed them into the same area. Imagine a Dynasty Warriors game, but now  take every single mechanic from P5 and layer it on top. It's too much to handle and it doesnt feel good.

The smaller mob encounters are also over way too fast for you to get comfortable with the combat, which means by the time you get to a boss you have no idea what youre doing. All in all its a very sloppy execution of a cool concept.

author: e6b47d05-87f7-51fc-94de-b4673c4beba6
content:
As someone who loved Persona 5, I'd love to recommend this game and I can tell that a lot of effort was put into its development on its original console systems. However, the PC port is a stuttering, lag-filled mess, even several years after the steam release. It's playable, but frustrating for an action game. Its combat is also somewhat questionable. It tries to marry the "ambush and start a fight" mechanic of a JRPG into a dynasty-warriors-style combat system. The result is squishing a chaotic number of opponents into a tiny combat arena while simultaneously removing the strategic map-management elements normally present in this genre.

Although I appreciate the effort at innovation, this just didn't quite work for me. I'd still probably appreciate the overall game if it played better despite disagreeing with some of its design decisions, but no amount of polish in flavor/style can make up for the poor performance of the game itself.

author: 23fb3e98-af64-5164-b5ed-4f5c335d1a44
content:
This game is a solid sequel to persona 5, and anybody that enjoyed that game should definitely play this one. It can be a little brain dead at points, but the combats pretty fun (for the most part). Every character (except Morgana) has a fun, if just a little too similar move-set I enjoyed playing and learning. I think Makoto, Haru, and Ryuji were my favourites. The road-trip story is solid, and has some great character moments for all of the phantom thieves, except like Morgana or Futaba (rip) from what I remember (Finally, justice for Haru). Most of the new characters are also great. I love Zenkichi SO MUCH. Even outside of all that, Ryuji gets to say fuck, so the game is automatically a 10/10.

HOWEVER
The game has some MASSIVE problems.

First and foremost, the PC port is absolutely TERRIBLE. The game constantly stutters to the point of being unplayable. Seriously, I couldn't even get past the first goddamn cutscene when I first tried to play. I had to download an external program called process lasso to get the game to even work properly. The game is also capped at 60 FPS, which isn't the biggest deal, but I found it can quite easily drop below that when things get hectic. Even on hardware which far exceeds the recommended specs. While I'm sure it was a pain the the ass recreating Persona 5's trademark look on a completely different engine, the anti-aliasing makes the game look pretty terrible. But luckily, this can be pretty easily fixed with the few settings tweeks. I also got caught in an infinite loading screen at one point, which was is always my FAVOURITE feature in any game.

Unfortunately the problems don't stop with just the poor porting job. While I liked a good amount of the story bosses (final boss excluded), a good amount of them have WAY too much health. I played on hard so I'm not sure how it is on lower difficulties, but I feel like most bosses ended up outstaying their welcome. I remember one of the optional bosses took me about 20 minutes straight to beat, all while having no extra challenge outside of the time commitment. Also, once I figured out spamming the square + square + triangle combo was BY FAR the most efficient way of playing the game, the combat became far less fun for me. Those are my main issues, but there's a few other issues I have with the combat, like all out attacks feel incredibly under powered, and the camera being pretty janky. The side quest also kinda suck, which is pretty disappointing for a franchise like Persona, where the side content has been one of it's major draws since Persona 3.

The persona fusion system in this game is also a hot pile of ASS. For some god forsaken reason you need to have high level early game persona for some of the later fusion. This would either take millions of yen of buying and deleting high level personas over and over again, or literal HOURS of grinding. I have no clue who approved this change, but they should be very careful on August 17th 2038 at 7:43 AM.

Overall, I still think strikers is a worthwhile sequel to Persona 5, and I would still recommend this game to anyone who enjoyed the original. BUT, there are some big problems that hold this game back from being truly great.

author: 9df1d8d1-f428-5d2b-89fd-114b48c428b4
content: I've played this game on Nintendo Switch at launch and it was the first close to mainline persona game I was able to play (at the time I think I had only played parts of Persona Q and Persona Q 2). It's actually a really good introduction to how persona games work, you have deadlines and side tasks, but it's simplified compared to the main games so you don't have to balance 20 social links, upgrading your stats, dungeon crawling, and playing the main story. Yes, it is super barebones in comparison but it's actually a good way to get used to the system without getting overwhelmed. Before I played this I had watched playthroughs of Persona 3, Persona 5, and either Persona 4 Golden or Persona 4, so I was used to the mechanics. This was a great intro to the system for me before I got Persona 4 Golden, though to be fair I think Persona 4 Golden is simplier than Persona 5 Royal which overwhelmed me a little my first playthrough. There is one main issue with the steam version I have noticed. It buffers a lot. I'll be playing and my screen freezes or is delayed a ton. Sometimes it works out after I mess with setting, but other times not which is why I haven't put more time into this version when my Switch copy has like thirty or so hours of gameplay. It can't be my computer because Persona 5 Royal and Persona 4 Golden have no issues running on it. Overall a really good game that serves as a fantastic intro to the game series, excluding the whole minor spoilers to Persona 5 part.

author: 131d7762-4bb0-5760-9830-e5927855ae7c
content:
TLDR: A Fun, However hollow Persona/Dynasty Warriors Style Game.

-Being a Persona Spin-off, the story shouldn't be expected to be strong, and to describe it the best I can: It feels like either a clone or a mockery of the first game. Only 1 or maybe 2 of the 'Clone Jails' Are decent, though the original one for the new member is great. The Final Boss is practically a Duplicate of a previous game's fight aswell, with less depth for lack of better term.
-However the gameplay, I can say for certain is quite strong in this game. Creation and Usage of Personas feels great. Basic attacking and follow-ups into combos are Really Fun. Having an actual 'Merciless' Difficulty only unlockable at the end of the game, and requiring practically perfect personas is quite a plus.

6.5/10 Overall, It's enjoyable, but more-so for the people that enjoy Dynasty-Style games. I'd put it low in the ranking for 'Persona Spin-Offs', and recommend you buy this during a sale if you're interested in it.

author: d7509fcf-a2a9-56d0-92f3-814b45d7af9e
content: The combat, music, characters, story, and overall gameplay is extremely enjoyable. The combat is so fun, I want it in future Persona titles. The combat's breathtaking and it's real fun combined with the banger music. However, the game is extremely unoptimized for PCs. The UI elements and texts are extremely blurry (even with anti-aliasing disabled), and it really took me out at the beginning. I got used to it to the point where I could play the game without being too annoyed, but it certainly doesn't feel like enough attention has been put into those aspects of the game, compared to P5R absolutely nailing them, where the game looks gorgeous at every turn. And the performance is pretty inconsistent as well, despite the game being locked to 60fps unlike P5R running flawlessly at 120fps. There are occasional frame drops and stutters, which I don't think should be happening with an i7-12700K and a 3080. And the camera feels weird to control with a mouse (but it's fine with a controller), where it was perfect on P5R with both mouse and a controller, which makes me think they just upscaled the Switch version of the game, leading to unoptimized camera and blurry UI elements. The game is still extremely fun nonetheless, it feels like a lot of care has gone into the music and overall gameplay (along with other things I praised), which is ultimately more important than minor optimization issues, but I'd like the issues to be fixed at the same time, so I can truly feel happy and satisfied playing this game :D

author: fe9dafd1-f956-5d88-955c-03869f734e36
content:
Absolutely loved it. It didn't outstay its welcome at all, despite twist-after-twist, even though that is sort of expected with Persona games now. The combat feels more fluid and engaging to me and doesn't burn me out in the same way the turn based combat would, the faster pace is very much welcome for me. Overall, I enjoy the combat more in P5S than the original. It feels very much like P5, though, carrying over every mechanic from that game -- on the combat side of things, anyway.

Story and progression has been streamlined. There's no time management aspect to it anymore, and no social links. 

Whaaaat?! But those make Persona games great! Maybe. But I never felt like it was lacking, going through just the story of it. In fact, I appreciated it, because it severely reduced the feeling of *bloat* that was so evident in P5. The pacing is better. But the game is still very dialogue heavy, with some serious moments, emotional moments, and laid back moments, with the crew just hanging out. It was great.

In other Persona games, I've never really had the urge to go in for a New Game Plus, or post game content, but here - I still have the drive to play, after finishing the story. Much of this is due to the more streamlined nature of the story and progression, but more than that, it's because I find the combat much more enjoyable.

author: 17c8aebd-1e1b-5e6a-8d10-149ea50c0e39
content:
This game is a very bizzare mix of P5's original mechanics and a hack n/ slash ARPG style game. 

The core problem that feeds into all the other issues I'm about to mention is that Strikers carries over ALL of the mechanics from P5, including baton passes, skills, elemental affinities, all out attacks, etc. This is way too many mechanics to juggle all at once while fighting enemies in real time. All of that stuff worked in P5 because it was a turn based game. But here, you're fumbling with the controls to desperately do the thing you need to do before you get killed. This process isn't helped by how awkward the control layout is, which to be fair, isn't a design issue, its a result of having so many more key assignments than you'd normally have in an ARPG. Sure, you can reassign them, but that doesn't help with there being way too many RPG-like mechanics in the first place. I suspect no layout could possibly make this mess feel intuitive. 

At the same, the game seems to be critically lacking basic features common to ARPGs: blocking, for instance. I also found out only after dying over and over again that while there is a dodge button, it is too awkward to use reliably (its H, try pressing that repeatedly while keeping your fingers on the standard WASD!) It also doesn't seem to stop the enemies from hitting you with skills, the only way to interrupt them being to down them with their weakness. 

Which isn't a reliable strategy because...you only get enough SP to use skills a few times during each infiltration. Since the red powerful shadow mechanic returns, this basically means you have to avoid those guys entirely. They're minibosses with massive HP sponges that take forever to kill if you can't beat their weakness. And even if you can, it drains all your SP. But don't try saving your SP either, because just sitting there mashing attack will get you killed by their repeated bombardment of undogeable skills before you have a chance to even dent their HP pool. Using non-weakness breaking skills also doesn't help, since they barely do enough damage to dent their HP pool either. 

So what you get at the end of all of this is a system that combines the worst of both worlds. You have the really shallow elemental weakness system that makes fights a cakewalk if you have the right skill, and impossible if you don't. You have to manage it at high speed while fighting in real time, but no simplified moveset that compliments this speed. 

You could try to coast by using the gun and basic attack, but those are really the only ARPG elements and they aren't very effective or deep because the bulk of the game is balanced around the RPG stuff carried over from P5. For instance, all you're really doing if you're not using skills is literally just mashing left mouse button over and over again. There is no timing mechanic, or having to vary your attacks, parry, etc...in other words, the basic fundamentals of an ARPG. Its all automated. 

Also, the screen is way too visually cluttered to even see what is going on or react to enemies properly. It made me really annoyed with the anime art style because sometimes I couldn't even see when an enemy is "down" and open for an all out attack because there were too many ridiculously flashy effects happening on the screen at once.

The story seems like it could be decent, but without breaking it into segments where you can control what you do each day, the game feels very streamlined and gives the player even less agency. The time management is the main thing that makes Persona games feel sorta like real RPGs in the first place, so without that, I just found myself lacking any kind of investment in the story. 

Skip this one. Its a JRPG half-assed into a clunky ARPG that doesn't get the high points of either genre correct, and simply re-hashes the main themes and characters of a much longer game.

author: bd453630-19a2-5033-8cd8-ebfbeeef2c4c
content:
I had this game on Switch and absolutely loved it. So when Black Friday rolled about and this game is also on sale, I just have to get it for my Steam Deck. Officially, it's not Steam Deck verified as of yet, but there are some tweaks I did that enabled it playable on Deck, but not without a few technical issues. The audio for one is missing from cutscenes when I play on my Deck. 

Otherwise, game runs perfectly fine.

Onto the game, story-wise:

This is technically a sequel to Persona 5/Persona 5 Royal, so if you hadn't played that game, you would be completely lost on the plot. It revolves around the Phantom Thieves, with it taking place nearly a year after the events of P5/P5R, with Joker returning to the town once more to meet up with his friends, and with Morgana in tow. However, they then stumbled across another alternate verse in a highly popular new app that had been making it's rounds, with certain individuals making use of this alternate verse.

Unlike P5R however, the 'villains' in this sequel aren't outright 'evil people'. They are still misguided individuals, and need a good dose of reality. But honestly, I prefer them a lot more than the villains in P5R. This game is also a very 'coming-of-age game'. If the prequel focuses only on one town and one area, this game actually has the group travelling across Japan.

Essentially a hack and slash game instead of the turn based combat in the previous game, the game still kept the basics of sneaking around and ambushing enemies. Dungeons however are easier than the original.

Hoping Valve soon verify the game for Steam Deck though. I really want to play it on my Steam Deck.

author: 7eb6bc37-60f1-5b8a-a5c0-cc9a3a86ec52
content:
Just to get it out of the way, if you're expecting an experience that even holds a candle to royal in any way, shape or form, you're going to be severely let down. P5S is basically just a story expansion pack in terms of its narrative, and retreading old ground is the name of the game. To the point where [spoiler] All the antagonists are just copies of the palace rulers with very slight tweaks, and the main antagonist is literally a somehow worse version of Yaldabaoth, right down to her design. The entire endgame is nearly identical to vanilla p5's: Go through not-mementos to kill not-holy grail to stop a false god devoid of humanity who is attempting to mind control all of mankind because they don't want free will anymore. It's such a step down from Maruki in every way that it enters freefall. [/spoiler]

The music is still mostly bangers and remixes of bangers, but the normal battle themes, while far from bad, do not even come close to 'take over' or 'last surprise'.

The gameplay is button mashy, but that's to be expected of a warriors style game. When the combat is fun, it's quite satisfying to pull some crazy move and kill 50 enemies at once. But when it's not fun, you'll be mindlessly hacking at the shins of a massive damage sponge while it one-shots you with every attack.

But the gameplay isn't what you come to this game for, you come to P5S to spend more time with the characters you love, and the game does a serviceable job giving the phantom thieves plenty more funny and heartfelt moments with each other. Unfortunately though, the game doesn't include any confidants other than the main group, and assumes that you spent valentine's day with Ryuji, meaning that there is very little actual continuation from the original game. Not only that, Yoshizawa doesn't even exist in this game's timeline, as for some baffling reason it was made as a sequel to vanilla P5 and lacks all of the story beats and characters introduced in Royal. The story barely even mentions the events of the original game, and when it does they're often throwaway bits of banter or a single dialogue option that elicits the same response as the other choices.

The side content SUCKS. Every single request you can get is either a mindless fetch quest in the overworld (without the ability to sprint) or agonisingly boring backtracking to levels you've already cleared. Go to this level and kill this specific enemy that only appears in this one location that's annoying to get to, then kill this specific enemy BUT with a specific character, AND THEN [spoiler] go back and kill the boss of a previous level again with no changes whatsoever. [/spoiler] It's padding at its most egregious, and it straight up locks gameplay perks behind it, making some of them pretty much mandatory.

The voice acting is way lower quality than in P5 or Royal, which is bizarre since the Va's sound identical to their 2016 selves in the latter. They either were given bad direction or the dev team went with bad takes, and it can be a bit distracting coming fresh off Royal. (Seriously Futaba sounds like she's drunk half the time and Ryuji's voice cracks every other word.)

Massive nit pick as the cherry on top: the menus have these cute little animations to them that are cool at first, but become agonising when you're just trying to get through the menus quickly and have to wait for the animations to play out before you can do whatever you're trying to do. Also, a r e y o u d o u b l e c h e c k i n g t h e r e q u e s t??

If there's a sale going on and you're a die-hard lover of these characters and this world like me, this game can be worth it for just a few more hours with the phantom thieves. But if you're expecting it to be an improvement or proper continuation to literally anything from its forebear, you'll be sorely let down.

author: adeb3656-b12c-5098-adf1-833c1cd38f1c
content:
[Much of my time was idle. A full playthrough is probably around 35-50 hours active time.]

I absolutely love Persona 5 + Royal and was glad to experience more of the narrative, which wasn't as good as the original with less personal growth among the player characters and less interesting early game villains, but still quite decent. In some sense it was also nice that it was a faster experience. But the combat gameplay just felt so terrible: Slow, cumbersome and frustrating.

It seems like there might be a lot of depth there if I had engaged more with it, but it just struck me as time consuming and not very worthwhile. I've had an excellent time both in original Persona combat and in fighting games such as Monster Hunter where I've soloed most hardmodes, but here the fighting just seemed very much not worth the effort, and fundamentally incompatible with the deep menu systems and skill usages from the Persona backbone. There were so many abilities and nuances that I'd have cared about in turn-based that just felt unimpactful or a waste of time in this system. For the first time I turned a game to easy and breezed through most of it. That made it a pretty decent visual novel but meant that anything to do with stats, fusions, gear, skills and attributes was pretty much meaningless and left the experience lackluster with major pacing issues. But before I did that, my experience with the game was a great deal worse.

A decent spin off game.

Mostly recommend the game for it's combat/systems and end of story moments

author: acf81452-e5f7-597a-b654-9043e5165198
content:
controls are a little wonky but the innovation is there. Gameplay so far encourages you to use all your party members and Joker's wild card in musou format seems to make good sense (i.e you can use free skills in your combo depending on the persona you have equiped).
Only issue is that theres alot to pay attention to so having a controller to slow down the game is a must. You could probably compare this game to ff11 / ff15 action strategy hybrid.

That said, i'm glad another action orientated game has been added to SMT. I've been wanting one since they stopped making Devil Summoner games.

In terms of story, they've flipped the script and the gang is exploring new territory this time around with social media being one of mediums for influencing 'cognition'.

------------------------------------------

Finished the game. Honestly glad i picked this up, a lot of the nit picks i had with P5R were tightened up in the gameplay this time around - i.e ambushing is slightly tricky and dangerous if you mess up - this makes it harder to keep alarms down to continue exploring. I would also stress again, the game makes it viable for you to play as everyone so you're not going to find yourself in a Tales situation where you can just play the game as your starting MC forever and call it a day. Overall a moderately challenging game that nudges you into trying new playing styles to keep it fresh. 

As for story it was serviceable. Nothing too over the top but the main draw is just touring around Japan with the crew. Haru is also given a lot more screen time this time around.

author: 63be9312-d540-5bad-b434-118f868f5155
content:
My honest review after clearing the game at 87 hours, not including post game. (1st playthrough)

1. Gameplay
A wonderful spin-off from the persona series set in the world of persona 5 with a unique twist on the dynasty warriors style. Hack n slash style of gameplay combined with mid fight persona switches and party member tagging. There are also interactable overworld objects that provide cover or grant their own attack options, allowing for different gameplay styles. In addition to persona abilities, all out attack returns and the mechanic of showtime changes up attack combinations and makes for a satisfying playthrough. 

2. Story
Even coming out of Persona 5 Royal with high expectations, Persona 5 Strikers has managed to prove itself to be a worthy sequel in its own right. The journey around Japan on a roadtrip feel so nostalgic and heartwarming. The plot is also a fair continuation to the original Persona 5 with its own twists in its story. As a game focused on battle gameplay and less on story, it manages to do its job well. 

3. Characters
The return of the Phantom Thieves starts off back at LeBlanc, a heartwarming reunion which brings back memories. The new Phantom Thieves also integrate themselves well into the team, enhancing the story further. The character development arcs of the new characters are great and being able to control each Phantom Thief individually plays perfectly into the immersion. 

4. Graphics
The overworld is amazing, using the same style as Persona 5 Royal. Each city is different from the next and really takes you on a tour around Japan. The new dungeons are fabulous, each having their own distinct features from those that mimic the real world to fantasy worlds. Attack and movement animations are fluid too. Persona 5 Strikers is without a doubt, visually stunning.

5. Audio
The OST in this game is once again, truly phenomenal, I had my doubts that it would come close to Persona 5 Royal, but considering how high the bar is, Strikers has done it. The electric remixes of returning Persona 5 OSTs are fantastic, fitting for the faster game pace of Strikers. Not forgetting the new tracks too, the first Jail's soundtrack was such a hook and made way for all the bangers in the OST, down to the final boss fight. 

6. Technical
Game is bug free and is buttery smooth, not a single crash throughout my playthrough. Load times are short as well.

7. Value
100% buy, bang for every buck, DLCs included! Even though this style of game isnt my preferred and it took a while to get used to, I loved every bit of it and have 0 regrets. 

Persona 5 Strikers offers more replayability compared to Persona 5 Royal and I can't wait to get back in to NG+ after clearing the post game. Fingers crossed that more Phantom Thieves content is on the horizon, as I have come to love the series so much, cmon Atlus make the dream come true.

author: 8052bfe2-d7ea-5c24-a69e-0a6d41a2b84b
content:
Cool spin-off for Persona 5. A nice roadtrip throughout Japan with all your friends to make some more memories and defeat evil gods (again), sadly romance options dont carry over, most characters except the main characters from 5 are missing and no Royal characters/content either.
Not the biggest fan of the combat either, its action-heavy and fast paced, but I prefer the normal turn-based combat. In this game it sometimes can get very chaotic with the dozens of enemies around you and abilites filling the whole screen, and a lot of the time you just button mash your way through hordes of enemies to victory, other than that its fine.
The game and therefore the story itself are shorter than the main game, which is to be expected, but because of that some story beats and especially the (main)antagonists are very surface-level and bland at times.
The  music, voice acting and visuals are all up to par with Persona 5 and the game also features some new tracks.

author: a3438bbd-eedd-581f-bae2-123511326df3
content:
Visual : The game looks really beautiful. It is more prettier than P5R.
Performance : Never had any performance issues with my intel i7 8th gen, 16GB DDR3 ram,  Gtx 1060 6GB locked in 60 fps.
Story: The story is good. not as detailed as other persona games but you will have fun time. The writing is really good and there are some cheesy line. Futaba might annoy you with some dialogues but other than that it's fine.
Combat: oh boy it's hit or miss. First I don't like the combat (recommending to play it in easy mode). It's dynasty warrior with persona paint on it. you can use you persona ability, items, baton pass but it's totally different game. I stopped playing after defeating first 2 villains. A month later i came back and exploring third dungeon and I really liking it now. Maybe it's because I was missing turned based combat that's why I didn't like the combat in the first place. In those months i was playing Persona 3 FES and some shooter games. I am surprised how good the combat feels now and on top of that the third dungeon is s cool. Dungeon crawling is really good i like it since i played it for the first time, it has nice platforming which I enjoy.

conclusion: It's not a spin off game. It is a sequel. It has lot of references from P5, There are some characters who related with Persona 5 characters and phantom thieves. If you never played any persona games before then try it who knows you may get hooked. Trying something new is always fun until you understand how battle system works.

content:
In terms of story, this game was following P5's story beat by beat right until the ending, but the new cast of characters felt a lot more shallow and uninteresting, with the exception of Zenkishi, all new characters were extremely forgettable.

In P5, every new palace also introduced a new member of the thieves, which made palace infiltration and the change of heart feel a lot more personal, while in this game, there is a tangential relation introduced between a monarch and an existing member of the thieves, which I think was not as well executed as it was in P5, maybe with the exception of the penultimate jail.

The combat is fun and flashy, the music is just as amazing as it ever was, the visuals are just as vibrant and beautiful, the characters are still lovable and engaging as ever, the game is a massive bundle of fun and definitely worth the time

author: 150d107a-2160-5cc3-bb53-81448c01e853
content:
Persona 5 Strikers is a bit of an oddball. It's a canon spin-off that assumes you played the base game, but it omits details from Royal. It’s also a Musō game with surprising complexity and the smallest scale battles in the genre. 

It’s not uncommon for Persona games to have weak beginnings and Strikers is no exception. Players are inundated with lousy tutorials and gameplay-interrupting cutscenes. It’s no wonder there are numerous negative reviews complaining about the supposed difficulty of the game. To put it as inelegantly as possible: unless those reviewers were playing on Merciless, this is a colossal example of a skill issue. While the tutorial is mediocre, the onus is on the player to use every tool in the game to succeed. Once you acquire the Master Arts for each Phantom Thief, the gameplay is like flowing water. Chaining special attacks and Persona skills into All-Out attacks feels great, and there are further opportunities for skill expression. Late-game bosses can be cut down like a knife through butter by remotely competent players.

There isn't much to discuss about Strikers' story, it's more Persona 5. While the story arcs are similar and many of the villains are laughably one-dimensional, Strikers shines with its upbeat charm and flashy aesthetic. Just don’t go in with hopes of a villain on par with Maruki, you’ll be disappointed. 

Strikers has a few remaining flaws. There are frame drops during cutscenes. The tension and pacing of dungeons are nonexistent since you can leave and return with full HP and SP. Ambushing Shadows is less precise than Persona 5. There's no “register all” button for the Velvet Room, and the way you purchase equipment in Sophie’s shop is unnecessarily inefficient, which is baffling considering Persona 5 solved this issue back in 2016. If you can overlook this, the game is a fine but flawed sequel.

author: a526dc33-af43-5d15-b5a7-3c957389d143
content:
Persona 5 Strikers is a spin-off set after the events of Persona 5 featuring most of the Phantom Thieves, developed in tandem with Omega Force and with significantly different gameplay to mainline Persona games.

I think that the gameplay differences are ultimately a good thing because turn-based combat, as good as it is in P5, gets boring eventually so the mix-up is appreciated here. The combat is fast-paced and can be engaging, however personally it's not ideal. Whilst I like character action and hack and slash games, P5S is essentially dynasty warriors with a persona skin, and I have some issues with that.

The hordes of enemies the game throws at you regularly make it very difficult to see what is actually happening on screen, and it doesn't feel like player skill is all that important in the grand scheme of things, rather most battles are just stat checks or a test of how long your patience will last against a bullet sponge. Fortunately, the effects look pretty decent and the music is fantastic as usual - so things don't get too boring.

In terms of story, P5S does some things well; the story is fairly interesting towards the middle-end, it's nice to see more of some of the Phantom Thieves and Zenkichi is a great character addition (he reminds me how much I would love a future persona game to feature a largely adult cast). But there are also a few failings; I think the story is too similar to themes that have already been explored in Persona 5 and Royal, and for the first half-or-so of the game it is far too formulaic in it's story-telling. Ultimately, it's quite predictable, which would be fine if things weren't presented as 'twists'.

I also have to say I was a bit disappointed by the absence of most of the characters that were in Persona 5 and Royal, and I feel that although it's set after Persona 5 it doesn't feel like it's a true sequel to the story.

And one final note because this was definitely the most annoying thing throughout my playthrough... The menus look great and all but they play so many animations when switching between menus that it significantly slows down navigating them, I also found the animation that plays when entering and exiting jails is too long when you're encouraged to go in and out often. Maybe it's a bit of a nitpick but for a fast-paced action game like this, the fact that the menus are way more cumbersome to navigate than the ones in P5 gets very frustrating very quickly, especially when you forget you're not controlling Joker so you can't swap out the character you're controlling in the menu.

All-in-all, it's a nice addition to the Phantom Thieves story which has a reasonable completion time, so I recommend it if you liked Persona 5 and want to see more of the main characters.

author: e8b7368f-731b-562d-92b6-311aa1a36237
content:
I was on the fence about this game at first. Yes, it is a continuation of P5 (one of my favorite JRPGs), but the choice of combat style a la Dynasty Warriors seemed a weird choice for me. Indeed, it took quite some getting used to at first. Many of the battles will present you with so much information on screen that it can be difficult to keep track of what is happening. Hordes of enemies swarm and remembering certain attack combos in unison with summoning your Persona felt like a feat in multitasking compared to the original combat of P5; though this may be more my lack of experience with hack and slash games if anything. Showtime attacks, which felt like more of an after-thought in Royal, return center stage akin to ultimate moves in combat, with each part member having their own unique set. Persona summoning is also incorporated into combat, with the ability to switch between your deck and cast spells as needed.

However, after a while, the combat became fun once I grew accustom to the controls. Playing this on PC, I would highly recommend plugging in a controller over M&K. There was something satisfying in the flashy and stylish way each Phantom Thief performs in a fight. Beyond the main combat, it keeps to the series' traditional Persona fusing system (complete with Velvet Room), along with the same familiar abilities, strengths and weaknesses. Any veteran of the Persona will pick up on these with ease. 

The gameplay takes place in various "Jails," similar to Palaces where they are tied to and modeled after a particular boss. Even after completion, you can revisit each one to tie up loose ends such as obtaining a rare Persona or completing side jobs that will occasionally come in. Another change is lack of Confidants or daily social activities in favor of focusing largely on the main group. Because of this change, late additions to the party in P5, such as Futaba or Haru, receive a lot more screen time. 

In terms of story, this game is a direct sequel to Persona 5 (vanilla, not Royal). The Phantom Thieves reunite to tackle another threat as they travel Japan in a grand road trip. The Metaverse returns and, unsurprisingly, someone is messing with it again. It follows much of the same structure as P5 in finding the current big bad, taking them down, and moving on to the next target. Strikers deviates from the main game in that you no longer have major hub areas to explore outside of the Metaverse. Most new location only come with minor exploration, with most of the meat being within the Jails themselves. In-game time is fast-tracked in comparison, with typically only a few 'days' between missions. No new formula here, but if you're looking for more Phantom Thieves goodness, this game will offer it. The game is not nearly as long as its predecessor; I finished at about 54 hours, which included a bit of time building my Persona team and tackling various side jobs/bosses. 

Most of the same beats are here: stylistic combat, great music, an engrossing story, and the same lovable cast of characters. There is not much more to say beyond that, as anyone coming out of P5 will feel at home here (at least once mastering the combat system). While not as grand as those of the main line games, it is a worthy sequel to try something new and help pass the time waiting for P6.

author: 4ea7640a-317b-515b-93b7-6b31eda003cc
content:
Positive experience overall, but I wouldn't pay much more than 30 bucks for this.

First of, there's basically absolutely no way I can recommend this if you haven't played p5 or p5r. A significant amount of the enjoyment I got from the game comes from watching the Phantom Thieves reunite and mess around in their tour around Japan and Jails(This game's version of Palaces). Playing around on a beach, visiting landmarks, tasting local cuisine; the characters having fun is pretty fun to watch.  Some of the characters even get some additional characterization which can range from meh to decent. 

Other than that? Zenkichi and Sophia are likeable additions to the team. Their respective character arcs couldn't be more predictable, but they at least get decent pay offs. It also helps that they have colourful enough personalities and designs which blend in surprisingly well with the rest of the phantom thieves.

The combat is also pretty decent, though it can get draggy if you don't make use of your skills to hasten through certain fights. 

There are more negatives. The story rehashes a lot of elements from the original game's story, except most of the climatic moments didn't have the build up and pacing leading up to them to make said moments especially emotional. Conceptually, it had a lot of potential. It was just executed rather poorly. Has a few cool moments though. 

Most of the sidequests are so boring I wonder why they're there in the first place. 
"Kill X Number of Y Mob with Z Character" 
"Collect X Number of Y Item Drop"
"Revisit a boss and kill it a second time"

That's about it really. The only thing that I can add on is that it maintains the visual flare from the original p5. All in all, it was fun and I'm glad I played it, but the game is riddled with some serious issues that makes it difficult to recommend at it's original price tag. Not to mention it's only like 20-30 hours.
