author: 297c160c-1f36-5aff-9b5d-0233017eb2b1
content:
Persona 5 Strikers is a disappointing sequel to an exceptionally well established title. Poor visuals, cut content, lack of an enjoyable combat system and uninteresting music leaves much to be desired. What remains is a decent story which is a replica of the original Persona 5, a couple of new likeable characters and the fantastic cast - The Phantom Thieves.

Performance is a mess, need to set affinity to utilize all processors which minimizes stuttering.

Although a chore to complete because of the off-putting combat system, Strikers is a must for anyone who wants more of the Phantom Thieves. It's not any better than Royal, very far from it but it will help fill the void that Royal will have left.

author: 7368e5ce-9804-5206-a0da-036843ee889b
content:
First off, if you didn't play Persona 5, this game is not for you. There is a legitimate story in this game that extends beyond the standard musou spinoff plot of "all your favourite characters have been sucked into a non-canonical alternate universe". It assumes that you have played through P5 all the way to the end. As such, the rest of this review will contain spoilers for P5.

Persona 5 Strikers is honestly a very weird game to review. It is a musou or warriors-style game that tries to cram as many P5 mechanics into a musou game as possible, and the end result is a musou game that is utterly unique, though in a way that is likely to annoy many players who are approaching this game purely from the musou perspective. However, P5 fans will see these quirks as knowing references to the original game and appreciate them nonetheless, even if the game is somewhat jankier as a result.

Plot-wise, P5S picks up not long after the end of P5 (the base game, not the Royal ending). The phantom thieves meet up for summer vacation only to find that people are messing with the Metaverse once again even after they destroyed Mementos. This meddling has resulted in change-of-heart incidents all over Japan, which the police have decided to pin on the Phantom Thieves. Thus, the gang now has to go on a road trip all across Japan, solving Metaverse crimes and clearing their own name.

Overall, I'd say that the writing in P5S feels like a lighter but still authentic-feeling version of what we got in P5. One interesting angle that P5S takes is that while most of the Palace rulers in P5 are straight up irredeemable villains, all of the Jail monarchs (this game's version of the Metaverse) in P5S are sympathetic people who have been wronged in one way or another and got tempted to use the powers of the Metaverse to take revenge on society. Many of them have backstories that directly challenge the beliefs of the Phantom Thieves, causing them to question how right and just their actions are. Unfortunately, while these are interesting ideas, they do not have time to develop properly due to the much shorter length of P5S, both in terms of gameplay time and in-universe calendar days. While a typical Palace in P5 might consist of two weeks of investigating the backstory of the Palace ruler, two weeks given to infiltrate the palace and steal the treasure and another two weeks to see the fallout of the change of heart and how it affects everyone, in P5S you will typically discover a Jail, learn about the ruler's backstory, perform a change of heart and move on to the next city all in less than a week.

However, if there's one area where the writing of P5S really shines, it's in the cheerful and bubbly character interactions amongst the Phantom Thieves. If you enjoyed the many interactions between team members in P5 during the less serious moments, such as the beach day, the Hawaii trip and the cultural festival, P5S is a treasure trove of moments like that. After all, the premise of the game is a cross-country summer vacation road trip, and every new city they visit is an excuse for them to enjoy the local tourist attractions. If you're a Futaba or Haru fan especially, they have much more screentime in P5S than P5 because they're part of the starting roster right from the beginning.

In terms of battle mechanics, most of it is standard musou game fare. You have a light attack and a heavy attack, and combining them in various ways leads to various combos that have various effects like air launchers and crowd control. Every playable character also has a unique mechanic associated with them. For example, Ann can infuse her whip with fire so that her normal attacks also deal fire damage, and Ryuji can activate a stance that increases his defense and knockback resistance. The unique mechanic that P5S brings compared to other musou games is the return of elemental weaknesses and resistances from P5. You can deal elemental damage by either spending SP to cast Persona abilities as AOE damage effects, or by using certain attack combo paths that naturally end with your character summoning their Persona without using SP. Hitting a regular enemy with an elemental weakness will trigger a small all-out attack which damages all enemies in the area, while minibosses and bosses have shield icons that must be broken with elemental attacks. Breaking a single shield will lead to a one-more attack which is a bit of free damage against them, while breaking all the shields will trigger a much larger all-out attack which deals a lot of damage and leaves the boss downed for a period of time.

On one hand, I don't really mind the elemental system from an offensive standpoint. Some people complained that bosses only take chip damage from everything besides elemental attacks, but every musou game has enemies split between fodder grunts that only exist to charge your ultimate ability and actually threatening enemies that need you to focus and think for a bit. On the other hand, I really don't like the elemental system from a defensive standpoint. Like I said, in musou games you're meant to treat the hundreds of small enemies as invisible and focus on the few large enemies, but in this game the small enemies also have elemental attacks, and some of them are super-effective against your character's Persona. Getting hit by a super-effective elemental attack, even from a grunt enemy, can stun you and lead to you getting comboed to death by the miniboss, and it's impossible to keep track of every small enemy when there can be literally dozens of enemies on screen at any one time.

The pacing of the combat sections is lifted straight out of P5, which will probably annoy many musou fans. Most musou games have you running through a decently large battlefield, taking down roaming groups of enemies while prioritising specific targets according to the story. In P5S, you take down one group of enemies, then you get a cutscene explaining a new story development, then another fight, then another cutscene etc. This is basically exactly how the Palaces in P5 functioned, but this is highly atypical for a musou game and people who are not accustomed to the pacing of P5 will probably get annoyed. Also, there is a very weird and annoying quirk with the game where you are allowed to exit the Jail at various checkpoints to fully recover health and SP and go back into the Jail at the same point, it doesn't advance the calendar and there is no penalty for doing so. In fact, the game explicitly tells you that this is a legitimate tactic. In that case, why not let the checkpoint heal you directly, instead of making you wait through 2 loading screens to exit and re-enter the Jail?

Also, most of the P5 gameplay outside of dungeon-crawling has essentially been removed in P5S. The calendar system is in the game essentially in name only. There is no deadline for clearing Jails, and leaving and re-entering Jails does not advance the calendar. The calendar only advances with main story completion and the time-management aspect of P5 is no longer present. There are also no social stats for you to level up, so your time spent outside of Jails will consist mainly of buying supplies and talking to your teammates to get side quests. However, to compensate for that, all the Jails you visit will still remain accessible even after you clear them and you will revisit them to complete side quests, which is a departure from P5 Palaces.

Overall, I would recommend this game to anybody who played P5, enjoyed the interactions of the Phantom Thieves and wished that there was more of that to snack on. If you're the kind of person who loved all the vacation side stories in P5 and wished that there was a game which is 50% of just that, then this game is definitely for you. Honestly I would hesitate to recommend P5S at full price, but this game goes on pretty steep discount quite frequently and it's definitely worth picking up during a sale.

author: 7b57506b-c274-56b6-9b21-4ebfe990d4c2
content:
Do I recommend this.. I honestly don't know. I wish there was a maybe button. 
I find that every time I try to play this I realize i'd just rather be playing Persona 5. The story isn't as strong right off the bat, but on top of that the gameplay also isn't as strong. I say this as someone that doesn't really like turn based RPGs. The gameplay of this reminds me closest of Dynasty Warriors and like Dynasty Warriors the combat neither satisfies nor challenges and I felt like I was coasting through the game.

At this point the phantom thieves know each other, and while each 'monarch' tries to relate to the phantom thieves for me it fell flat on the first two monarchs. Where as Persona 5 immediately gut punches you with a corrupt teacher abusing students, Strikers seems to just.. start. The first enemy is a pop star abusing her fans which never grabbed me. There's little in the way of character development as all of the phantom thieves already had their character development and got to know each other.

In the end this game is for folks that just want to see another adventure for the Phantom Thieves, but be warned it doesn't touch the quality of the original.

author: 805c44d6-5dad-5a55-91b3-638790324c55
content:
Do you love musou?  Let me share with you my favorite part of this musou hack-and-slash brawler game with a Persona skin:

You will enter an area, get a bunch of story, take 2 steps, get some dialog about a monster, fight the monster, take two steps, get a bunch of story, take 2 steps, get some dialog about a monster, fight the monster, and these steps will repeat until you finish the area.  In the middle, you're going to get interrupted nonstop with tutorials until they're done, and then you're going to get some more you didn't think existed.

All the while, 2 steps, stop, fight, 2 steps, stop, fight, 2 steps, stop, fight.

30 hours of that.

10/10 A++ would musou this way again!

content:
Only buy this game if two things are true, 1. it's on sale and 2. that you really want more persona while you wait for persona 6. 
*SPOILERS PAST THIS POINT*




The game was very repetitive and palaces where difficult to call unique from one another just because they were all castle with a different coat of paint, additionally most of the bosses/enemies felt very bullet sponge like, making it have a artificial playtime, even playing on easy mode it took up to 15 minutes to complete a boss fight, which would consist of light attack 2x + one special so as to proc X affinity to hit the weakness which felt much less satisfying compared to P5. The story is practically non existent following the same twists the P5 had. however if you are like me and want to play just to hear the Phantom theives chat and hang out this game is worth it, when it's on sale. author: 7d20301f-484a-59a3-bef6-ed2f21bcc8f8
content: It's not the worst musou game I've played but no where near the best either.  The boss enemies are extreme HP sponges which just gets boring.  Honestly, by the lock boss before the end of the 2nd jail I am completely done with it.  The HP pools of the bosses have ground my enjoyment of the game down to 0.  Learning patterns and rinsing and repeating over and over for far too long is the reason I don't play NASCAR games and is now the reason I will never play this again.  I've got better things to do than go to one boss battle after an another spending anywhere from 20-30 minutes doing the same things over and over.  Otherwise, the elemental system from Persona was interesting to work with in a musou but doesn't fit as well as it does in a turn based RPG.  The story so far has been a mix of all right and mediocre and since I just finished putting 176 hours in P5R, it was nice to have a continuation with the characters but sadly, this was a waste of my money and I will never play it again.

author: 8a5d8b50-058d-589f-b8ff-e6bfcb64f7ab
content:
Can't speak on this port of the game as when it originally launched, I had frequent crashes. However, having since played the PS4 version of the game I can confidently say it is an incredible game. A true sequel to the base version of Persona 5, P5S is an absolute perfect blend of both Dynasty Warriors gameplay and Persona gameplay, in a way that I have not seen from any other "warriors" type cross over game to date. 

Though the combat system has changed entirely to a hack and slash action RPG style game, it still manages to maintain a lot of the systems that made Persona 5 what it is, such as the baton pass, Persona fusion, elemental weaknesses, one mores and even adding Showtime attacks which mimic their Persona 5 Royal counterparts. On top of this, you still have the typical Persona gameplay of wandering about various parts of Japan and spending time with your buds, as you would expect, but this time without the time constraints. 

Another aspect that thoroughly impressed me was the story, though it is "just a crossover game" it is not treated as such and given the full seriousness and treatment of a sequel to Persona 5. With a fully fleshed out story, two fantastic party members with their own story arc and all the character development from P5 that makes Morgana a bearable addition to the cast now! 

You get the full on Persona experience and the full on Dynasty Warriors experience with this game, the best of both worlds with no shortage on either of them. So if you're a fan of either game, I highly recommend this game. The only thing I will say is go play Persona 5 Royal first, as you will lose a lot if you haven't played that game first.

author: 8fe1d726-d5cb-5d3e-99d3-10243c8d209c
content: A big criticism I see from people about P5 is that it doesn't have those friendship moments with the Phantom Thieves as P4 did with the Investigation Team. This whole game felt like those friendship moments that P5 lacked. I felt way closer to the characters after this second adventure. I thought about playing Strikers before P5 since it released on Steam first, but I am so glad I waited so I could meet the characters properly. As far as Musou game sequel/spinoffs go, this is a great one that pulled off the same effects as Fire Emblem Warriors Three Hopes. I got to meet some old friends, make some new ones, and enjoy an already-built world in a new format.

author: d24c878d-1157-5a7f-a362-478bbe8f10ce
content:
This game was supposed to cure the gaping hole in my heart left after finishing Persona 5 Royal, but like a drug, it only held me over temporarily before striking that hole even deeper than it was previously.

In all seriousness, for being only half the length of its predecessor, Persona 5 Strikers packs on hell of a punch. The gameplay is a pretty big shift for those who have grown acclimated to Persona's turn based style. Yes, the camera controls are absolutely vile, and you may need to reach near-divinity to process all the information on screen, but you get used to it pretty quick. Once you find your favorite character(s) to play and get some levels under your belt, things get a lot smoother. The story maintains the bar of quality set by Persona 5, definitely continuing its style, and the new characters that come along for the ride are a blast, and bring some unique angles to the Phantom Thieves. Once the story gets going, it's hard to put down.

All in all, 10/10, and as a side note, you should definitely let Haru drive, trust me.

Persona 5R ran perfectly, and Persona 5S has been the most unstable game of this year across steam. Absolutely unplayable. author: c6c92c6a-d862-5bde-87ca-fc9173de99ec
content:
Overall great follow up to P5.
Story-wise it's a direct sequel to P5 Vanilla ending. Story itself is very similar to main storyline of P5, but it flows better thanks to pre-established PT characters and is very interesting because of its focus on trauma and tie-ins with PTs. It does start kinda dry tho, but picks up later.
New characters are great, espeically new additions to the PTs.
Gameplay is dynasty warrior style action rpg, its good, but sometimes bosses can feel a bit spongey.
Soundtrack is more fire from Lyn.

Only bad part is PC port. 
60 fps and compressed assets suck. I wish they would do a refresh with 120 fps and 4K assets like they did with P5R. 
Default controls are pretty terrible.
I was also constantly getting this annoying bug where your hotkeys just stop working in menus until you alt-tab.
Also loading times are pretty terrible, even on NVMe SSD.

content: appallingly bad game that tries to somewhat amount to what persona 5 was. combat is clunky as all hell, ui tries to be stylish like p5 but is a pain in the ass to navigate. somehow, scenes in between run worse than combat scenes, and the issue of too little SP recovery is still apparent, but much worse this time, as you can only really use 3 moves before running out of stamina. bonus content is pretty cool, but it does not in any way enhance the gameplay. a shame, because this games story and characters are actually pretty cool and i would definitely enjoy it. alas, the game is not at all up to code for persona 5's standards, or even just regular video game standards. if you like hack and slash games, try it. if you like persona 5 enough, try it. buy it on sale.

author: 496d2b31-bf90-523f-8d56-f65d05d83b04
content:
Coming into Persona 5 Strikers, I thought the game would be a fun spin off where I get to see all my favorite characters in a hack and slash game. However after completing this game I'm more than happy to say that this game is more than just a spin off, but a worthy sequel to the Persona 5 story and an excellent addition to the franchise. 

The combat in the game at first was a challenge at first, but after getting used to the controls it felt smooth and it incorporated the core elements of Persona 5's battle system like baton bass and persona creation excellently. Each character felt like they had a unique combat style that matched their character and were all fun to use, with my favorite's being Yusuke and Zenkichi.

The story was also a strong point of the game, and the two new members of the phantom thieves, Sophia and Zenkichi, were wonderful addition to the main cast and added a lot of life to this game. The story also allowed characters that didn't get as much development in the original game to get fleshed out more, with Haru getting the most development out of any the original cast. The villains of this game had some really great boss designs and were characterized in a sympathetic light, which allowed them to act as foils and further the growth of certain members of the Phantom Thieves.  My favorite part of this game was while there was an overarching plot about freeing people from their trauma, the game also spent a lot of time on slice of life elements. It really did feel like I was on a road trip with good friends, and made me appreciate the Phantom Thieves characters that much more. 

The visuals of this game are top notch and maintain the flair and art style from the original game that we all know and love. The soundtrack is phenomenal and just as good as the soundtrack from Persona 5 Royal. Lyn absolutely brings her A game to the table with all the new songs featuring her, and the remixes of songs such as Last Surprise and Blooming Villain do the originals justice.

I would wholeheartedly recommend Persona 5 Strikers to anyone who is a fan of Persona 5/Persona 5 Royal that just wants to spend some more time with the characters that many of us have come to love. It's a fantastic addition to the franchise and I hope Atlus will continue explore the world of Persona 5 in the future.  

An easy 10/10!

author: d99e64a3-5cf7-5015-a8fd-98e7879d922b
content:
Okay game, horrible port. Buy only if you really want more Persona 5 content, and even then just try get it on a console or something.

Constant crashes mixed with no autosave (???) and awkward placement of manual save points (luckily cutscenes even with chooseable dialogue options are completely skipable) , barebones support for PC graphic options, esp over 1080p/FHD.

Gameplay is hit or miss leaning on miss. Mixing hack n slash with normal Persona turnbased elements, like how Dynasty Warriors does it, but worse. The real time actions of the enemies makes it frustrating to use strategic skills and the hack n slash part does not feel good to play standalone (saving grace is Yusuke with his carbon copy Vergil moveset). 
To do well in hard mode feels more like needing to grind levels and cheese skills and items you to obtain from mindless mob grinding (kill trash mobs in an area, leave the area, kill the new batch that respawned and repeat) to beat the insanely bloated HP of bosses and mini bosses; otherwise you'll be stuck in a 30 min clunky boss fight that ends prematurely because you ran out of SP and your computer friends died somewhere between the fight starting and you zoning out after watching the boss's health bar tick down at like 1% every 5 minutes. The AI teammates in your party act like basic computers reacting to enemy attacks (ironically not smart enough to be AI), yet somehow manage to still be useless to the point you have to babysit them esp on hard.

Story is regular Persona business (pretty decent overall but not as good as the mainline games such as P5R, P4G, P3 etc.) but it is also completely linear and can be skipped through without missing too much (useful, because it's what I had to do after losing hours of saves multiple times). IMO it almost has ruins the impact of the story/ending Persona 5/Royal had given you, especially if you play this one right after.

Banging music though, makes up for all the shortcomings. But again don't play this on PC unless you have to.

(This was written after losing a few hours of grinding for the 3rd time)

author: b3cb3832-7d77-5c67-aeb7-02a357b78acf
content:
This game is fun and I like it but i have a few problems with it.

First is the anti-aliasing sucks balls, you either have everything blurred and smudgy or jagged.
Second is the difficulty spike between easy and normal, it goes from being baby mode to actually challenging, I was trying to beat a boss and wiped 5 times in normal but beat in 10 seconds on easy.
Third is the PC controls are top tier garbage, you have to use a controller or you're gonna have a bad time.
Fourth is the price, this game feels so cheap it should not cost more than P5R which is also on steam. buy a key or get on sale.

If you can look past these issues then you'll have fun.

content: I've always hated the persona series but this has been my most disliked one so far to a certain fault. It's still very time-consuming repetitive with cheesy dialogue that make the story goofy at times. The map designs are very cramped and simplistic with very little depth. Overall I would not recommend this. This will be the last persona game that I ever get.

author: 4bf0ea19-4139-5043-8d1b-7025434f478a
content:
I enjoyed this game WAY more than I thought I would, definitely worth getting it.

I loved how much it focuses on developing the character's friendship as a group, I think it's one of the strongest points it has, which is something the original P5 could have improved upon. The story is a bit predictable and has many repeated points with the original game, but some bits are really good. I'd almost say the main plotline is secondary until well past the halfway point of the game, up until that point it's basically Slice of life with dungeon crawling, and I don't mean it as a downside. The Phatom Thieves go on a vacation through Japan and it's full of hilarious moments.

The gameplay itself is the main complaint about this game since it's not turn-based, but people seem to forget this is a spin-off title developed by Tecmo Koei, and honestly as an action RPG it's very entertaining and considered to be one of the best they've developed. I found it incredibly overwhelming at the beginning with all the tutorials and characters with different playstyles, but I got used to it and appreciate that they made all characters playable, relevant and they actively encourage you to learn them.
Also the soundtrack is a complete banger, easily a top contender for best Persona soundtrack, put me Daredevil and Axe to Grind in a 10 hour loop and I'm a happy person.

As a side note: If you see the text blurry, disabling antialiasing fixes it. Graphically the game is not the prettiest while comparing it to P5 or P5R, and those games weren't pushing any boundaries either, but it's something completely secondary in this franchise

author: e067e48c-d853-5858-806d-61ca49cea472
content:
Persona 5 Strikers (P5S) is an action RPG title that is co-developed with Omega Force - who popularized Musou-style action genre with Dynasty Warriors series where the action revolves around mowing down ridiculous hordes of enemies. I initially posted my review at the 37h mark (around 3/4 of the story) but felt compelled after I've finished the game to make the review more complete, in order to do it justice - because the game went from being pretty good at first to being great when I was technically done with it. 

It should be noted that P5S appears to be the canonical sequel to Persona 5 (P5), so if you're the type that needs to follow stories in chronological order, you might want to pass on this game for now. Personally, I've yet to play P5 myself although I do have some background having watched the awful Persona 5: The Animation before. If you have no background of P5, some names and terminology that come up in the game might leave you confused but I don't think they are a huge issue. And if you're invested in the story thereafter, then all the more reason to pick up Persona 5 Royal (P5R) - the definitive version of P5 also available on Steam - when you're done with P5S.

In terms of gameplay, other titles in the Musou genre (which I'll refer to as "Musous") are laid out in mission stages where the combat field (the stage itself) involves mowing down hordes of enemies while completing set objectives - visceral large-scale combat on an open field while being outnumbered and yet overpowered. However, P5S's game structure is that of a JRPG and is an authentic Persona experience. Instead of stages, P5S uses JRPG dungeons (known here as "jails") which become available as the story progresses. When encountering an enemy (or via scripted events) in dungeons, it will usually spawn a horde of enemies - this is where the Musou-influence comes into play. If you're familiar with Persona series, just think of the turn-based combat being replaced by action combat. There are some minor platforming/puzzle-solving in various dungeons which I didn't appreciate but they do add variety. Outside dungeons, you hang around in a designated open city like those in the Yakuza series except there's no fighting to be had. There are side quests in the game (known as requests) which are mostly kill/fetch quests - nothing super interesting but aren't annoying either. In terms of content, there's the main story comprising of a few dungeons. Finishing the story will allow you to make a clear save to access post-game content which comes in the form of requests to obtain the best weapons for your team. Finishing the post-game content will then allow you to start NG+ which also unlocks the highest difficult, "Merciless". In NG+, everything you previously earned is carried over. There are a total of 9 playable characters and 8 of them are accessible from the start of your first "non-tutorial" dungeon while the 9th will join later in the story. In NG+, you can access all 9 in the first actual dungeon.

Combat is one area the game shines in and caters to various styles of play. The controls in the game are responsive and all the Persona mechanics are very well integrated into the combat. Your attacks are made up by strings of basic attacks ending with a special attack. In addition, you have a dodge that has invincibility frames and can invest points in perks later on to capitalize on perfect dodges. If you're not a fan of fast-paced action, there's also a dedicated button to access your personas and also freezes time. There's also access to Persona fusion like any other Persona games. Different personas have different (but fixed) effects at the end of their combo strings, so finding a good mix of skills that work well alongside the combo strings is what the substance of build-making is - figuring out what skills are good and the fusion path to inherit the skills you want, to the target persona to fuse. In P5S, skills learnt by personas (i.e. not inherited from fusion) are always remembered and can be reconfigured when out of combat. The party size is up to 4 and members can be changed when out of combat, with the main restriction that Joker (the main protagonist) must always be in the team. So if you want to go at it alone, you can do so but only with Joker. All characters have a different play style and you can swap to any party (not team) member during combat. Progression takes the form of levels/equipment, persona roster, character-specific arts and a bond board which is used to unlock team-wide perks. Combat may initially feel plain and restrictive due to low SP gauge for abilities but gets better with game progression as characters learn new skills and from unlocking perks at the bond board. Although Musous tend to have a bad rep for being no-brainer button-mashers, P5S isn't quite the case and you can play it as a skill-based game by not abusing consumables, which will be in short supply anyway unless you grind for them. Boss fights are especially fun.

The story is pretty decent but I think it's the storytelling that really shines here which is helped by the good writing and overall presentation. Like any Persona titles, the story starts out with a mystery and progresses with investigations. The dialogues are mostly full voiced and the English dub is pretty good although you should keep in mind that we're talking about anime here. The script is well-written and there's a lot of humour which the voice actors did a really good job in delivering. The story itself takes up like 50% of the game with cutscenes and non-action-related gameplay, so if you're invested in the story, this might be a good thing; if not, the game will feel like a beefed up visual novel with sparse but lengthy action gameplay in-between. While I did enjoy the story conversations, one gripe I have with it is that there's a lot of repeat information which feels more like padding rather than real value to the overall plot. For Persona fans specifically, there aren't any social links here and literally no consequences to player choice - it is, after all, not a mainline Persona game. However, there are many bonding events that do more than just a serviceable job of fleshing out the friendship of the protagonists.

Presentation is top notch in pretty much every Persona game I know of (since Persona 3) and this one is no different. The UI looks sleek while remaining usable. Combat looks amazingly flashy and feels good to pull off combos/abilities. The music was initially only serviceable for me, although they are quite fitting, which was quite disappointing given this is one area Persona titles tend to excel at. However, I did really like the themes in the dungeons of the later half. The track during the final boss fight was exceptional which I thought was why that fight felt more epic than it already was - think Ameno Sagiri in Persona 4 Golden. My only gripe with the presentation is that the UI clutter makes fights with hordes of enemies difficult to read and I would've preferred if they went with much fewer but stronger enemies for encounters - like other Persona titles where enemies are limited to a few so that fights are more strategic.

Performance-wise, I'm happy to report that I didn't encounter any technical issues in the entirety of my 90+ hours playtime. Game runs great and loads fast on my AMD 2700X/GTX1060 6GB setup even when installed on a spinning HDD.

In conclusion, I've thoroughly enjoyed P5S and would strongly recommend it even at its asking price. It has a decent story that is well delivered, has a good amount of content going for it, the combat is fun and caters well to players looking for simplicity or depth. As for replayability, it depends. But that's what I'm doing right now in NG+ merciless. Overall, fantastic game!

author: 1a560981-0434-55fd-9c21-3560b851abe1
content:
In short, Persona 5 Strikers is a wonderful game with a nice history, amazing voice actors and soundtrack, fun gameplay and beautiful graphics. I absolute recommend this game.

Full review bellow, may cointain spoilers, I dont know.

I really loved Persona 5 Strikers, not only it brought back our dear Phantom Thieves together filling that void that you get when your favorite game or show ends but it also delivered an amazing history and game.

History

I really enjoyed the history, usually Persona games are really straight foward, the bad guys are evil, the good guys bring them down, nothing wrong with that, however, in Persona 5 Strikers most of the villains arent actually evil people and its really good to see such shift from an abusive professor that beats middle schoolers and abuse them to an artist and singer consumed by sadness and sorrow doing some wrong things after obtaining an unknown power through Emma that could help them in running away from scars from the past.

Not only it gave the gang a weird feeling after beating the shadow form of the villains, but they also felt so connected to the problems they were facing. Instead of having the usual hero vs villain fight to save the people, our dear Phantom Thieves wanted to help the villains aswell, since they were good people too! It was so nice to see that people could forgive people like Natsume cherishing his comeback or Mariko listening to the mother that lost his daughter saying that Mariko was really important to the city and wanted her as mayor again.

We're living times were people define you for mistakes you commited, you see on Social Media people absolutely terrorizing famous people lifes for errors they did 2? 6? years ago, ignoring that despite being famous they're humans aswell, imperfect and capable of changing. People do it to everyone nowadays, one mistake and your life is ruined.
So Persona 5 Strikers history brings a really important message, that not everyone that do mistakes are evil people, that people despite doing wrong things wether you forgive them or not CAN change. I really liked it, it is really important to have themes like this delivered to us.

I really liked Sophia and Zenkichi, both were such well developed characters. Despite having the means to have an extensive knowledge, Zenkichi being a grown adult working for PubSec and Sophia an AI with full acess to information, both had such low knowledge of emotions and spent the whole journey learning. It was so warming to see Zenkichi coming to therms with Akane and finally facing Owada, thus, becoming a good father and a good friend to himself, no longer running away from his ideals and goals. Sophia, even though she is an AI, displayed so many emotions, everytime she interfered and spoke to villains, showing her views and ideas about what was going on, I could imagine her crying if she could, for an AI she has so much passion, its like even though she doesnt have a physical heart, it is there. She became a caring and loving friend, a true humanity companion :)

It was also nice to see how much Makoto and Haru matured, while Ryuji and Ann are still teenagers slacking their duties on school hahaha

Gameplay

I enjoyed so much the way Atlus introduced Persona to hack n slash, it was really well done. Battling felt so satisfying with such beautiful graphics and soundtrack, the voice acting is top notch. Every character had an unique way of attacking and the way baton pass works in P5S was really well done.
Despite having so much fun, there are things I believe it could be done diferently.

Since the battles are so action packed and fast, having an image show every time you attack the enemy weakness not only becomes a visual polution but it also decrease the value that it had on previous Persona Games. It is so satisfying to see an image pop up with a close face of your character when you crit in Persona 4, it didnt feel that satisfying having the close up every time you attack the enemy weakness, sometimes it felt like it was delaying the battle and I know I just felt this way because the image showed every time. The close-up face image should only show sometimes, I suppose in future hack'n'slash games, Persona magic abilities could crit too and therefore the image would only show if the ability landed a crit? I dont know.

I am grateful that the commands arent a mess for keyboard users, I had no problem playing this game on keyboard and could enjoy it's full experience despite not having a controller. I dont think its a flaw, its just an opinion, but, I wish they changed the default key for guns, it felt weird to use ctrl key + shift for charged shots and sometimes I accidentaly pressed the windows key, also, it was difficult to leave the Gun mode when using Sophia due to the keys being so far away. Maybe its a problem in my end, who knows.

Soundtrack + Voice Acting

Amazing as always, Persona games always deliver good music and this game is no exception! The new versions of musics used in Persona 5/Persona 5 Royal are REALLY good, I couldnt image that such good tracks could be improved since they were already good, but they improved them a lot to fit this game! Keeper of Lust in Persona 5 Strikers is such a banger, congratulations!
Also, thanks Atlus for possibility of choosing old Persona games battle musics, it was such cool addition, I really loved it.

The voice actings was perfect! There were so many emotional moments that would NEVER be as good as they are if the dub wasnt so well done! Yusuke telling Natsume to dont lump Sayuri with the soulless history that he wrote, Sophia and Ichinose/Konoe, Ryuji telling Emma to shut up when she was telling bad things to Sophia. So many good moments.

Ahh I feel like playing again just by remembering those moments haha, Persona 5 had such a good dub and Persona 5 Strikers keeps the tradition.

-----

Thanks to everyone involved in the production of this game, it is really an amazing game and I felt so happy while playing it.
There are so many good things to write about Persona 5 Strikers that would make my review so big, but in short, thank you very much for creating such cool game for my favorite series!

author: af6c21d3-d891-52b3-911b-5c6d08140527
content:
summary get this if you finished persona 5 or royal.

this game is a p5/p5r base setting with changed battle system and also social system since the story set after p5 ending which you suppose to max confidant with all your friend. story wise still the same p5 vibe so if you like p5 you like this as well.

as for gameplay most ppl think this is a warrior like gameplay with p5 skin, while truth is its persona/smt series base system but changed to warrior like battle style with it p5 battle adaption such as weakness/all out attack/baton pass/show time etc... it start out kinda difficult when you dont understand the game or you are not action game player, but as you play and understand the system more you feel the p5 adaption is on point. 

overall while the game is far from perfect but it put in effort to try new stuff instead of just skin change. maybe it will be better next adaption if there any.

author: 67fc4f81-c0d9-5a0e-967f-5c401a93d035
content:
I am a HUGE Persona fan and it pains me a lot, but I can't recommend this game in this condition. The stuttering is so stupid that I can't understand how it is even possible. We are talking about a game that you can perfectly play on Nintendo Switch, but I can't play on a MSI Raider GE76 of almost 4000€....

I tried the cores the game uses to execute with Process Lasso (Pro, I even bought it to try play the damn game), and if you asign all the cores but the first one, the game doesn't stutter anymore. BUT, there are random stages that don't load properly and you get stuck in them. And since the game doesn't save automatically, if you were unable to save for the last hour... well, you lost an hour.

Also, the game crashes sometimes one an event finishes (killing a boss) or when going from one stage to another.

I finished this game on ps5 and Nintendo Switch and I bought for PC just to enjoy it as its max... and instead what I found was a huge fucking mess.

Play the game, it is worth it. The spirit of the characters is there, the music and the gameplay. Everything is there. But this port is trash and the developers should be ashamed of themselves for having such a good game like this, being unplayable for some of us. I tried to play it, but after having lost about 10 hours of progress in total, I'm done.

author: b4558456-e823-5fa8-8490-8675fd1da7c5
content:
Los Chorizos Fantasmas estan de vuelta para una ultima aventura.

Unos meses despues del final de Persona 5, Joker y Morgana vuelven a Tokyo para pasar el verano con la banda y resulta que hay alguien jodiendo con el metaverso otra vez y cambiando los corazones de la poblacion, asi que los muchachos se ven obligados a hacer algo al respecto. La diferencia es que para esta altura los personajes ya son re porongas, asi que la amenaza principal no se siente tan apremiante. Sabes que los Phantom Thieves le van a romper la cara a quien esta detras de todo y eso deja lugar a un juego que no se toma tan en serio asi mismo y que tiene muchisimo fan-service e INCLUSO MAS humor que la entrega anterior
El juego tiene el framing de un Road Trip, lo cual es una idea genial. Vas viajando por todo Japon en un motorhome por cuestiones de la historia, pero esto mismo es una excelente excusa para ver a los personajes viviendo alocadas aventuras (y morfando hasta el hartazgo) en distintas ciudades.

Algo importantisimo a aclarar es que para esta entrega el sistema de combate deja de ser por turnos y pasa a ser tipo hack and slash, pero super rapido y estilizado. Piensen Devil May Cry pero contra docenas de enemigos al mismo tiempo. Asimismo, la musica de combate son, en su mayoria, versiones mixadas de temas clasicos de Persona 5, pero en versiones tirando a metal. Keeper of Lust y Last Surprise se llevan las palmas. Una maravilla como siempre la musica, no es de extrañar.

En fin, es una mas que digna despedida para estos personajes tan queridos. Ojala los volvamos a ver algun dia.

author: d230a193-8b22-5cca-b92e-42ce8493b41e
content:
Nominated this game for the "Best Soundtrack" award which it totally deserves.
other than that the game is undeniably fun :

The dungeon/metaverse sections are the heart of the experience, Omega Force and P-Studios translated the original turn based combat into a musou style game pretty well; the fighting mechanics are implemented perfectly, combat feels fast and fluid while it still feels like a persona game. 

The story is a direct sequel to the original P5, so unless you played it or watched the anime you wont understand most of the rules here, cause they aren't explained that much.
the story it-self is good and the new characters are written pretty well. 
you can still pick between multiple dialogue options but they all lead to the same result and there aren't different endings like there was in the original game; this can be good or bad based on the person playing it. for me it was fine, cause it wasn't forcing me to lookup responses and pick the one that led to the better ending, I just picked the goofy options that I liked.

the game is still stylized like the other persona games and will age well for years to come but swapping between different Menu pages (like the inventory ,etc.) has become a bit slower, (they added longer transition animations to them) which you'll get used to it after a while.

[b] Positives : [/b]
[list]
[*] Ploughing through a large number of enemies is fun.
[*] there are a lot of custom hit combos and animations for the different personas you gather.
[*] there are weak points for the enemies just like the original game and executing them in a hack n slash manner feels satisfying. so you'll have to pick your party based on the enemy types in that dungeon.
[*] You can also pick between all of the phantom thieves, each one with their own combo set and fighting style (some better than the others) so the combat is pretty deep.
[*] World traversal (although a bit restricted) is pretty fun too. stealth is still in the game.
[/list]

So if you are a fan of Persona 5/Persona 5 Royal or just love hack 'n slash games in general, you'll definitely enjoy playing this one.

[b] Negatives and Nitpicks: [/b]
[list]
[*] Social part of the gameplay is a bit butchered compared to the original P5 but its fine for the context of the game. the over-world gameplay is fine too, you have to sometimes gather info from the NPCs and maybe buy a couple of stuff for the dungeons.

[*] The padding in certain areas was pretty blatant, there are side missions (Requests) but most of them are added just for padding the playtime (although the game is pretty long itself). the Requests aren't that different to the main game, they are mostly fetch quests for an specific item or "kill x number of enemies" or even "replay a boss" a couple of times and etc... but the rewards are worth it. although i must add that for some side quests you'll spend a bit of time with the others members which is always great to see in the story.
[*] The grind for the BOND points at the end of the game was boring, went through half of the merciless NG+ mode to complete it for 100%.
[*] It takes a long time to beat [u]some[/u] bosses/elites, you'll just have to spam the weak point for a couple of minutes and apply buffs. without much else to do.
[*] 2 out of the 8 dungeons feel short and half-assed ([spoiler] Okinawa and Kyoto to be specific [/spoiler]), they make sense story wised but I preferred the longer and larger dungeons.
[/list]

If you are a fan of Persona 5/Persona 5 Royal or just love hack 'n slash games in general, you'll definitely enjoy playing this one, cause i did.
83/100

author: dbf3904e-8dae-5352-ac7a-8933fbf60005
content:
TL;DR - A slightly diluted sequel of vanilla Persona 5 with action-oriented combat and the soul of the original game, play only if you've played and liked P5.

Oh boy, it took me a quite a while to get through the somewhat overwhelming and slow first few hours of the game but in the end it was worth it. The "issues" I ran into at the start are subjective, you get to use all of the characters at the start and there is a lot to learn, not to mention playing on Hard difficulty made it difficult for me to progress until I got the hang of some mechanics as I was getting destroyed so it was mostly my fault.

The game is difficult only if you're unsure of what you're doing, as you get through the game and learn combos, how to manage your resources and what's important, it becomes much easier.

What makes the game diluted is that the jails are less in-depth than palaces and there are no confidants, so it is a much more streamlined experience with fewer things to tie you to the story and characters emotionally, though the original in a way did that for you already.

The combat itself is in my opinion superior to the turn-based version because of the depth, you can control 4 characters at once with Joker being the wild card (being able to use multiple personas), and each character has their own combos including mechanics like dodging, parries and perfect dodges. As you learn these things you'll be able to handle most things in the game with ease.

The story, while not on par with vanilla's, is still good despite being slow for the first two or three jails, after that point the entire progression of jails changes and everything flows much more smoothly. It really does feel like a sequel (because it is) and not some spin-off, it is perfect if multiple playthroughs of the original games don't cut it anymore. What holds it back a bit is that the stakes are noticeably smaller, or to put it differently, since the Phantom Thieves are no longer newbies, saving the world only feels like a road trip and not a struggle for survival like it did in the original games.

The music for me PERSONALLY is less consistently good but when comparing it to P5's music standards it is still really good, I simply have more memorable soundtracks in the original comparing to Strikers.

The game has a post-game with beefed up bosses and some new content, as I am writing this I haven't yet tried this content but I intend to clear it, I went from feeling uneasy whenever I thought about struggling to welcoming the challenge now that I know how to approach the gameplay.

Overall, I enjoyed the game and I would implore every Persona 5 fan to try it, I really hope there will be more Persona 5 media in the future because despite playing Vanilla and Royal multiple times, saying goodbye again still stings.

8.5/10

author: 788f1c10-b179-54a5-ad38-99cbbc4f2d73
content:
Ugh.... I guess I'll review it. I loved P4G and P5R as the first disclaimer, and I'm not much for JRPGs. So this is the hack and slash "sequel" to P5. And I don't hate it? I'm not sure if I like it because it's P5 content or how it plays (despite it taking two attempts to get into it). If you really, really want more from the P5 Story go for it. If Japanese hack and Slash are your thing... go for it. If you are just coming to terms that you might have a thing for JRPGs.... I dunno... try it out. It's not bad just very, very different. And it is disconnected from the canon in the weirdest ways. Most of that can be explained that it got made at the same time as P5R by a different Studio and they had no idea. All in all it's a P5 hack and Slash that furthers the story and it has no technical faults. So i guess I recommend it but tbh I am not sure if I like this game or not.... Which you probably experience as well.

Well I'm done with the game, "For real" this time. I have to say, that while the Gameplay didn't do it for me, I'd happily play through it again. Because as disconnected the story is from P5R, it's entirely good on it's own. There are more moments that moved me to tears, which is kinda hard to do, than there were in P5R. So It might not be a real Persona game, but it does it's very best to live up to one and I really hope that at least Sophia comes back in P6.

Pros:

Decent story.
Great characters (well it is Persona 5)
Koei Tecmo's "X Warriors" style game play.
Game generally is fun, jokes also nice and funny and makes you laugh.
Musics.

Cons:
Your story on Persona 5 feels forgotten (for example your romantic interest or people connected with you)
Repeating game play (well it is "X Warriors" style series anyway)
Not good keyboard layout even you change keyboard mapping still not good.
Dificulty is not "Normal" it feels "Hard" even in Normal Difficulty choice. Maybe it is also effects of "X Warriors" series from Koei Tecmo/Omega Force.

Still if you wanted to see what happens after some time your "Persona 5 (Royal)" story and also if you like "X Wariors" series like myself you can play it without worry. But better buy it with discount and don't expect "Persona 5 (Royal)" kind of deep story.

I'm down to play if they fix this mess but in it's current state it doesn't run well on higher end computers. I have an intel i9 12900k, a 3080 and 32 gbs of ram and if I don't increase the games priority to high and adjust the apps affinity to be able to use all CPU cores it will stutter and freeze even on the pre-rendered opening cut scenes. author: 095a2ac4-9cb9-5d4a-ad73-329d761dbc8b
content:
i love persona 5 so naturally playing its sequel was something i really wanted to do and while i havent finished it yet i feel like ive put enough time to have an opinion

the gameplay is awesome, they got everything that makes persona 5 what it is and somehow converted it into a completely different genre, the music is also really good and really fits [tho some are reused] however i will now list the technical issues this game has that ive noticed so far 

the audio mixing is really bad. sometimes the music is too loud, sometimes theres this weird reverb on th dialogue making them really hard to hear, sometimes the voices are so quiet you cant hear them all 

the optimization is wonky, i couldnt get AA to work without having to open my gpu control panel to fix it, if you run this game at 60 fps which lets be honest you will and the frame rate drops at any point, instead of the frame rate actually dropping the game just  slows down... literally and ironically that makes some fights extremely difficult as input lag also goes up as the game slows down 

the controls are great.. with a controller, do not play this game with mouse and keyboard its truly awful 

however i still really recommend this game, its lots of fun even with its issues

Loved persona 5 and its royal version. However this game is literally unplayable for me. I can't seem to get a stable 60 fps while in game, it seems a lot of people have this issue too, something to do with having 6 - 8 threads on your cpu. There seems to be some sort of fix but I've tried everything and the game at max plays at 41 fps. 

Actually saddened and never thought I'd have to refund a game, specially a Persona one but here we are. It's been 1 year and this hasn't been fixed. Most likely it never will. If you have a medium rig, sure, buy it and try it out. If you have a powerful rig, don't waste your time on this game.

Edit: Who are the two fanboys who put the "jester" award on every negative review lol

author: 9c274211-a3b2-5ea4-b20f-6f430d4c0874
content:
This game is a direct-sequel to Persona 5 Vanilla (And semi-sequel to Royal's bonus content, but not needed). 

Strikers takes place the summer after Persona 5 ended. Everyone's on Summer Break, and it becomes a roadtrip of the good ol' Persona variety. The game implements the mechanics of Dynasty Warriors and Persona 5 itself very nicely, with the UI being heavily stylized via Persona, and the mechanics mixing the two to a satisfying degree. 

If you're a fan of Persona 5, I'd still pick it up even if you don't necessarily enjoy Dynasty Warrior games, since the story and gameplay both feel very well tuned to Persona.

author: 28f9bd69-3146-5f04-bdfd-09418691dd87
content:
Having never played a musou type game before and being on the fence of getting this i saw the game only costed 24 dollars and decided to get it. I wanted to write an early review of what i thought about the game if anyone else was on the fence of getting it so i played for about 6 hours to get a general feel, before going in i knew there wasn't social links and i was fine with that but if your looking for that kinda stuff its not here really

Now this review is from the stand point of having never played a musou game but i can say this game is very fun for me it might be terrible from a mosou veterans stand point but honestly your probably only playing this if your a fan of persona in the first place

As a disclaimer I played with a controller since the MK controls seemed awful 
The combat is real time all out brawls while being surrounded by shadows but the actual combat boils down to basically pressing X and then Y for a finisher which is usually your personas ability which is FREE to do without SP. Which is amazing because SP drains fast in this game if your manually casting spells. And this game lets you play as any of the phantom thieves (besides akechi and yoshizawa) i found my self playing more as the other characters then Joker but i mostly played ryuji so i could dream of punt kicking that stupid cat into outer space. Each character has a very unique fighting style and move set (idk about morgona i haven't touched him) that encompass their persona,gun and melee weapons into their rushes and attacks ruji can charge up his attacks and his base Y makes him harder to flinch Ann and mokoto can imbue their weapons with their personas elements yusuke has parries and haru has massive aoes. There's also two new persona users shown off in the games opening cut scene one joined the phantom thieves at the first hour of game play and she uses yoyos shes pretty fun but there's another guy i saw using a persona in the opening cut scene of the game idk if he joins or is an antagonist though 

If you played P5R you probably blew through the game without much trouble besides that dam space palace. So I came into this game expecting it to be easy so i cranked the difficulty up to hard and I was very wrong, It was actually hard for me even on normal to my surprise. Still i only have 6 hours so maybe this is just early game woes mixed with having never played a mosou before

Another point is that the game pretty much mandates a day 1 clear. To my surprise you could leave the palace and time wont progress at all, so i would drain my SP and HP leave buy some healing fuse personas ECT come back and be ready to go.

One Con i have so far is that characters that are not being played by you do not receive master arts XP which isn't to bad for the 4 people you really like considering you'll be using them often. but if you go against a boss say weak to nuclear and fire but don't use Ann or Mokoto at all your kinda outa luck because not only are they under leveled for not being in the party but they also dont have all their master arts compared to your main 4. so far this has been my only gripe with the game

author: 8af983c6-419f-53bd-838c-34c4906af44d
content:
As someone who finished the OG P5 game on PS4 twice, and Royal 3 times, it should say a good bit when I tell you I didnt even get halfway through this game.

Highest difficulty:
If you arent constantly keeping your allies fed with an endless supply of xp sourced from fodder battles, a few enemies have aoe attacks that they make absolutely no effort to avoid, and die instantly as a result. This means if you arent spending what I can only assume is 3x the intended time in any given area (due to the enemy variety and lack of anything interesting happening while you mindlessly beat fodder to death for hours) your team gets smoked immediately (and i do mean i m m e d i a t e l y) and youre left to either dodge perfectly doing one person's damage on an enemy with hp scaled for 4 attackers for 10 minutes or spam gun attacks from across the map, which takes longer, but not enough longer than its worth dying even once while doing the more entertaining gameplay style.

Anything lower than the highest difficulty:
Spam any button and win every fight without even the slightest effort.

By the time I was frustrated enough fighting using only my gun from max range and swapped down a tick and realised this, I was too burnt out to continue. The conversations are entertaining enough, but only just enough, to make me consider picking it back up once I forget the torments of the combat in a few years.

If you really really really care about having more P5 interactions from ONLY the main cast (no one from royal, and no side confidants) save yourself the effort, play on the easiest difficulty and sprint through every combat section without deviating at all from the main story route.
Just another classic Persona spinoff side hustle with the bare minimum effort put in to milk enough money for the next, sure to be just as amazing as 4 and 5, mainline Persona title.

author: e1151ba3-1f8d-5453-8527-d9c325cb0dab
content:
I love this game.

TL;DR: Story feels samey from the original game but it's still enjoyable. Gameplay has no social sim aspect but the transition into action combat was really well done, higher difficulties alleviate the button mashing issue.

I won't deny the story does feel like a rehash of the original Persona 5, but out of bias I'm fond of that familiarity, and some characters that did not get much of a spotlight in the main game such as Haru finally get a moment to shine here. You see way more group interactions in this game and I wish we had more of that in the original. The two new main characters, Sophia and Zenkichi, fit really nicely into the cast without altering the dynamic of the group that much.

Gameplay-wise I will admit it is not going to be everyone's cup of tea. The affinity and 1 More system from the series' turn-based combat was translated incredibly well into an action format, but it can still carry that notorious Musou stereotype of just mashing buttons in most normal encounters. For that reason I'd suggest playing on Hard for the best experience since it makes the benefit from exploiting affinities greater.

Also worth noting the entire social sim aspect from the main games is not here. It's pure dungeon crawling and platforming with the real world only really being used for story purposes and buying items. The Confidant system is replace by a secondary EXP bar named "BOND" that works as a sort of skill tree.

author: 0378c2f9-f861-5d0f-97e9-b6edaf21345e
content: Not only does it do a very good job at adapting the mechanics of Persona 5 to a musou format, it arguably one of the best games of the genre. The gameplay feels smooth, fun and intuitive; giving the player very wide array of movement and ways to attack. Each member of the Phantom Thieves feel unique in terms of playstyle. The soundtrack, much like the previous game is absolutely amazing. The dialogue between the phantom thieves is fun and enjoyable. I only gripe with the game is how similar most of the jails feel, generally being 3 prison keeps, 1 trauma cell and boss battle each. Other than that, i thoroughly enjoyed playing the game. Definitely recommended, especially for players looking for a fresh style of musou games.

author: 49374810-83a5-5f3c-be6b-8e81ee692a66
content:
I've had a complicated relationship with Persona 5 Strikers.

   Years ago, when Joker was announced for Nintendo's Smash Ultimate, I had no idea just what I was getting into. The art style, the voices, the designs - I fell in love quickly. Upon playing Joker in Smash, I eventually bought Persona 5, and then Persona 5 Royal, and then I bought this.

   Initially, I was so into it. The fast-paced Koei Tecmo ARPG combat was thrilling, with the banger arrangement of remade battle themes from Persona 5. The return to where I spent easily over 300 hours between Persona 5 and 5R, and meeting the cast again.

   At some point, I believe around the middle of the game, I found myself starting to dislike it. To the extent that I actually had to set a motivator for myself to finish it. I made a bet with my coworker that I would give him $100 if he finishes the re-release of P5R on PC before I finish Strikers. That's how sluggish I was, pacing-wise. After returning to the game, I found that I was just under-leveled, and maybe had the difficulty too high. I'm not really experienced with these ARPGs.

There are some segments that are a bore compared to the fast-paced gameplay in the first palace. I didn't like the segments where I had to blindly walk around open areas and talk to NPCs to hear generic dialogue about what's going on, just to progress the story. This being said, those segments are brief, and the rest of the game forward makes that part of the game worth playing through.

   If you've played Persona 5 or 5R like I have, you'll definitely want to play this game. Maybe it won't be your style of gameplay, and maybe it'll take you a while. I don't regret my 43 hours with this game. You won't either.

content:
La música es lo que hace para mí que este juego me llegue al cora. Este fue mi inicio en la franquicia y con tan sólo jugar el primer nivel por así decirlo, me motivó a conocer los personajes y me puse a ver el anime para ponerme al tanto del mundo y al increíble equipo que lo recorre. Unas vacaciones entre amigos, historias entrañables, combate divertido aunque no perfecto, progresión encantadora en la que la tensión siempre llega con buen sabor de boca todo bañado en un jugoso soundtrack que hace a la experiencia única.
De momento me encuentro en negación porque probablemente esté en el último nivel y no quiero que se acabe por lo que alejo los ojos del juego a ver si así me dura más. 
No soy un sujeto muy exigente, pero incluso creo que para aquellos que sí lo sean este juego es sumamente bueno.

author: a60923fd-1ecd-51fe-932b-a20155d5b578
content:
EDIT October of 2022: Persona 5 has just been released on PC. I highly recommend playing through it first before Strikers.

Persona 5 Strikers is a sequel/spinoff to Persona 5. Unlike it's predecessor which was a turn based jrpg with dungeon crawler/social sim elements, Strikers is an action hack and slash game in the vein of Dynasty Warriors.

One of my favorite aspects of this game is how familiar to Persona 5 it feels. It has so many little touches like the player being able to pause the game and view the dialogue log mid conversation. All of the player's companions return from the original which is a very welcome inclusion. As a huge fan of Persona 5's story and characters the primary selling point for this game was being able to continue the adventures of Joker and the gang. Which this game delivers. On the flipside this is also potentially the game's greatest shortcoming. It's a direct sequel to Persona 5 and fully expects you to have beaten that game before playing this one. Considering Persona 5 isn't on Steam (as of the writing of this review anyway) this is a massive problem. Because of that if you haven't previously played P5 or P5R you will be rather lost in terms of the story and general gameplay mechanics.

The action rpg combat is serviceable albeit very simple. It feels kind of mindless at times and selectively makes you pay attention when it throws a challenging enemy at you. It does feel like the developers did their best to try and make an action rpg out of Persona 5's combat. However I never felt like it ever surpassed that game in terms of strategy or personality. I can see this game appealing to people who were turned off of Persona 5's turn based combat. However because it's story expects you to have beaten P5 it also doesn't really appeal to newcomers. 

All in all in terms of being a spinoff/sequel to Persona 5 it delivers. It gives you more of that game just with a different spin on things. Outside of that though if you weren't crazy about the original like I was it's hard to recommend. Especially since Persona 5 isn't on Steam as of yet. Hopefully if/when that game releases, Strikers can have a second wind on Steam. But til then it remains as a novelty for the minority of PS4 owners who own a gaming PC and were also huge fans of Persona 5.

author: 81292547-e527-535f-8a24-fed4d97ca80a
content:
[h1]SDHQ STEAM DECK PERFORMANCE REVIEW (FIRST LOOK):[/h1]

[table]
[tr]
[th] Follow our [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/42495043/]curator[/url] page for more Steam Deck reviews and our [url=https://twitter.com/SteamDeckHQ]Twitter[/url] for immediate updates on all SDHQ content including reviews, news, and more!
[/th][/tr][/table]


[i]This review is based ONLY on performance of the game on the STEAM DECK.[/i]


[h1]The Game Itself:[/h1]


The Phantom Thieves are back to strike against the corruption overtaking cities across Japan. With the crew on summer vacation, Persona 5 Strikers will have you travel all over to figure out what is happening and redeem the hearts of those imprisoned at the center of this crisis. Unlike other games in the series, the gameplay is hack-and-slash, closer to Koei Tecmo's series, Dynasty Warriors, but paired with the Persona charm, it fits near perfectly. Outside of combat, you will walk around the cities and get closer to your friends while talking to them with this road trip vibe. In the end, the game is definitely an awesome and worthy successor to Persona 5.



[h1]Steam Deck Performance:[/h1]


On the Steam Deck however, there are a couple of issues stopping me from enjoying this game. First, the game will only run when using Proton GE, so you will need to make sure it is installed (you can follow our guide on getting it on our website). Next, while it can run at higher graphics settings, I noticed there was still some slowdown. The game can definitely hit 60 FPS, but even when set to it, it caps itself around 58. To fix this, make sure to turn Vsync off as this will push it lower.

The last one is that cutscenes will only play music, not any sound effects or voices. There is subtitles so it is still passable, but it does ruin the experience a little bit if trying to fully immerse yourself. No Proton GE layer seemed to fix this, so if you are going to play on the Steam Deck, cutscenes will be impaired.

Overall, the game is still very playable and can run on the Deck, but there are some caveats. The game is a lot of fun, but with the cutscene issues, it tends to break immersion a little bit. But if you can look past this, you will find a solid experience that continues one of the best JRPGs ever made!

[/th][/tr][/table]

author: 10750e54-320b-590e-866d-6ef388358a87
content:
[h1] Sophia is Humanity's Companion!(Best AI!) [/h1]

After finishing it...I felt empty in a feeling of reflection, I put a song on while thinking about it, weeks later I managed to gather my thoughts, AT LEAST FOR ME although the game has a linear single ending, the experience which i received of it is the following:*minor to none spoilers ahead*

This month we had Brazilian Children's Day, why am I talking about this? The overall plot revolves around the childhood trauma of two of the characters. And the way P5S approaches the moral theme of trauma lives up to the series' legacy, the way it handles and showcases how to deal with childhood trauma. 

I reminded myself, regardless of our age, we will always have an inner child, or at least memories from our childhood that profoundly influence our overall mindset. So I loved Strikers Plot, despite the switch from RPG to ARPG, I still recommend it as a good Persona game.

P.S: I recommend getting the deluxe edition for older fans, the music pack  playing in the game with all the music from the previous games in the background ringin' gave a  little nostalgic feeling, well worth the extra$. 

[h1]PROS[/h1]
- Music
- Crosswheel weapons (Rarely do you see this in games+it's in the best char=sophie)
- Zenkichi... relatable char, it's the closest to my usual moral, it was quite an experience watching him grow... he also uses BIG SWORDS "ZWEIHANDER"... (literally me in the soul series)[most unique moveset ingame battles]
 - Cooking and dialogues, the overall camping trip.
- I liked the fact that in this persona we didn't have a villain that was purely evil, just people with twisted goals.

[h1]Cons[/h1]
Grind,grind,grind,grind,grind,grind,grind,grind... i think grind. Well...did i say grind? Oh yeah, grind! 

[h1]Final note[/h1]  
- I would rate the story a 10/10 but the gameplay around 6/7 so I'd give it an 8 for overall fun.

author: ca6854bd-06cb-5212-938f-2f5d69d58e0f
content:
As a fan of both Persona 4 and 5, and (specially) Dynasty Warriors, this game is a good combination of the musou formula with the Persona's JRPG gameplay.  Its quite take a time to get a hang of the mechanic and juggle between the musou and the rpg but overall its a fun game to play

Edit: So after playing the game up to near the end game, i can say that the game is very well written, i dare to say the story are better written than the original Persona 5 game, not saying Persona 5 is badly written, but P5S expand from the original game, and the new characters in this game is also good and interesting. 

Gameplay wise like i mentioned it may need a while adapting to, and after playing for a while you maybe have a certain character that you like or hate mechanic wise because each one has different gimmick.

My only nitpicking on this is just the persona fusion... WHY WE HAVE TO LEVEL THEM TO CERTAIN LEVEL NOW??? Though this is minor problem and most of the persona can be fusioned by just the original level.

Overall it is a very good experience, though to completely experience the story you HAVE to play Persona 5 first (either vanilla or Royal as it only continues the original story).

author: 80dfe865-9a76-56d3-9aeb-36688c98eebd
content:
first off

Do not play this game if you have not played Persona 5 (or Royal thats coming to steam soon)

for the sake of levity i'll try to be brief

this game is great, but only if you love Persona 5

i'll be honest, when i heard of a musou-like spinoff of one of my favourite games ever, i rolled my eyes and wrote it off.
i bought the game eventually, let it sit on my backlog for a few days before eventually giving it a go, and...

within the first cutscene, i was won over.
its important to stipulate that i felt this way because it uses the same story telling methods and writing that the base game provides, immediately making it feel like an extension of Persona 5

and it certainly is

this game provides the lighthearted moments that the base Persona 5 was missing, its lovely, just a damn good time. same great characters, some fun narrative hooks, if you've played Persona 5 i don't need to say anything else

The gameplay is... alright. its probably the weakest part of the game if i'm honest. the real-time battle animations can feel a bit stilted at times, its not particularly complex either, but i had a good time with it overall. you're given plenty of incentive to change up your playstyle and the sheer style makes the game a blast visually.

The Music? ITS LIKE THE BEST PART HOLY SHIIIIII-
when they use a remix of "rivers in the desert" as a prelude to the actual boss theme you know its about to be a banger. every battle theme thumps. theres new battle themes, old battle themes that are given this sexy rock remix, its wonderful. the real-world location themes are also absolute classics, everytime you go somewhere new you'll be tapping your feet for a good while. 10/10 soundtrack, brilliant time.


tldr: if you love Persona 5, you owe it to yourself to play this one, it doesn't treat p5 Royal content as canon but youll be too invested in the game to care. the dungeons (jails?) can feel a bit sloggy at times but everything else makes up for it for the most part. 7.5/10 (presuming you've played persona 5)

author: 67e9fd1d-6d5a-5608-a76d-f93f29528aa5
content:
Eh, I don't know. It's Persona alright, but they took out the turn-based nature and the multiple different endings, and kept everything else. Yeah, fusions, cards, status effects, and type weakness/strength are still in here... not to its credit.

The levels, despite having shadows patrolling around, are just sorta... Empty and uncompelling- there's nothing to search for unless you want some cards or sellable junk. If something spots you, you're forced into a battle unless you run away fast enough, and it's always a group of enemies that you'll Yakuza-fight away with whichever character you've chosen to play as.

Here's the bad thing, though. It's a hard game unless you set it to easy. Why? Literally in the first Jail, you'll find out that the characters are all squishy as hell and get afflicted with status effects constantly. It's extremely annoying, and they'll all usually die while you're trying to take something down. It made me realize that the turn-based system is REALLY needed if you have all these systems in play, cause otherwise you get this game where everyone gets randomly spammed with whatever until they die. The swarming makes it impossible to counteract, too. Oh, and there's tanky damage-sponge enemies aswell.

Spent 15 hours tickling feet to grow a better bond between me and my friends. 10/10 gameplay.

Other then that, the port to PC isn't horrible. I had absolutely no issues with bugs or crashes and my PC is pretty meh. Likewise with graphics, no issues. I don't know who came up with the default key binds though but dear God, why? Thankfully, every key can be rebind so controls are not bad. Same with controller support.

Overall, I loved every moment. It's a great follow up from the original Persona 5. Strikers did well giving the series a new refreshing spin. I originally played on release on the PS4. I 100%'ed it there and with Persona 5 Royal coming to PC in a few weeks, I decided to 100% it on steam too. Highly recommended.

author: da2544c3-ab14-5abc-b8ac-695d0a43849c
content: This game is pretty fun! As a fan of Persona 5 Royal, and having never played a hack and slash before, I thought I'd give this a go. As a preemptive warning, this game does spoil the ending of Persona 5, so play that first. Combat can get repetitive as with any game if you play it for long enough, but the Persona flair adds a lot to the combat. The only part I dislike is they bumped the SP cost of every skill in the game compared to its Royal price, and so that made it much harder to regenerate that SP, so you will need to leave dungeons pretty often. Luckily, since this is a spin-off, there's no calendar system to deal with, so it won't affect game play in any meaningful way other than a loading screen. Other people also claim that they are running into performance issues, but I've never noticed any major stuttering or lag at all, and while my PC isn't super low end, it's 100% not high end. If you're a fan of Persona 5/Royal, give this a try. If your a fan of hack and slashes, this game isn't a bad option for you either. Overall, 8/10. Little rough around the edges, but an overall fun experience
