author: cd11aa69-0f88-5bc4-ae93-485672620069
content:
Playing Persona 5 Strikers is like spending a few hours alternating between playing Persona 5 and playing literally any Dynasty Warriors game, while binge drinking. Then you pass out, have really weird dreams in which the two games have mixed together in your head (much like the Red Bull and vodka in your stomach), and wake up in a fog of confusion and regret. That sounds like it should be kind of awesome, but it's a mess in practice... and worse, actually kind of boring. 
 
This game is only worth it if you're a big fan of the Persona 5 characters and want to see a continuation of their story. I can't really recommend it for the gameplay itself. Like other successors to the Dynasty Warriors games, combat can be fun at first, but gets repetitive fast. Koei did a good job of making the attacks have the same flair and art style as Persona 5, but it doesn't innovate enough, or expand on the usual formula to make it feel truly unique compared to their other games. It just feels like something I've played before, while failing to be quite as satisfying. 
 
Wait for a sale-- a big one-- or watch someone else's YouTube playthrough. If you're a Persona fan, combat is probably going to wind up feeling like a chore to ferry you along to the next cut scene, so give some serious consideration to spectating this game instead of playing it.

author: 76d65f8f-8e7d-57d7-be26-4b0072c770af
content:
fun game, lot of good things

[b]Gameplay[/b]

Easy and accessible. 
[list]
[*]First [spoiler]Shibuya[/spoiler] dungeon has questionable difficulty, you take too much damage considering it's the start
[*]Checkpoints in this game are overpowered, as you can use them to save, fast travel, but most importantly leave the dungeon and return with full hp and sp
[*]The game gives you a lot of checkpoints so you can go into each miniboss at full hp and sp 
[*]Game also gives generous hints for boss fights
[*]After first dungeon, I had more money and persona points than I needed
[*]The sixth [spoiler]Osaka[/spoiler] dungeon is also poorly scaled, because the two previous dungeons both only have one map, so you don't get enough exp unless you repeatedly grind
[*]Persona fusion has been simplified, all combinations are preset and you can see them all. Personally I don't like it, but I can see why they might want it easier for newcomers
[*]New explorable areas are all well made! While not as in detail as Shibuya in Persona 5, it makes up for quality with quantity and variety of places in Japan you go to
[*]Achievement completion is straightforward. However, maxing all bond skills is a dull and unavoidable time sink
[/list]

[b]Story[/b]
[list]
[*]Obviously, game is aimed towards fans who have already played Persona 5
[*]Surprisingly, it's not too interconnected to P5, so the story can be enjoyed even if you've never played Persona
[*]No social links, which makes sense. You're already a group of good friends, you don't need to break the ice again. But you can't go beyond that, so you're friendzoned by everyone, no romance for you :(
[*]New playable characters are distinct from other characters and have good chemistry with rest of group. I say distinct, but the outfit of the last member feels too similar and generic
[*]Villains are compelling and well written. They do follow tropes but seeing how its done in Persona's setting is new and interesting
[*]Overall tone and mood are much lighter than Persona 5
[*]Music and visuals are stunning, which is almost to be expected
[/list]

author: 89fa5070-616a-5fd6-9f1c-6b0289c7e8e5
content:
Persona 5 Strikers feels like a hard game to sell, not because I didn't enjoy my time with it, but because it is a sequel game that is designed to be enjoyed by people who liked the original, but are okay with much of what made the original good being taken out.

Persona 5 was my first introduction into the Persona or the larger Shin Megami Tensei franchise, and two features of the game that I deeply enjoyed were the time management and the confidants. Neither of those are present in this story sequel, which means that there are no real consequential decisions for the player to make. Perhaps due to the game taking place over the course of a Summer road trip, there is no threat of a ticking clock over the player's head. You can go to and from the Jails (this game's version of the Palaces) as much as you like, which means there is no consequence to leaving to refill your SP. Thus, the choice of risking pushing deeper into the dungeon on low SP versus leaving early at the cost of time doesn't exist anymore.

The confidants are replaced by the BOND upgrade tree, which focuses on the friendship you build with the other Phantom Thieves throughout the game. It's as fine as any other upgrade tree in any modern game, but unlike Persona 5 the choices you make don't really matter. You'll have almost everything by the end of the game outside of the raw stat boosts and the biggest additions to it will come from events that happen during the main plot anyway. The confidants added side stories that you were incentivized to see through to the end on top of getting interesting new abilities. BOND is just lacking by comparison.

But, with that said, as somebody who likes action RPGs I still had fun playing the game. It does a good job of making Persona's combat fit into an action system, with trash enemies being easy to dispatch with some attack strings, but the actual demons requiring you to take advantage of their weaknesses to dispatch them efficiently. Naturally there are less playable characters here than a regular Musou game would have, but they all have their unique quirks that make them fun to play in their own right. The story is interesting enough, even if it does start to feel a little like a rehash towards the end. It should be noted that the story of Strikers follows the original ending for Persona 5, and not the ending of Royal. The music is as great as ever, although part of that is due to the game using remixes of certain songs from the original Persona 5 (Counter Strike and Daredevil are absolutely bangers though).

The game also ran on my Windows 10 PC with no problems whatsoever. It's always nice to play a PC game that doesn't waste your time with having to fix it, or having to wait for the developers to patch it to an acceptable state. It just worked.

So in conclusion, if you're desperate for one last adventure with the Phantom Thieves, don't mind going from a turn-based battle system to a realtime action one and don't mind the loss of confidants or the time management, then you'll have a good time here.

Recommended

author: 9e3e8aee-bd21-5f80-bce1-d5157f9b47d0
content:
Niche game for Persona 5 fans that likes Hack&Slash or just accept gameplay suffering for the MAIN story. Can't recommend to anyone who doesn't complete at least P5. H&S mechanics are fine, but I didn't like them (still better then dancing games). Game definitely lacks polishing and not on par as P5R. Mapping multiple actions on a same button will take you in unwanted situations at least a few times per game, Vertical gameplay just purely bad implements with slow camera, jumps and ropes.
Fighting are OK, but pre-combat scenes are fucked: you enter an empty room, Futaba calls that it's clear on here radars and enemy just raises from nothing and starts talking to you. Why? Just shut-up and fight me, ok? We both know that we can't talk this out. This happens so often that you will get in a big empty room knowing that an enemy will be there. This annoys me from the start and till the end.
I didn't like "original" P5 remix soundtrack from the start. I bought Legacy BGM pack just to add more battle music and don't listen to this. Only after late mid game I get involved with a music because it starts sync with scenes and story. I wished for at least original P5 soundtrack, but you will get it only after completing the game and I'm not going in that rabbit hole again.
Story are good, mostly predictable with a few twists. Sideguest (aka requests) are awful: kill, obtain, secure, crawl. It's just boring grind after fully-featured sidequests introduces in P5 with good entertaining stories. Just skip them, it's not worth it. You can buy a lot of stuff in a shop.

author: 786c012a-b976-5801-9157-d0785102e410
content:
Persona 5 Strikers is the rare kind of game that's able to both feel like a pleasant surprise and a tremendous disappointment rolled up into the one package, and it certainly makes for an interesting experience to think about. There isn't even really an element present here that feels wholly great or wholly terrible either, it's a balancing act where every idea is on the cusp of either entirely falling off the deep end or being something truly inspired that gets the game as a whole to stand out from the original Persona 5. I'd even go as far as saying that if this game were about 10 hours shorter that I'd think it was an outright great little time, but as it stands, the longer things went on, the more the initially small flaws would build up until it created something that I barely could bother finishing.

Transforming Persona 5's core combat from the more traditional turn based combat into a musou was definitely a creative decision that I was initially concerned about since there have been so many instances where a lot of the strategy a game could have ends up getting removed in favour of button mashing, but it's honestly the thing I think Strikers ended up doing the best as I went on. Despite being a musou by definition, with the hack n slash combat paired with waves of usually very weak enemies, I was impressed by just how much of the dynamics of Persona were still present. While the basic hacking and sladhing will get you through a lot of the smaller encounters, against anything with even a hint of challenge to it, it immediately feels as if it plays a bit closer to a real time Persona rather than a standard game of the genre, with careful team building and full exploitation of enemy weaknesses both playing a huge role in getting you to the stage where you can take things down. To still provide such a strong incentive to be spending like, 20 minutes at a time in the velvet room to minmax your team and make that time feel worth it is very cool to do when the gameplay style takes such a sharp turn and it leads to some situations that really do feel frenetic, yet rewarding.

This is especially true for the boss fights, which were consistently some of the best parts here, often being on the far more tanky side of things, but always feeling as if they properly took advantage of the genre shift and all made for some engaging and intense fights that would more often than not come down to the wire, the final boss especially mixing things up in clever ways that I won't spoil. Adding those additional flashy moves that could be kited around was also a good move in making the choice to move in this direction feel warranted and meaningful while providing another avenue to provide some additional spectacle to things, keeping up with the theme of everything about Persona 5 being so incredibly flashy. That said, things aren't quite perfect either with the shift in style, with certain ideas getting lost in the process. MP conservation might as well not be a thing considering how much more health everything seems to have in this, you're going to either be staying at full MP or blowing it all in a single bigger fight, and it hinders such a core strategic element that could've been fixed just by giving the party way more or it instead of making it a resource that was even more finite than it was in the original game.

The dungeon design was also really bad for the most part, starting off with a couple that were really fun in one way or another, albeit pretty bland from a layout standpoint, but as things went on, rather than building upon concepts that were established and knowing when to add a little twist to them to elevate the experience to the next level, it just was more of the same, but more of it, and far more formulaic. This reached a peak with the 6th dungeon, which was a genuinely agonising experience because of how much unadulterated tedium was thrown towards the player. This sense of repetition carries over to the narrative as well, as while I love the vibes of the phantom thieves going on a road trip and saving the world in the process, after a certain point it becomes increasingly obvious just how many story beats have just been taken from the original and veeeerrry slightly retooled, just with character writing that feels far heavier on the tropes.

In general there's a certain impersonal feel to how a lot of the narrative is executed, villains that are barely connected with the protagonists in any way beyond vague similarities in their strife, everyone just doing their own thing and happening to cross paths along the way, and basically any other interaction outside of the main cast. While this definitely works in some instances to make the world feel more alive and not something that entirely revolves around the protagonists, it quickly leads to wishing that the game would've at least used this in a more creative way at the very least. These 2nd hand stories of hardship and trauma you hear throughout are obviously still pretty dark and all, but without basically any contextualisation to these beyond the bare minimum, it ends up leaving a very minimal impact in comparison and makes it hard to truly get invested in the antagonists throughout, often feeling explicitly introduced to cause conflict without any other purpose.

The lack of this personal element extends out to the rest of the game too, gone is the sense of proper time progression and planning, instead replaced with the game's date exclusively moving forward when the plot demands it rather than leaving any leniency for one of the best aspects of the original game. Things just have nowhere near as much of a comfy charm when you're not spending a lot of your time just, living life and chatting with characters, and not only are all the side characters from the original not present at all, but the social links or any equivalent are also missing. All of this is replaced with this one bar called the "bond bar" which is just an artificial way of trying to evoke the same feelings without putting in any of the elements that elevated this, and like so many other elements just feels like it was included to keep up the surface level similarities. Funnily enough though, despite all my complaints, a lot of this only started becoming truly detrimental near the end once things began to outstay their welcome, and even amongst this painful end portion, the final boss was still a really great time and there were a few other isolated elements of greatness mixed in, not to mention that the game was almost as stylish as the original, albeit less polished.

I genuinely feel like if you're more used to games on the longer side of things that you'll get more out of this than I did, as I'll admit that I do begin running out of patience after a certain point and it probably makes some of the issues present here feel even worse than they are in reality. Still won't affect my own opinion, but I could definitely see others enjoying this more than me as a result. If you're a big fan of Persona 5 and are fine with a bit of repetitiveness, I could definitely recommend this, it still maintains a very high amount of P5's identity while taking things in a different direction. It's not perfect, but you get to see more Phantom Thieves in action and Haru finally is able to get a reasonable amount of screentime too, and that stuff combined with the surprisingly fun combat ends up making this an alright time even if I personally ended up feeling pretty disappointed and bored towards the end.

6.5/10 - Recommended but only if you're a pretty big fan of the OG Persona 5 and wait for it to go on sale

author: 9bec7ac0-55da-5a10-a681-329eff819592
content:
After coming from Royal, the story felt kind of predictable and unsatisfysing, but that's not to say it's bad. I still had plenty of fun discovering the story behind the jails and the 2 new party members, but that was never the reason why I played the game as much as I did.
The best part of this game is definitely the combat. The satisfying nature or the combos, the insane nuance of the movement and master arts, and the adjustment of the persona mechanics all combine to create an extremely sturdy gameplay cycle with a very high skill ceiling for each of the 8 playable characters.
over the course of the base game, even in hard difficulty I rarely felt like the challenge gave the combat enough justice, but merciless difficulty was a whole different story. Being NG+ exclusive, of course merciless would be difficult but holy shit, some of the bosses put dark souls to shame (although i would've liked the boss to not take an hour and a half).
I can't put all my thoughts into this one review because steam won't let me, so I'll conclude with my recommendation: you should play base P5 before this but it isn't a requirement, hard mode is the only difficulty with any challenge until NG+, and if the combat hooked you then I'd highly recommend merciless, but this game is best enjoyed with full context and played at your own pace.
10/10

content:
I love the Persona games - especially Persona 5 (both original and Royal). Unfortunately, I'm not sure I have the patience or time for the long-time gameplay of the actual games, so I've been reluctant to try the actual game for myself and settled with watching the (long) cutscene movies on YouTube. So when I heard about Persona 5 Strikers, and found out that it was very different in terms of gameplay from the traditional Persona games, I decided to give it a shot AND LOVED IT!
Overall, Persona 5 Strikers is great for Persona fans that don't quite have the time or patience for the usual gameplay of Persona games.

author: 371f9770-1c11-549e-b610-629772b1f9ce
content:
This was a drag to play through, so much unnecessary dialogue and down time. Its a huge turn off from the exceedingly fun fast pace hack n slash and then cut to 3 - 10 minutes of dialogues at each checkpoint.

The writing is not great either, no character development for any of the past members and cheap forced sympathy for the villains. There was tons of needless dialogue, dialogue that could've been summed up in a sentence. Instead they make like 3-5 members of the phantom thieves to give some sort of dialogue reaction like "we're stuck", "oh no", "what are we going to do". But to give credit where its due, Zenkichi's arc and Sophia's are my favourite standouts. 

Gameplay is fun, the typical 'Warriors' type combat with Persona element mixed in and provided mindless enjoyment. The Jails (Dungeons) are linear, boring and mixed with the unnecessary forced dialogue at each checkpoint. It gave this dynamic of clearing enemies for fun and then cut to boring dialogue that last for minutes. The Jails were visually appealing but annoying to play through with lots of backtracking and downtime like unnecessary dialogue and defending Futuba for 3 minutes to move to the next area. The bossfights were fun though, each one had their own mechanic that provided decent challenge and having the option to fight them again.

This is not a must play game, at best your looking at a Marvel movie level of enjoyment in this game. Its no masterpiece and I believe anyone who enjoyed Persona 5 can skip this game.

Edit: *There is no ultrawide support.*

author: ea3fea33-fa55-5d5f-a01e-4565d97bfe4a
content: An interesting twist on the typical Persona formula. The switch from turn-based combat to hack-and-slash makes fights more interesting, but still leaves something to be desired. The story is unabashedly a rehash of the original Persona 5, making the conflict very uninteresting. However, the two new party members are very well done and enjoyable. Of course, style and polish are the forte of the game. Everything from finisher animations to menu UI is a pleasure to experience. Persona 5 fans will certainly enjoy this spinoff, but fans looking for more substance may be disappointed.

author: e5059497-83d6-56b5-b0a8-a96e14ae9cad
content:
Not quite the masterpiece as its predecessor, but a solid sequel. The combat gets pretty nuts, you fight ridiculous amounts of enemies dynasty warriors style, but there is plenty of variety and strategy to it. Excellent boss fights! And naturally the soundtrack slaps too because Shoji Meguro. The one huge flaw it does have is the story takes like 1/3rd of the game to actually get interesting. But even with the weak story early on it's still fun, and the story does get really good(albeit being a bit too similar to the original). The cast is mostly the original P5 characters(sadly no Kasumi here...) with a couple excellent new ones added in like Zenkichi and Sophia. 

Final verdict, 8/10.

author: fc774847-1021-5330-bf16-d64b76976527
content:
Slow start aside, this is what I wanted from Persona 5. 
I thought the original game was good but very flawed in matters of story, characters and setting. Some of the themes just never connected, the social links varied wildly in how good they were (most got ruined by including boss fights in the end), and overall the story and villains felt weak, cartoonish, and juvenile.

Persona 5 Strikers is a do-over. After the second dungeon the game opens up and goes mask-off about being  P5 without the rewrites and crunch to finish. And it's *really* good at being Persona 5. I now enjoy this side of the franchise way more, love all the characters and would be super down to see them again.

Added to being a superior telling of P5's story, it's also just a great action game. It's not perfect, some mechanics could have used some polishing, but I had a blast with it. I really really beg of you to continue after the second castle -- it is the weakest part of the game and could be completely taken out and it wouldn't change much. Game starts from the third castle onward and never lets up. 

I'd recommend this to anyone who kinda enjoyed P5, and people who want a cool action game to spend a long time with.

author: 1d195c96-6d66-55ef-b2e8-d6d4c9a56432
content:
If you like Persona, you might like this game. If you don't particularly like Persona, though, you won't find a good Warriors/Musou game here, and if you aren't that familiar with Persona's gameplay mechanics, you also won't find a helpful introduction to them here. Incidentally, I don't have notifications on, so I don't really care if you agree or not; I'm being honest, as a big fan of Musou and someone who vastly prefers other MegaTen spin-offs.

Ryuji is one of the only remotely sympathetic characters, and most of the rest are varying degrees of awful and insufferable. Naturally, the one kind of likeable character gets treated like dirt by most of the rest of them. Not that they have much empathy for any other living thing, however, as evidenced by Yuusuke's insane soliloquy near the end of the second venue. This also ironically tries to make the others seem like good friends, even though that's never once evident in the game itself.

Not that they miss any opportunity to talk, at length, about everything. Sometimes it's kind of charming and can even be a little helpful, in battle when one might mention the weakness of an enemy. Most of the time, it's something you want to fast-forward through or skip. You have multiple options in most conversations you're involved in, but you usually only get to chime in once or twice, and it doesn't really matter what you say that much, either. It "but thou must!"s all the way. Most of the time, if you get a few options, it's "horrible person", "more plausibly deniable but still horrible", and "seems sensible but skews horrible-ish thanks to the railroading happening in most of the game".

One of the game's best parts is how it creates some interesting places to see and fills them with things to do. Unfortunately, it doesn't really immerse you in the location, aside from some superficial traits, and the areas you can walk around in are extremely small. You seem unable to revisit places you've been, aside from the tiresome and fairly homogenous jail/palace/whatever they're calling them environments, which isn't really that exciting. Most of the layouts of these places are confusing, but not in a challenging or fun way, and the themes end up looking a lot alike, so it becomes easy to get disoriented. You'll also probably not be able to finish one in a single attempt, and additionally, some enemies give no indication of how powerful they are, so you might mop the floor with them, or they might one-shot you, which is super fun, let me tell you.

You also can't just pause and exit the game if you get yourself into a fight you either don't want to finish or know you're going to lose, so you have to just shut it down instead. This discourages you from ever taking any risks or exploring, which seems to be a poor decision in game design. Sometimes things happen that are either impossible to avoid, despite what the game indicates, or just not well explained and thus annoying, like the invisible platforms, which I regard as one of the laziest things in any game.

Other elements, like the shallow cooking one and local cuisine, are intriguing at first, but most of the dishes are the most disgusting trash anyone could ask for. Half of the recipes I found were of things that even the most Japanese of friends either can't stand or never eat. Most of the truly appealing fare was barely touched upon at this local shop or that, if it appeared at all. That's a shame. You're also forced to make a batch of truly gross curry and they attempt to bully you into making it again. But not to worry, the cooking element is mostly optional...mostly. It does seem a shame, though, to have such a potentially useful thing end up being so distasteful in so many ways.

The biggest problem with it being a Musou/Warriors game is that it doesn't play like one, and it isn't fun even for just that. It takes ages to get through sections because the characters won't shut up and keep having cutscenes that you can't skip through, which means you are constantly losing all momentum. You're also expected to try and be stealthy, which is already an element I dislike in most games, but it could randomly decide you're not being stealthy enough and throw you into a fight via cutscene or unexplained gameplay mechanic shenanigans. Add to this the fact that most items you find in a dungeon are literally garbage, and it's very hard to recommend this game to anyone but someone who dearly loves the Persona series and can't get enough of the characters. Even that kind of person might be put off though, because the gameplay is unlike both Persona and Warriors games enough that it is often frustrating for all the wrong reasons. Add to that the fact that the difficulty settings are just a lie, and it's really hard to keep coming back.

author: 89348e08-649b-5a69-869d-4352b4e86e06
content:
I can hardly find a concise way to express my feelings for P5S, other than: it exceeded my expectations.

This game doesn't feel like it was made so that Atlus could squeeze a few extra G's out of their franchise, which can easily happen with sequel-spawning franchises. It feels like Atlus genuinely wanted to tell a brand new story to people everywhere, one filled with emotions and difficult topics as usual, using their most recent (and most popular) world to do it, because Atlus loves their franchise as much as the fandom does. Strikers has just as much heart and soul as the original P5 did, and you can FEEL it in every mile of this road trip of a lifetime.
If you're still apprehensive, let it be known: it's easy to figure out the new combat system, the new characters and story are all wonderful, and our beloved Phantom Thieves are just as stylish+hilarious+wholesome as ever;)

author: 249fd5b6-137b-56b6-8e9d-430335d847df
content:
When this game was first revealed, I was honestly skeptical if a Persona installment would work with the mechanics of a Musou game. Diving in I expected a half baked experience where you mindlessly killed hordes of enemies from level to level but that was not the case. Everything that you love about Persona is present within the game. Great characters, amazing storytelling, a fun world to explore, and the music(OMG THE MUSIC!) Hanging out with your friends one second and diving into a huge and unique dungeon has never been so fun. Strikers doesn't feel like a spin-off. It feels like a true mainline Persona game. The only difference is the combat that I would say is very similar to the newer Final Fantasy games. After close to 100 hours and a 100% completion, I can confidently recommend this game to any Persona fan old and new. Get ready to become a Phantom Thief once more!

Also ATLUS!!! Give us more Persona on Steam! Thank you!

Edit: ATLUS IS GIVING US MORE PERSONA ON STEAM! LET'S GO!

author: 8a9384d9-1d2e-54cc-9c45-15ce74084eea
content:
I highly recommend Persona 5 Strikers to any Persona 5 fan, even if you are not familiar with musou games at all. Here is a list of things you might want to know before jumping in: 

1)  It is strongly advised to complete original Persona 5 prior to starting this game. Strikers is a direct sequel that draws heavily upon P5, which implies that a) many scenes require familiarity with the story and characters of P5 to fully appreciate, and b) If you have not played Persona 5, Strikers will contain a lot of major spoilers. 

2) Beating the Royal version of Persona 5 before Strikers is not required. Apart from a (damn good) battle music track which unlock after completing the main story of Strikers, there are no references to content that Royal adds on top of the original P5. 

3) Social links and time management are absent. However, the story contains numerous social scenes, most of which are great. In addition, there will be some optional opportunities to hang out with your friends in certain cities you visit.

4) The story itself is pretty good. Characters are great: new ones receive significant development, while every returning member of Persona 5 cast gets their fair share of moments to shine. 

5) Combat happens in real time with time freezing while summoning persona or shooting a gun. However, it features a pretty good implementation of certain key elements from turn-based combat of the original P5: the importance of a diverse persona roster, SP management, buffs and debuffs; weakness system and all-out attacks; various types of technical hits; quirks of different healing spells. Apart from using skills for SP, every persona has its own set of skills which are cast as finishers of various combo moves. To top that off, each teammate has a collection of unique features that personalize their approach to battle. All of this adds up to a very fun, addictive and fluid system, where people with prior knowledge of P5 combat can gain a solid foothold right away. 

6) Fusion system is more restrictive, but I still had fun with it. There are much fewer personae in compendium, and each of them has a very limited number of fusion recipes. In addition, some of those recipes require parent persona to be at least of a certain level. However, the game allows you to increase the level of a persona by spending persona points (earned by fusion, releasing personae or collecting personae from battle when your stock is full), so no tedious grinding is necessary to meet those requirements. It's still possible to create really powerful combinations, but now you have to think harder about the way of passing all the skills you want to the target persona. Thankfully, skills cards exist. 

7) Dungeons are fun to explore. Apart from distinct visuals, each one has some gameplay or level design features that give it a unique feel. Stealth is the same as it was in P5: simplistic and satisfying. Also, now you can use environmental objects in battle, which is really cool and often powerful.

8) Visuals are stylish as always, and soundtrack is a blast. 

9) Completing the main story, all side quests, beating all optional bosses and unlocking New Game + took me approximately 60 hours. Almost no grinding was involved, and I had a lot of fun the entire time (except for a single battle).

author: 320bfd43-ae44-537e-a240-63f777f76dea
content:
It's a spin-off made in-part by Dynasty Warriors developer Omega Force was announced, most folk assumed it would be a Persona-skinned, musou-style action game similar to the studio’s other licensed series like Hyrule Warriors or One Piece: Pirate Warriors. In reality, however, the simple but engaging real-time combat of Persona 5 Strikers is structured much closer to action-JRPGs like Kingdom Hearts, barely resembling a musou game at all.

So this game, it’s good, great story, and it is much more than a button masher. It beautifully blends rpg action with hack and slash combat. The music is great as always. The only problem I have with this game is most of the time, there’s too much dialogue but I got over it after like the third conversation. The villains are also great. There’s a lot of exploration! Overall, great game. Considering this game is like warriors we could possibly have a few crossover characters and that would be cool, considering they did a crossover with Hatsune Miku in Persona 4 Dancing All Night which was a nice addition to the game.
10/10

content:
Pretty fun, but the grind for the bond exp trophy is a terrible slog that I'm in the midst of. Other than that, my only other complaint is that my Xbox controller is very particular when it comes to this game. You have to wait to connect the controller until the game is running. If you don't, the game will bug out and constantly switch the button icons from Xbox to PS and the button mapping gets funky.

That aside, this game was a good experience. You'll want to have played P5 or P5R in order to fully grasp the story. The combat was difficult to grasp at first, but after a few hours I got the hang of it, especially after I figured out how to get my controller to work with the game. 

With that being said, I doubt I'll come back to this game after I get all of the achievements for it, or at least not any time soon. It's a great game, and the mainline Persona games are probably my favorite video games of all time, but it doesn't really hold a candle to the mainline games. Most of the enjoyment I got from this game was just getting more Phantom Thieves content.

author: 64fe242f-797f-5db5-8137-705b63a15b76
content:
P5R ON PC OUR DREAMS HAVE COME TRUE

Clickbait ‘title’ aside, Persona 5 Strikers is for sure worth your time coming off either vanilla P5 or P5R. A subtle hint I like about this game is the lack of confidants/social links, with the new BOND system taking its place. It says all the individual bonds between Joker and the rest of the regularly scheduled Phantom Thieves are as ‘maxed’ as much as possible, being more about enjoying the experiences of their trip around Japan and becoming a tighter group overall as opposed to the compartmentalized substories SLs tend to be. 

Zenkichi and Sophia are also great additions with great character arcs, the former reminding me of previous Hierophant Arcana characters and their respective daughters, but this one being something the Phantom Thieves have an active, prolonged hand in that makes it feel very believable and relatable. Sohpia is a bit more predictable of an AI gaining sentience, but she still has a very heartwarming personality and conclusion. They both remind me quite a bit of Takuto Maruki, may Billy Kametz rest in piece. 

As someone who has never played a Dynasty Warriors game, I have to say the combination of action and turn based combat from both series is put together seamlessly and the moment to moment gameplay flows perfectly. Baton passing and showtimes really make you feel like working as a team has true benefits and each interaction really brings each PT’s character out, my favorite showtime being Zenkichi’s. 

So yeah, P5S is a great addition to the Persona series, even if a full $60 is a bit steep coming off 120+ hours from Royal. I’d conclude it calling it a very heartwarming experience, that’s the feeling I got from my time with it if I had to describe it in one word. Great straightforward story that lets us see our favorite delinquents again and seamless gameplay that is punchy, cathartic and as stylish and over-the-top as ever. (And of course 10/10 music, especially randomized music from all past mainline Persona games, good one Atlus.)

author: 90b6d8a3-0a1a-5e88-8406-6dfb21af017a
content:
Ayyyye, I'm back again with another review...I know, I know, who goes from Travis Strikes Again to Persona 5 Strikers? I don't know, I'm just wack with my taste, I guess. Still working on The Silver Case too, and I'm almost done with [i] that [/i] game too. Anyways, it's showtime!:

[h1] The Narrative/Story [/h1]

Well...it's a lot like Persona 5's original story (whether it be Vanilla or Royal, doesn't matter cause they both segway into Strikers.) This time around, you've travelling all around Japan and saving the world once again! Everyone gets their own moments to shine in the story again, which is nice and we do see the development from P5 show up here. It's hard to really comment on as it really just boils down to the Phantom Thieves (along with a couple of members, one of which is unironically one of the best parts about the game.) 

The locations chosen work with the story and the pacing and writing were fine, better than Vanilla 5's writing in my opinion. I think the themes that felt a little tacked on in the original are either written better here or the new themes (like family issues in Haru's case, not going into any spoilers) are decently enough written. The entire of the game....mehhh...it's kinda cheesy, maybe I'm just used to the Persona formula of having happy but sad endings, but it still had me invested through the end.

I'll give it either a A-/B+, it's alright. Not the best writing in the world, but far from the worst...trust me...I'm...not so fond of some of P3's writing in particular, but we'll save that for when Persona 3 Portable gets ported to PC sometime next year...


[h1] The Gameplay [/h1]

Probably the best aspect about this game. Being a Muso game (and having played Hyrule Warriors on Wii U a long time ago), I actually really enjoyed this game's gameplay. Sure, after a while, it gets a bit repetitive, but upgrading you and your party members as well as mastering new skills by just doing combos and whatnot freshens the game up a bit, not to mention you're [i] always [/i] getting new Personas and strengthening them, getting them new skills just like in normal P5. A lot of the mechanics carried over quite well to this game and in my opinion, this is one of the best Muso games I've played (which isn't saying much because again, I've only played Hyrule Warriors before this game that was back when the game came out.)

The only issue I have with it is that if you like doing side content, getting some of the [i] really [/i] good demons and having the best equipment possible for everyone like me, you'll have to do quite a bit of grinding for money and Persona Points (PP for short...kind of an really overused term in RPGs if you ask me.) I'd say it's mostly worth it get to awesome Personas like Yoshitsune, Alice, and Mara and with the ability to pitch which skills to inherit when fusing, skill-swapping for Joker's Personas any time in overworld in the Persona menu, and a constant flow of new Personas, grinding shouldn't be too bad, I'd say money's the biggest issue and even then there's ways around it. So I guess the only complaint I have with it asides from it potential repetitiveness is that it's a little grindy, especially towards the end.

A-, it's pretty solid stuff and I'm genuinely surprised how the mechanics from Persona/SMT carried over into a Hack N' Slash as well as they did here.

[h1] The Visual/Audio Design [/h1]

[i] *Sigh* [/i] Yeah... this is one of the weaker parts of this game. Let me get the graphics out of the way first, though.

Visually, the game looks great! The overworlds are nice and detailed and look great without suffering any performance issues (which surprises me quite a bit given that I've heard Muso games usually have pretty bad PC ports or at least mediocre ones that have their issues) and the effects like the ones seen on the Personas is nice. The menu, while not [i] as [/i] stylish as P5's original menus are still pretty nice here and definitely have their own flair and are relatively easy to navigate (minus the menu before the final boss which was...kind of clunky.) I really can't complain about anything visually with the game, the models are all nice, the FMVs both pre-rendered and animated are quite nice and the game looks pretty good for game that was on Switch and PS4 originally (the former suffering pretty badly from framerate issues from what I've heard.) Point is, it looks good, Atlus did great with this game's visually just as I'd expect them to.

Now the audio....uhhh...well...it's not great. Let's start with the voice-acting. I kinda feel like a few of the cast members forgot how to do their original character's voices, Ryuji sounded kinda off here and there especially and so did Joker, and some of the other character's actual audio sounds quieter or louder than others which is also kind of distracting. You can definitely tell this game was recorded during COVID while the everyone was at home, but they certainly tried and to be fair, the further along the game goes everyone sounded just fine again, so I guess it was just a few lines from everyone that got a little messed up. The acting for the new characters were perfect! Loved Zenkichi's VA's performance especially, he absolutely nailed the character and really made the banter between the Thieves lively. Sophia's...fine too, I can't really say anything about her without going into spoilers, but she did fine with her roll too. A- stuff, if only because of the few lines that could've been re-recorded to sound better and...not forcing people to record from home and just have them socially distance and record in a studio, it is what is, though.

As for the music...well...I was told not to use the default music and to just use the Persona BGM DLC I'd bought with my Deluxe Edition I got about a year ago (...yeah, this game's been on my backlog for A WHILE now...and the other DLC is kinda whatever, I used it for the beginning of the game and never used it again, so it kinda felt like a waste, I forgot to mention that in gameplay, but whatever) and while I enjoyed the DLC music being there for Persona 1-4, the other music was okay too, nothing special and it got a little repetitive hearing the same few battle songs over and over again, but there's some original music in here (namely Daredevil) which are absolutely [i] banging [/i] tunes. I'd say the overall OST excluding the DLC music is a B+, it's alright, there's some good songs in there, but [i] a lot [/i] of the music was reused from OG P5, which is a little...I guess lame.

[h1] The Verdict/Conclusion [/h1]

While this game does have its issues of being a little grindy and being a little repetitive, it's a nice companion piece to P5 that I'm sure anyone would played the original game (and also likes Muso games and or Hack N' Slashes) will enjoy. I'd give it around a 7.5-8.0/10, nothing spectacular, but a solid game that kept me invested til the end. If you've got like 70 hours to spare like I did (I idled for some of my hours to get to 93.1, don't always believe my hours, Yakuza 0 and Kiwami 1 were also botched in that regard), then go for it.

Oh, but here's one piece of advice [b] PLEASE DON'T BUY THIS GAME FOR FULL PRICE. WAIT FOR A SALE. [/b] Yes, I know this game's only a year old, but that doesn't excuse it for being overpriced (especially with the DLC like...really? $10 for a BGM pack, jeez man. Meanwhile, Atlus is STILL pulling this kind of stuff with Nocturne HD Remaster and more atrociously and recently with Soul Hackers 2...which I'm not gonna even bother buying until it goes on sale because 1. I still wanna play the original and 2. I don't want pay $100+ for a new game, that's just ridiculous.), it's a good game, but not $60 good, $30 maybe at most.

Well, if you're still up for it despite that, then it's showtime!


[h1] Post-Review Ramble [/h1]

So uhhh...yeah. Hoping to finish The Silver Case soon and [i] that [/i] game's gonna be a fun one to review...just you wait...

author: 761298b2-69d9-5c01-8e8d-83b7667915a5
content:
My hours are elevated due to leaving it on when not playing. I originally played about 40 hours.  I wanted to like it...........I really did. However, there are some very "meh" aspects. First of which is the predictability in the flow of the game. Travel to new place, eat, find a new jail and liberate people, travel again......wash rinse and repeat. I suppose those things would be fine if they weren't each so shallow.  Each new area/place requires an investigation phase. This would simply mean talking to a few npcs..........and boom! Investigation is complete. The eating phase is simply the characters raving for about 2-3 minutes about what foods to eat in the area. This means nothing to you, the player, or to the story. It's done by cut-scenes. Ultimately it feels like a lot of the dialogue during this phase is just rehashed over and over. One character is excited about a certain food, and other characters mention alternatives.  The next issue is...............

The predictability of the issues surrounding the monarchs. Several of the monarchs have ties to members of your party, but it's not done in an interesting way. What's more, it follows the unfortunate pattern in anime-like games where it feels like every character has to say their "piece" regarding to a situation, and it's really not necessary........especially when they are just agreeing with each other in different words. 

The gameplay is simplistic and while it may seem really cool about creating and improving new personas..........you will eventually start to lose enthusiasm despite multiple new personas being available at each level. Why? Because you will notice that the move-sets are the same as other personas and that the stats really don't vary that much when within 10 levels of each other. 

The leveling is broken when you can earn as much experiance and more money in the beginning area of the 2nd jail than you can by the time you  can enter the 5th jail. The beginning area of the 2nd jail is one of the few areas where enemies respawn (including a near-500 exp enemy). Just continue to let yourself get detected and maintain it around the 30%-90% and go after the crystal enemy each time you hear it on the map.  The crystal enemy also gives about 500 exp. You can get up to a million yen in about an hour and level up quicker than most areas. 

Ultimately, after the 4th jail and seeing everything start to repeat again on the 5th location/jail.........I just gave up and youtube-ed the ending.  Save your money. At least with Persona 5 there was a better overall story and had a dating aspect.

author: 5f4c07e5-db64-50f4-8d14-149a5d604623
content:
P5S is a good Hack-and-Slash that can be enjoyed by any players, be it existing Persona fans or new players.

P5S is a direct continuation from the base game, Persona 5, but can be enjoyed even without experiencing the base game itself. This allows Persona fans to enjoy the story continuing from its original ending, but also allow for new players, experiencing the Persona series for the first time, to enjoy the game. The story isn't anything too great but is good enough for an enjoyable experience. The story is very linear, meaning the choices made by your character will have no impact towards the endings. The dialogue options only affects how the other characters will respond and could make for some funny interactions between characters. The character interactions are great and provides lots of humorous and some badass moments.

The gameplay is where it truly deviates from the usual Persona Series. All previous installations of the Persona franchise (Not including spinoffs like Arena or the Dancing games) were mainly Turn-Based JRPG, but P5S is a Hack and Slash. 
This makes the game more fast-paced and action packed but could be a turn off for those who enjoy the strategy of Persona games. 

P5S is also significantly shorter as compared to the other Persona games. It took me 40+ hrs to clear the base game and could easily be cleared in a shorter amount of time as I took the time to do every requests and search every nook and cranny of each jail. Also there is still New Game+ to play which could easily take me an additional 20hrs or so. Making the total game time to be around 50-60hrs.

Overall, I would give this game a solid 7/10. Gameplay is good but certain parts felt repetitive (especially farming Persona Points to fuse certain Personas in the later part of the game). Story was pretty so-so but the character interactions were great. I would recommend buying this game on a sale for anyone who enjoys Hack-and-Slash or are Persona Fans.

EDIT: Took me an additional 25hrs to complete all achievements. Have yet to complete NG+ playthrough, but doubt I would finish it. It is still a fun game to me but to 100% it did not feel as fun as just completing the game on the first run. It lacked the replayability that all base Persona games have but the challenge that Merciless posed in the early stages of NG+ was indeed quite challenging. However, once you fused a few max stats Personas, the game becomes quite a breeze and just knowing how to use Status Ailments and Technical to your advantage to wipe through most bosses relatively easily. This does not change my rating of it as to 100% a game is more of a perfectionist or if the game is really one of your favorites. In my case, its just that I really enjoy the Persona series and just wanted to 100% it as I wait for other Persona ports that.

author: c89c2ff3-e815-5e72-9db4-4faf4876a79c
content:
After spending 103 hours in Persona 5 Royal on the PS4 (PC port PLEASE), I breezed through Persona 5 Strikers in a measly 35 or so hours. 

While P5R is a turn based RPG with heavy social elements, P5S is an action game through and through with most of the RPG elements and social elements slimmed considerably or completely removed. It is still a hell of a lot of fun though. The combat against mobs can get old but the boss fights (of which there are plenty) are where the combat really shines and shows how excellent it is.

The story is a sequel to P5R and while the main narrative isn't nearly as engaging as the previous game's story (though still fun), the characters, both returning and new are just as excellent as always. They are what make the Persona 5 games so memorable and fun and they really shine here - P5R was their origin story and P5S is them getting to go on a new adventure already knowing each other. 

And that MUSIC...this soundtrack is amazing yall. Hard to not wanna punch something in the face when Daredevil starts playing.

I will be saving my remaining side content (which is mostly just extra boss battles and finishing the persona registry) for a NG+ run down the road, but I am eager to return to this game sometime.

author: b7208ccc-6700-5532-afd6-3370daed520f
content:
I have about 10 friends who have this on their wishlist, which reminds me that I should say, this is NOT Persona 5. This is sequel to the original, faithful in every way EXCEPT that it has a completely different mode of gameplay. It resembles Musou's, if you've played Dynasty Warriors OR Hyrule Warriors, you should know pretty quickly what you're getting into. I'm not a Fighting game man but you're gonna have to remember some button inputs.

Should edit this as I go on. Initial impressions are good, except what in the hell are these keyboard bindings. The main character and Makoto are the only ones without free aiming, just why!?! If you're gonna play this with keyboard and mouse, I think an extra button or two on your mouse will help you out. if you have good reflexes, get the Level 1 Avenger skill (Not available initially), with which you can nullify an attack if you Phanton Dash towards that enemy at the perfect time; I tell you this as it brought me the most joy out of the combat in the game.

I suffer slowdowns after a few battles, and had to reset the game. Later I found out it's caused by the Rendering Scale option. You also have to tab out of the game and come back for the slowdowns to go off or for the Rendering Scale option to apply. I change back to 1.3 Scale if I know there won't be battles for a while so it doesn't look so jagged (You cannot change this option in the middle of battle so don't plan to do it in the middle of the dungeon's boss fight before an hour of unpausable story!)

Atlus, if you're not going to port the original Persona 5 OR Royal (The extended version) just yet, at the very least make your other releases up to par (Tip: Don't look up anything about the game if you wanna avoid spoilers, seriously, Youtube reviews should suffice, avoid comments or even Community Hub content).

You might want this mod, the letterbox border is just terrible, it looks like a bug: https://gamebanana.com/mods/288445

author: 5dd8bc4e-ba73-58d2-b75d-ef6e0cfa035a
content:
Persona 5 Strikers overall does a fantastic job of bringing P5's characters and gameplay to a whole new style of combat.  Fights are smooth, the combos are satisfying, and it still feels like Persona combat.  Elemental affinities are still present, and Joker can freely swap between available Personas.  Every playable character feels unique and has a moveset I feel accurately represents them.  For example, Morgana can transform into his car form seen in Mementos, and several of Makoto's combos involve riding Johanna or rapid punches.  The story overall was pretty good and helped make this still feel like a Persona game.  The Phantom Thieves are rather static characters compared to the original game, but instead they help others find their own way, especially the two new members of the Thieves.  However the first few Jails can feel rather...samey and formulaic.  It doesn't help that every boss fight takes place in a castle.  It loses some of the uniqueness seen in P5's Palaces.  I also don't think the Jail Monarchs have the same impact as Palace rulers, but there were good ones.  

One major returning part of the game to really tie it back to the Persona series is the Velvet Room.  Lavenza alone manages it this time as Igor is nowhere to be seen.  And this was honestly what I felt to be the weakest part of the game.  Especially coming nearly fresh off of Persona 5 Royal, the Velvet Room felt very bare bones.  Persona Fusion works in pretty much the same way, but there's not much else.  You gain the ability to level your Personas directly up to Joker's current level with a new currency, but it gets very expensive very quickly.  Not helped are the new restrictions that the Personas themselves now must be at a certain level to be fused.  This wasn't a big deal in the early game, but trying to get powerful Personas in the late game was a chore as they often required Personas acquired in early Jails to be at a level far past when they stop learning new skills.  For example, King Frost requires Jack Frost and Jack-o-Lantern to be at level 40 while Joker to be at level 66.  But Jack-o-Lantern might be around level 8.  So the only way to get him the extra levels is to spend the new persona points.  But I at least could not find a reliable way of getting them besides re-summoning and dismissing high level Personas.  Gaining new Personas in the field is random; there is a chance a defeated Shadow will drop a mask for Joker, and that chance can be increased by leveling a skill.  Repeated Personas will give persona points instead of exp like in P5.

Overall this is still a very fun game with fantastic music and a decent story, but I think Persona 5 Royal is the more polished experience.  But for a spin-off sequel in a totally different genre?  It did a great job.

One last note: the digital deluxe edition is slightly misleading.  The art gallery and OST are locked in a separate application with no built-in way to download the contents.

author: d4538100-c6c6-5121-a80b-8d5a91870755
content:
Part of the cult status Persona series!

Not turn-based like most other Shin Megami Tensei games, but HacknSlash like Nier/DMC or similar. But, it fits the visual style of the predecessor Persona 5 perfectly. Also, playing P5 first is recommended, it contains the entire main cast and follows after the events of P5. Multiple story references to P5 too

Music and Visuals are A+ like you're used to
Fusion system like in the Persona series, but with roughly half as many Personas and skills.
Playable characters have different combat styles: buffing, fast/slow, status effects, etc.
Story is similar to P5, writing quality is on par with most fanfiction. But, 90% voiced with great voice acting! Also in Japanese with English subtitles.

Must buy for SMT fans. Also recommended for fans of Nier/DMC action games. If you're neither, check out some gameplay footage!

author: d0f414b0-b852-50c8-aed3-b8e69c989285
content:
Let me get this out of the way - I am a HUGE Persona fan. I finished Persona 5 (2 times), Persona 4, I've played Dancing in the past, and I'm currently playing Q and 3.

I CANNOT recommend this game. I am not a fan of Dynasty Warrior themed games. However, the problem goes beyond that. I didn't feel any... heart and soul in this spinoff. It just feels empty. I love the cities, they're beautifully designed and animated but... The dialogue isn't getting with me. It feels like dialogue that was created by an AI just for the sake of rushing out a half-baked story. The heroes don't feel like they're emotionally tied to the villains like they were in Persona 5, and beyond that? The villains just simply aren't interesting to begin with. It feels like they were just thrown into the mix for the sake of combat instead of them having a place in the story.

The perfect description for this game is generic. It's just not good, in my opinion. I found myself skipping through dialogue, and even skipping cutscenes. Cutscenes! I've never skipped anything in a Persona game prior to this game! A single sentence can easily sum up what was drug out through pages upon pages of generic, filler-like dialogue. And speaking of being drug out, I feel like this whole game is drug out through and through. As I got closer to the end of the game, I found myself wanting more and more for it to be over, groaning as I discovered 2 extra jails past what I believed to be the final boss.

I will say this - this is the most advanced Dynasty Warrior themed game out there. And with that being said... It still manages to be a boring, repetitive slog in terms of gameplay. The combat is just X, with a few Y's thrown into the mix for a petty amount of combos you can do. The combat, in reality, just becomes spamming whatever ~Ma move hits everybody's weakness.

Today, I'm gonna FORCE myself to finish this game, just for the sake of uninstalling it to free up space on my computer. Yeah, you heard that right, force. You should NEVER have to force yourself to finish a game, it means it just straight up isn't a fun/good game. It just feels like such a slog... As a person who literally completed New Game and New Game + of P5R back to back with no break, I'm heavily disappointed with this spinoff - and if I could... honestly? I'd refund it. I hope the next spinoff will be better.

Edit: I was so bored playing this that ultimately "forcing myself to play it today" turned into forcing myself to play it spread out through a period of a few days. It's that boring to me.

author: 3d9eb562-6d87-5829-9c5a-cfadba3e638f
content: If you liked Persona 5 you will love this game. I loved the game and only had minor issues with it. One being that the side mission requests can get very repetitive and boring especially at the end as you do the same things over and over again and get a ton of them especially near the end of the game. Also on hard difficulty, which is what I played the whole game on, some boss enemies get insanely bullet spongey as you wail on them for what seems like forever without much risk of dying. I also have a minor complaint in that the all out attacks seemed pointless at times as you would break the enemies guard only to deal an insanely small amount of damage after using what is supposed to be a finisher. I understand that it shouldn't just instant kill bosses, but sometimes I would use it and the boss health bar wouldn't even visibly move. In terms of positives there are countless including the near perfect transition from turn based to action combat as well as the excellent aesthetics and a story that tugged on my heart strings a couple of times.

author: d6cf96b0-1116-54a1-b4db-e87ecf0eb5be
content: A well-polished game that is, unlike other goofy dancing/fighting spin-offs of Persona, great enough to be considered a main-line Persona game. It's enjoyable to see the Phantom Thieves together again, joyfully hanging out one moment and deep in action dungeon-crawling the next. The gameplay is a drastic shift from turn-based Persona 5, but Koei Tecmo managed to revise their mindless hack-and-slash recipe from the Musou franchise to incorporate personas, the element and skill system into the action very well. It feels like I'm playing a normal Persona game, only with the real time action gameplay instead. Very recommended for anyone who enjoys the Persona franchise or the Phantom Thieves gang in particular.

author: 47de08ed-c3c2-57ac-bd1b-ad482384c813
content:
TL:DR
Gameplay? Very Good
Soundtrack? It's a banger 🤘
Artstyle / Graphics? Beautiful
Story? Good
-----------------------------------------

A sequel to Persona 5 - The gameplay changes from the usual turn based combat that you can find in all Persona games to a hack-and-slash type combat you can find in games such as in the Dynasty Warrior series. While it does change the gameplay, the gameplay is very good, especially in Persona 5's artstyle. Gameplay is very good.

Soundtrack can be described with one word: Amazing. The songs you'll usually hear in this game are remixes of songs you'll find in the original Persona 5, but do not get me wrong, THEY ARE NOT BAD! The remixes are just as good as the original songs they are remixed from. You'll enjoy the battle themes, boss themes, etc. The original songs made for this game though are good, while continuing to retain the Persona 5 OST's original style.

The artstyle is still the same as it was from Persona 5, and it looks gorgeous. As I said from earlier, the combat looks SO fantastic due to Persona 5's artstyle, making everything look flashy and just all around beautiful. Though, I can say it may be overwhelming for a small amount of people, but it wasn't for me.

The story isn't necessarily the best or what you expect from a Persona game, but it is a good sequel to Persona 5 story-wise. The story does take place a few months after the end of the original Persona 5, and it ends with a satisfying conclusion. For those who hasn't played Persona 5 originally, I wouldn't really recommend playing this game at first, as there may be things you don't understand, or things you would appreciate more if you played through the original Persona 5, such as the characters. That's to say though, the developers for this game did say you can enjoy the game even if you didn't play the original Persona 5, so knock yourself out. Overall though, story's great.

Thanks for reading.

author: 66f6210d-d11a-5125-bd7d-069a1a937920
content:
It was probably wrong to jump into this game as my first Persona game in terms of story, (second JRPG I've ever touched) but I found that I was able to somewhat pick up things fairly quickly from wherever it was left off from whichever the last game was. As someone who is brand new to the Persona franchise, this game was a blast to play, and the story while I thought it wasn't something that was 'out there' and a 10/10, the music is incredible, and bond that the cast of characters share and their interactions with each other, really kept me playing.

All of the characters are likeable in their own ways, and while the dialogue does get a tad corny every now and then, it's just a bunch of people who are just having a great time on their Summer road trip. What's not to like about it? Sometimes it does get a bit old with the same repeated lines when you're exploring the Jails, but other than that, the cast ranging from the 'problem student' Ryuji, to the dad of the group and cop Zenkichi, hell even Ichinose, even when she doesn't get as much screen time, they are all great.

The story was pretty decent, while I won't spoil anything here, the character development of some of the cast, was super satisfying. Although, the plot twist or two while it did have an impact, I did see them coming from a mile away. Overall, the story is still definitely memorable, and something that Hardcore Persona fans and brand new players like me would have a great time with.

The combat is fast and frantic. The gameplay is slick and some of the animations are super cool. Of course, each character has their strengths and weaknesses, while the game obviously isn't just going to let you go through the story like a breeze, if you don't play with these strengths and weaknesses in mind, even on normal difficulty which is what I played at, you will be punished more than you think you will, and I like that challenge. I do recommend that you play on hard difficulty however, and I probably should've done so from the beginning, because one you get your all your Personas kitted out with a wide range of abilities, buffs and debuffs, hitting those weaknesses really does a number on enemies and makes some sections a bit too easy. 

The soundtrack is absolute banger, which is a bit of a shame, since some of the best tracks are behind the combat encounters, and like I pointed out just then, the fights can be very quick. When you do get to those longer encounters, the music, combined with the slick gameplay is bliss.

If you already are a fan of the franchise, I can probably see you buying this game full price upfront. But if you're like me who was debating whether to do the same or not, I'd still recommend a buy, but when this game does get a discount, I would highly recommend that you buy it immediately. The art direction of the game is top notch, the gameplay is excellent, the story definitely has its moments, and the cast of characters is awesome. If the previous Persona games would now get a PC port, even with its difference in gameplay, I would throw money at you ATLUS and SEGA.

Zenkichi best boomer/10

content: I was a bit disappointed at first because I was expecting a Warriors game. Instead of a strategical beat em up, I got Persona game with real time combat. The jails don't feel like Warriors battlefields, they feel like dungeons. Not saying that's inherently bad, just wasn't what I was expecting. The writing isn't amazing, in fact they somehow managed to make the characters feel even more one note than they did in the first game. But persona spin offs are always like that, let's be real all of us were going into this expecting that. If I could give this a neutral rating I would. Overall I'd say it's good but probably worth waiting for it to go on sale. I don't think it's worth a full 60 bucks.

author: c2fbe734-6a1b-5d6b-8c06-9316ef00aa6f
content: Probably one of the most fun Persona experiences thus far. I got into the Persona series very late as I only started when Persona 5 first came out. I love this series, the game play feels fun and refreshing compared to some other turn based RPGs I have played in the past, the social links help you build a really big emotional attachment to the characters in the game, and even the story in amazing. Now about Strikers, it takes all of that and simplifies some aspects but makes others lots of fun. Strikers still has an amazing and compelling story just like Persona 5 and 4... is it predictable, a little bit, BUT I think that is okay as the story is really just there to have a base for the AMAZING game play that Strikers has. If you always wanted to try a Persona game but could never get into because you thought there was too much out of combat time the boy do I recommend this game.

author: 301b1f8a-75ab-5435-8f2c-b378a1713791
content: I've got this game imported from Japan after a month it came out in Japan. So around March of 2020, both on Nintendo Switch and Playstation 4. Beat them both which was nice, if you are expecting similar gameplay to Persona 5 or Royal then you are mistaken, this game has similar gameplay as Hyrule Warriors(That's the first game that popped in my head) As a spinoff (I know some people consider this game as a sequel but I don't really) Scramble, I won't be mentioning it as "Strikers", I'll be mentioning it as Scramble since it was called that in Japan. If you think you gonna see characters from Royal in this game, I'm sorry to say but they aren't in it. The story in this game is somewhat alright, I do like in some aspects and some I don't but I won't mention anything due to spoilers and I don't want to spoil anything. The gameplay is pretty alright kinda just stiffy imo, but once you get used to it, you can play it. One thing I would like to complain about is the fusion system, it's feels off like extremely but I think it's just me. Overall I give this game a 7.5/10, it's good for a spinoff but compare to the other Persona spinoffs. It isn't that good in some degree, the only thing I do like is the animation and the story.

author: 72425e6c-23d3-5886-bc97-2801013b5c46
content:
persona 5 royal is my favorite game of all time. i even cried when i beat it, absolutely incredible. this abomination of a game is a waste of money and if i had to force myself to beat it: following reasons

the gameplay is incredibly unfun, the "jails" (which is a glorified name for palaces in p5) are unbelievably repetitive, have no flavor, and are reskins of the current city you are in (which is not impressive looking either). the fun part of palaces other than the scenery was that you could do puzzles and explore around. in this game, neither of those exist as everything is a copy and paste of each other and there is 0 fun interaction whatsoever.

the combat is super SUPER horrible. i really enjoy hard games. i loved dark souls 3 and i have beaten every kingdom hearts game on lvl 1 critical. challenge is NOT an issue. unfortunately, this games combat is lackluster at best but the issue is that there is a fight LITERALLY (i promise i am not exaggerating) every 5 seconds (sometimes less) of walking in this game. if you don't fight youll get behind on levels,  so it's all around bad. not only this, the "difficulty" is not actual difficulty, it's just numbers being changed, the attacks aren't any harder to dodge or have any different logic like a harder mode would in another game, it's literally just more health and you deal less damage. this was so horrible and unfun that once i got to the third dungeon i modified the game to one shot every enemy and ignore all damage just so i could get through the game without ripping my hair out from boredom

if you've played and enjoyed a persona game, you KNOW the stories are absolutely amazing. if you would like to avoid spoilers for persona 3 fes, golden, or royal, or this game itself, skip to the next paragraph. persona 5 royal has one of the best stories i've ever seen, be it a book, a video game, or a movie. the characters were great. in this game you have a copy and paste of shido and a character that has a background like akechi's and has the personality of sojiro, all of the antagonists in the game are just rehashed and watered down versions from the previous game. remember kamoshida? the first palace in this game is a girl that takes advantage of men, the second dungeon is a guy who sells writing that isn't actually his... the third dungeon is a cross of okumura and a crappy shido, the fourth is the only actual interesting dungeon that i won't spoil anything for, the fifth has nothing to mention, but the sixth dungeon's antagonist is just a copy and paste of shido and the next one after that is basically mementos and ending the world all over again. nothing in this game is original whatsoever. one of the characters, sophia, is a copy and paste of aigis from persona 3. the only character in this game that i actually liked was the final antagonist, ichinose kuon, had a good personality and ok motive, which is the only reason i liked her, but it was literally just akechi 2.0 and you also could easily tell she would be the antagonist immediately after speaking to her from the first time. the way she was revealed as the antagonist isn't good either. in royal or golden for example you are interacting with the antagonist the whole time and tension is built and you later realize they've been betraying you the whole time, in this game, it's just "oh, remember kuon from way back when? yeah shes behind this" it's so unbelievably stupid. also, the final enemy of the game is, "phones took over everyones lives and we can't think for ourselves now" literally the dumbest story ever

the design/look of the game is the only thing i can credit the game on, outside of the dungeons, the game looks absolutely great, despite being terrible in the dungeons. not much to say here

the music was another strong point. in the persona games. the persona games are the only games i know where the music in them can be good enough to put in playlists with "real music", in this game, all of the original songs made specifically for this game are absolute bangers. the only complaint is that any song that received a "remix" for scramble that was taken from 5 absolutely sucks in this, because they tried to turn a jazzy thing into rock, and it absolutely sucks.

the only reason i forced myself to play through this is because i've beaten every persona game and i had to force myself to play this to say i'm fully up with the story in every game and i also spent 70 dollars on it sooooooo

yea don't buy this game

author: 6c9c4e6d-77f0-585d-a77a-e8b756a427d9
content:
This is an easy recommendation for me. The story can sometimes drag and feel like it's progressing nowhere. At times, the gameplay can feel a little clunky and disjointed. However, ultimately I think these more minor issues can be overlooked in the grand scheme of the game. It was nice to see these characters brought back for another (much shorter) story. 
Getting past these moments where the story can drag is relatively easy, but the gameplay is harder to write off. In my eyes, the original Persona 5 practically perfected JRPG combat, but the Action RPG gameplay on display here is just serviceable. I eventually got used to pausing the action to use persona abilities, but I feel like getting used to this overall hindered my experience with the game. I didn't really have a problem with it, but it's worth noting that this game lacks a confidant system entirely, and the days progress as the story progresses.
While maybe not being quite as good as the original game’s, the soundtrack is very well done. All of the new tracks were really memorable, and remixes of old tracks were too. The opening was great as well.
The story starts strong, drags on for a little while, then picks right back up as it climaxes. I think the payoff and experience are well worth putting up with these moments where the story drags. This road trip structure was really enjoyable and held the game together when the story was lacking. If you enjoyed these characters in Persona 5 and thought it’d be fun to go on a road trip with them, then look no further.

author: f4da937e-411c-53ef-96f8-d0984fa0d016
content:
Recommend getting if you like Persona. P5S is pretty good, a little lacking in story and villain development with sometimes clunky controls.

This game is basically Atlus's experiment at doing an ARPG, it turned out 'okay'. Camera and lock targeting is pretty lack luster. You have to 'pause' a lot with persona/gun to just get an understanding of what is going on and switching between characters is a little clunky for an modern ARPG. On top of that, the battles are 'instanced' so you lose a little of the open-world-esque that you would expect from an ARPG.

Though you have a calendar like past Personas, the game is a little more free form with the player choices. I actually found the lack of the 'confidant' aspect of character development made it feel pretty empty. Especially since the characters became pretty well developed in P5/P5R and almost none occurred in P5S.

author: 48ae412a-0c27-5339-a139-2e17db69bb8a
content:
This recommendation comes with some degree of caveat. For those of you looking for a Dynasty Warriors type of game, be prepared for system mechanics that are very unusual to the genre and not super intuitive unless you've played the main branch of Persona games already. For those looking for something similar to the main branch of Persona games, you'll only find bits and pieces of that here, as the gameplay is based around high-speed action rather than turn-based strategy, and things such as Social Links/Confidants and an approach to a day-to-day calender system are not present here. There is still a calender system in this game, but it's much less pronounced since you aren't limited in how much you can do in a single day, and thus there's never really a threat of running out of time.

If these are things you can work around or if you simply have exposure to both the genre and the Persona series, you'll find a very fun game that manages to combine the systems from both games pretty well. Overall score would be an 8/10 if I had to give it a numerical value.
