author: fa5359ee-967e-57e6-8cb7-eb775c347d7d
content:
The Hog Rider card is unlocked from the Spell Valley (Arena 5). He is a very fast building-targeting, melee troop with moderately high hitpoints and damage. He appears just like his Clash of Clans counterpart; a man with brown eyebrows, a beard, a mohawk, and a golden body piercing in his left ear who is riding a hog. A Hog Rider card costs 4 Elixir to deploy.

Strategy

His fast move speed can boost forward mini tanks like an Ice Golem in a push. At the same time, he can also function as a tank for lower hitpoint troops such as Goblins as he still has a fair amount of health. Most cheap swarms complement the Hog Rider well, as they are nearly as fast as him and usually force more than one card out of the opponent's hand.

The Hog Rider struggles with swarms, as they can damage him down and defeat him quickly while obstructing his path. Barbarians in particular can fully counter him without very strict timing on the defender's part, though be wary of spells.

A Hunter can kill the Hog Rider in 2 hits if placed right on top of it. However, if you place something in front of the Hog Rider, the Hunter's splash will damage the Hog Rider and hit the card in front of it more.

The Hog Rider in conjunction with the Freeze can surprise the opponent and allow the Hog Rider to deal much more damage than anticipated, especially if the opponent's go-to counter is a swarm, or swarms are their only effective counter to him. Skeletons and Bats will immediately be defeated by the spell, while Spear Goblins, Goblins, and Minions will be at low enough health to be defeated by a follow up Zap or Giant Snowball.

However, this strategy isn't very effective against buildings as the Hog Rider will take a while to destroy the building, giving the opponent ample time to articulate another counter.

Against non-swarm troops, it can deal a lot of damage during the freeze time, but this can allow the opponent to set up a massive counterpush. For this reason, players should either only go for a Hog Rider + Freeze when they have other units backing it up from a counterattack, or if the match is about to end and they need to deal as much damage as possible.

It is not a good idea to send in a Hog Rider simply to destroy a building, especially if it is the only building targeting unit available, as defeating Crown Towers becomes substantially more difficult. Spells or simply waiting out the lifetime of the building are more effective. The exception to this is an Elixir Collector placed in front of the King's Tower. If a Hog Rider placed at the bridge, he can destroy the Collector for a positive Elixir trade, though the damage from both Princess Towers will usually mean he does not survive to deal any damage to them. However, if the opponent sends in defending troops, it can be an opportunity to gain spell damage value.

In a deck with several low-cost cards, it might be worth it to simply send the Hog Rider against one building. These decks shuffle their card rotation quick enough, that they will arrive to their next Hog Rider before the next building arrives in the opponent's card rotation.

Long-ranged troops like Musketeer and Flying Machine can snipe those buildings, preserving some of the Hog Rider's health, possibly allowing it to get some Tower damage.

When there are buildings placed in the middle to counter the Hog Rider, understanding the placement of the Hog Rider and the type of building placed can help the Hog Rider to bypass certain buildings.

Passive buildings such as spawners and Elixir Collector have a larger hitbox than defensive buildings; which means that if a passive building was placed 3 tiles away from the river in the middle of the opponent's side, then it is impossible for the Hog Rider to bypass that placement as the Hog Rider will get pulled to that building.

Defensive buildings have a smaller hitbox than a passive building, which means if that if a defensive building was placed three tiles away from the river in the middle of the opponent's side, a Hog Rider placed at the very left or right side of the Arena may be able to bypass it due to its smaller hitbox.

If the player has a building already placed down in the center of the arena, and the opponent tries to bypass it with a Hog Rider at the edge of the arena, they can use certain air troops to push the Hog Rider towards the building as it jumps over the river, effectively denying the bypass attempt. They must be already hovering over the correct placement, as very quick reflexes are required to correctly perform this technique.

For Bats, Skeleton Dragons, and Minion Horde, they should be placed right in front of the Hog Rider as soon as it is deployed.

For Minions, Skeleton Barrel, Mega Minion, Flying Machine, Electro Dragon, Baby Dragon, Inferno Dragon, Balloon, and Lava Hound, stagger the above placement one tile to the right if the Hog Rider is placed on the left side of the arena, and vice versa.

They can also use ground troops to achieve the same result. Something like an Ice Golem deployed at the Hog Rider’s landing spot will obstruct his path and force him to go around the unit, which causes him to be closer to the building instead of the Crown Tower.

The Hog Rider can kite Very Fast non-building targeting troops due to his own Very Fast speed and building only targeting if he is placed on the fourth tile from the bridge, slightly into the opposite lane. He can also stall grounded units when placed right at the bridge. He will pull them towards him while deploying, and then be untargetable by them when he jumps over the bridge. After landing, he will pull them back. This can be useful when the player needs to deal damage in the same lane they are defending. It will also help separate troops behind a tank in a large push.

A Tornado placed on the second tile front of the player's King's Tower and staggered two tiles towards the Princess Tower will activate it without any damage dealt to the Princess Tower, helping them in defending future pushes. This can also be a method of mitigating all damage dealt to a Princess Tower, but doing this more than three times may result in the King's Tower's health being low enough to be targeted directly, opening up the possible threat of a back door three crown. A better alternative is to pull the Hog away from the Princess Tower into the attacking range of all three Crown Towers, which will negate all damage as long as none of them are already distracted

A very powerful combo is the Hog Rider, the Musketeer, and the Valkyrie, typically referred to as the Trifecta. The Musketeer will defend against most troops, while the Valkyrie can protect her and the Hog Rider from swarms or high damage units. The Hog Rider is used to deal damage to the tower.

This can be effectively countered by Lightning, one-shotting the Musketeer and severely damaging both the Valkyrie and Hog Rider. The Minion Horde is also effective, but the enemy can Zap them and the Musketeer will one-shot them all. Even if the Musketeer is defeated, the Hog Rider and Valkyrie will have enough time to severely damage the Tower.

The Hog Rider should be placed behind the Valkyrie to give it a boost so that it stays in front of the Hog Rider, protecting it.

A Hog Rider combined with a Goblin Barrel can be awkward for the opponent to defend against. Timing it so that the Hog Rider is tanking the tower shots for the Goblins is the most effective way to deal damage. However, a Barbarian Barrel can shut this down with minimal Tower damage for a positive Elixir trade, as long as the Goblin Barrel was placed directly on the Tower.

author: ecd67f72-54e6-5fd8-87ab-c060182ea937
content:
The unexpected persona game to say the least but ATLUS did a very good job of keeping this game, well... still in the theme of Persona.

[h1] Combat Mechanics [/h1]
To be simple, Turn-based JRPG turn Real-Time.
A lot combat aspects are still there, surprisingly. Exploit weaknesses, All-Out-Attack, Baton Pass.[b] THEY ARE ALL STILL THERE! [/b] I'm surprise of how they are manage to do that and make it work flawlessly. And the most exciting of all, the Showtime is just gorgeous!

[h1] Everyday Mechanics [/h1]
Apart from the cut confidant, not a lot have change. You start by gather the information about the target  and then you go in the dungeon now call "The Jail" and then you go to a total nut job mode. Sometime do a request and spend time talking with teammates or inside the RV. Basically the game loop is that.
Bond system is the new one that they introduce in this game. Similar to Social Links/Confidant but instead of going to each teammates and get their abilities, you get points to upgrades which you will need them.

[h1] Story [/h1]
Since currently at the time of this review I have not finish the game yet and I know that no ones want a spoiler. So the only thing that I'm going to talking about is how they tell the story.
The story goes on like in the Persona 5, you notice that something is going on in Shibuya just when the Thieves are having a summer trip and later they know that the issue is going across the japan in various cities. The story has to deal with trauma of "the Monarch", the ruler of Jail, that works like a Palace [b]with a twist[/b].

[h1] Sound and Music [/h1]
Talk about Persona without the music is [b]WRONG[/b].
Although Shoji Meguro, ATLUS house composer, is not the composer in Persona 5 Striker, the music still an absolute banger! Sound effects overall is perfect.
Right now I really dig "Welcome To The Jail", "Counter Strike", "Axe To Grind", "You are Stronger" and a lot more!

To be honest, the things that ATLUS did. This would be a bottom at my list of what ATLUS would do the their games and I have doubt at first about this being the Beat'em Up kind of game because I don't like this kind of game. But they really take my breath away here, got to give it to them.

[h1]Some After Thought[/h1]
What I said above is all true, this game is still a fantastic game and I urge anyone who interested in this game to play. HOWEVER, this game-by all means-still is not a traditional Persona experience. I still recommend mainline Persona more than this game overall. And since this is a beat 'em up game and this is a linear-story game, the replay-ability is next to none apart from the completionist gamer. So for me, the flaws of this game is really "It's not normal Persona" which is dumb. ATLUS did a thing that throw us off, and they done a fantastic job. The bitter opening of this paragraph will not effect my verdict.

This. is. still. fantastic.

author: ddf22c59-53b3-508b-a984-099e47771a60
content:
Pros:

Good character interactions (imo better than P5 or P5R, none of that Morgana vs. Ryuji drama)
Gameplay is addictive as hell (no seriously, the base game is like 40-50 hrs but here I am doing playthrough after playthrough because I just can't put it down)
Killer soundtrack (then again, it's P5, you probably know what to expect by now)
More screentime for characters that were somewhat neglected in P5 and P5R, such as Haru and Yusuke.
Many characters to play and imo they all feel pretty distinct, useful, and pretty fun to play

Cons:

Writing (plot) is kind of meh, especially near the end, but it's not terrible
Sometimes freezes during loading screens (I've heard people say the 5th dungeon specifically, but for me it happens all the time, even entering/leaving velvet room, using shops, location transitions, etc.), which can undo your progress if you haven't saved recently. That being said, SAVE OFTEN.
SP/persona skills seem unbalanced, especially on Merciless mode; you have to use skills multiple times to break "shields" on bosses, let alone down them for an all out attack, but the amount of SP each character has is similar to P5/P5R, where this is not the case. Endgame often turns into a case of spamming persona attacks and SP items (the grind for SP items is real, especially since shops don't restock unless you do multiple battles in the metaverse)
Some controls are a little wonky (such as all-out attack, phantom dash, follow-up attack, interact, etc. all being triggered by the same button, with limited ability to create separate hotkeys for them). This seems to be a symptom of poor porting from console.

YMMV (i.e. some info that may be a pro or a con depending on the person):

No confidants/social links, no time management (you can leave and re-enter the dungeons at any time to replenish HP and SP with no detriment), no turn-based combat (i.e. missing many Persona gameplay staples)
This is a direct sequel to P5, NOT P5R (and the story very much reflects this)

content:
This game is quite literally better than Persona 5 in a number of ways.

It's story is just Persona 5 but better. It's music is just Persona 5 but better. The dungeons feel more fun since you can actually walk around them quickly and actually DO them. The combat is insanely fun. Zenkichi and Sophia are amazingly written characters that solo Kasumi and Akechi, tenfold. Their characterisation being well-woven into the story is also amazing. The pacing is much better than Persona 5 being around 50 hours playtime instead of 100. 

If you haven't played this game, DO IT. It is amazing. It is emotional. It is powerful. Everything is just better Persona 5 and you don't even need to play Persona 5 to understand the story or characters.

author: 609cd06a-1c76-58e8-80db-93f195105eb4
content:
It's very weird to see an entire full-length sequel to Persona 5 with Dynasty Warriors-style action combat, but it's a really cool idea and it's surprisingly well-done! While this game's menu animations aren't quite as immaculate as the original game's, they did a fantastic job carrying over the look of Persona 5 into this engine, to the point where a lot of the time it literally just looks like more of P5, but now running in 60fps. Per Persona tradition, the OST is still absolutely amazing, even in what is essentially a spin-off, and with that classic Warriors-style buttrock flavor appropriately mixed in as well.

The combat is very interesting at first. While attack combos and switching between characters feels a lot like other recent Warriors games, it still has a LOT of mechanics from P5. Sneaking up on enemies, going in and out of battle encounters, Persona skills, elemental weaknesses, all-out attacks, managing your HP and SP with items, even a lite Confidant system is here. However, much like Warriors games, you are often fighting a LOT of enemies at once, and nothing seems to stop all of them from attacking you at once, with all sorts of different abilities. This makes the combat VERY overwhelming for me, to the point where I definitely prefer Persona games' usual turn-based combat.

As someone who wasn't particularly impressed by the story and characters in Persona 5, it's kind of hard to get into this game for those same aspects, especially since a lot of it feels like a retread of the original game's plot points anyway. I almost dropped this game entirely since the story is pretty samey in the first few dungeons. Still, if you really like the cast of Persona 5, then you might have a great time with this game.

author: ffcdd17a-9941-5576-b94e-b6defbc7d965
content:
You know, all these reviews that are just copypastas and memes(or for this game. pleads of bringing P5R to PC) are getting me sick and tired. What about you hear a real review? I won't speak anything of the story as a. my playtime is low b. youd probably be looking at this from an outsider perspective.

Is P5S worth it? First off, yes. Musou games get really fun once you get the hang of it and all the characters all have unique traits(except Morgana getting a fucking weak 1 damage battering ram move. Not cool Atlus.) and once it gets on a roll, the gameplay gets addicting. First off, the first jail is seriously a chore to get through and it may make it seem like there is nothing else to do. But they made the decision to bar all the side studff until you can get to your next jail.

Second off, I said it's worth it But only on a sale please. It may have a good gameplay loop but I find this to be a bit... lacking for its current normal price

Third off, you may need to atleast have knowledge of PS's plot to get the story

Next, the music is amazing and absolutely gets you in the mood to straight destroy

The game also has a semi open world aspect where you get to buy stuff so you can cook or get it ready for use. Also be sure to always talk to your teammates in the non-metaverse map if its a new day. They will usually harbor some loot for you.

Umm... damn writing a long review is hard.

author: e0b31259-f6d7-5836-8b82-4a27a8d6d72f
content:
Have you played Persona 5 / Persona 5 Royal? If you said No. Do not buy this game as it is required story wise. 

After just completing Persona 5 Royal after 140 hours and absolutely loving it for the masterpiece that it is. a True 10/10. I was looking for more and i came upon P5S. Is this game better then Persona 5 Royal? No, Not by a long shot. Is this game worth playing? Yes. The combat does take alot of time to get used to and can be at times annoying. Especially the first half of the game. The bosses tend to be HP sponges and do not be scared to lower the diff. Normal is mostly good. Do not play this game on hard unless you want to suffer. The best part of this game is spending more time with all the characters that you grew to love in Persona 5 and meeting some new ones on the way. The story is solid and there will be some rehashing, related to Royal sem 3. (sem 3 is not cannon in this game). It was nice to travel around Japan and see the different areas as well. Overall i would rate the game a 7.5/10.

author: 36dc099a-ae9b-54cc-ab0c-26063f69fe41
content: P5S, maybe surprisingly, feels like a full and proper sequel to P5 (but, of course, not Royal..). Clocking in at about a 45 hour playthrough for me, it's a bit a good amount more lean than P5 (which took me about 110 hours), and I'm all for it. The social sim half of P5 is now condensed to a lot of screen time with your teammates (as well as building a general Bond meter to get skill points), but the fact that you and the group are ALWAYS together means you don't feel like you're being shorted on social content. The musou-style combat (combined with traditionally Persona-style dungeon exploring) works excellently and, frankly, I liked it way more than the turn-based combat of P5(R). I highly recommend it if you liked P5 and want more time hanging out with the gang.

author: 3608b51b-2bbd-590d-a21b-96118c46dc83
content:
TLDR - If you liked P5, then you'll like P5S, which is a slightly dumb'd down experience (no bonds to make, no social life to juggle with dungeon raiding). Same basic battle system, but here you're able to keep hitting attack in-between all your persona abilities to hit the weak spots and move around a bit. You'll still mainly be relying on hitting weaknesses and then performing all-out attacks. 

Story-wise, nothing groundbreaking here. It's just a road-trip romp with all the friends you made in P5 plus a new addition or two. 

Overall, if you wanted more adventures from the original P5, then this game is for you!

author: d789b585-8542-5e11-8c6f-16846eee2c11
content:
The Gameplay (although kinda gets repetitive just pressing the same two buttons), soundtrack and characters are amazing and it's a huge improvement over the original Persona 5, but here's a couple of things that bother me as I'm still playing the game while I am writing/editing this (long??) review and i hope these could be taken notes for in the future to improve upon:

1. (Issue that connects to the Modern Games)
The other battle songs being locked behind a DLC paywall (even though i paid for it so that the main songs wouldn't start getting on my nerves) which was the same issue i had with P5 when i played it years ago because of that.

2. The Calendar doesn't do anything since there's no deadline making returning and that leads to the unecessary issue of  leaving and entering the Jails repetitive for some healing instead of giving the checkpoints some sort of healing station in the dungeons like in the older games since the calendar barely does anything like in 3-5.

3. (Another big Issue that also connects to the Modern games)
It's been so many games and spin offs after P2: Eternal Punishment and there still isn't an option to make the Navi shut up, like Rise and Futaba because they're very annoying because their lines get repeated a lot and gets tiring especially Futaba with her very "quirky and cool" gaming references with her """""crippling social anxiety"""" problem when the first Navi did her character better because she's quiet and chill (and that was over 13 years ago with Persona 3 in 2008 on the mf PS2) so i have to mute the Voices entirely during bosses and Normal Combat making the cutscenes afterwards awkward til i finally get to actually open up the menu after 10 million cutscenes bringing my next issue being..

4. That i wish i wasn't bloated with cutscenes that last longer than the gameplay which completely ruins the pace during the jails when the game comes to a stop for just a cutscene of everyone standing still til i can move again, why not have them talk about it in the top right box while i move around, which is an ongoing issue that just gets tiring after the first jail but thankfully there's an option for me to skip cutscenes so I'm glad they put that lol.

4.5. The Second Hot Spring Scene is self-explanatory, just not really all that funny after Persona 3 since that had a fun minigame with it.

5. Why can i not move my camera as i am moving inside of a vent like in P5?

6. Why can i not see my Showtime gauge/bar like how HP, SP and Ammo are shown in the UI instead of hoping to god i get a showtime to do DMG/Knock Down Midbosses that are objectivelly harder than the main bosses

6.5 But it's Okay because nobody bothered to playtest Yusuke because he demolishes literally everything with his two hit combo no matter how strong the boss is to Physical

7. Istg i feel like the AI in this game is how people see the AI in Persona 3 but instead this is worse than that because you don't have a tactics menu to have some control of your party so that you tell what each Party Members does to prioritize for you instead of them going headfirst dive into a modboss/boss and die out of nowhere, or even use their SP for no reason when i don't want them to which connects to my previous second issue, the main healers/support not healing Futaba when i want those character specifically to focus on support.
It's a real shame because i'm minding my own business in combat to then just suddenly realize two of my characters died while all of them were together and i'm out of items to revive them back and lose the fight countless times because of it.

8. I don't know if it's because of the hardware I use since i own a Low End Laptop (little bit higher than the minimum requirements) o play games and play it on the lowest settings for it to run good ..but like, to my experience the game tends to softlock in the loading screen a couple of times especially when i go back in the Van so i have to press Alt + F4 to exit the game possibly losing a lot of progress that i haven't saved which is enfuriating since all the progress i made didn't matter because of this

Here's the Positive that i have to say about it for my own experience:

Overall my favourite parts about this game are the Combat (surprisingly after all i said), the two new characters: Sophia and Zenkichi, the Villains are sorta well better written with them having backstories instead of just being evil because they're a "nasty" adult and the god dang soundtrack, especially the ones in each area since to me they're overall the strongest part of this game making me not quitting or refunding it entirely, still pretty cool game i recommend a lot, not at full price because this doesn't deserve the $60 tag so get it during a sale

7/10

author: e4339384-a5b8-52af-82bd-cdc0a81b8c80
content:
tl:dr, combat's bad, story's bad, only bright spot is you get to see the P5 cast again.

Yeah I dunno what this "Musou" or "Dynasty Warriors" thing sparks in people, but it really does not mesh well with Persona's style. When you do an All-out attack or the screen says "Shows over" it's supposed to signify telling the enemy "smell ya later" in a flashy end to the fight. But here it takes maybe a centimeter off some midboss' interminable health bar? The best thing this game's combat does is make you appreciate how well designed the original P5's combat is. Not many people look or feel good frantically button-mashing into a huge dude. It's just awful; it's awkward, it's long, it's painful, it tests reflexes that you didn't need in P5, and you have to do way more of it than you did before because this is a much more fighty game.

Can't speak for later antagonists, but at least the first one is a complete writeoff. One of the things Persona games do brilliantly is encode a larger theme into the motivation for each foe. P5 is centered around rebellion, so that every boss feels almost cathartic to beat. P5S has, at least so far, just been "let's beat this person up because they're bad and we're good". There's no theme to this, and it makes the story feel way less fulfilling. The only thing I'm still here for is more of the main cast, and even then there are no bonding events so the interaction is superficial at best.

author: 6628de5d-162f-5bfc-8c97-42e0ddd10d89
content:
pros:
- very catchy music
- very fun and innovative game play
- diverse ways of managing fights
- the jails (dungeons) are very fun to explore. level design is great
- get to travel to many places that you don't get to in base P5
- decently challenging secret bosses for you to grind

cons:
- story is rather weak and fairly predictable compared to the base game or to royal
- not much character development except for the new characters introduced in P5S
- AI for your party members can be frustrating. Although AI in this game is already some of the better ones that I've seen, your teammates can still act like buffoons and get killed constantly by easily dodgeable attacks.

overall great game. The highlight of this game for me is gameplay, dungeon exploration and fight management (and music of course). Don't expect a great story and you'll enjoy this game a lot.

author: 197652ac-d2a4-5f38-805f-3a00301aa003
content: I'm not exactly the most professional person to give my opinion obviously, and especially not someone who's played a ton of Persona outside 5 and it's spin-offs. But I'd say that this was an extremely fun experience. The story isn't all that complex or thought provoking and can be a tad generic, or even rehashed from the original at times. But every area has a good message and consistently interesting dialogue between the party members. Like the original, the cast is great. And the two new additions to the crew are very much welcome. Then combat, much like the story, is pretty simple. Many of the mechanics are the same as far as weaknesses, and how buffs affect you and the enemy go. However this time it's put in an entirely different system. Ditching the turn based combat of the Persona series and making it a stylized and unique version of the Dynasty Warriors format. And with that in mind I can concede that it isn't for everyone. But in my personal opinion, the combat is fun, fast paced, and certain battles can genuinely feel grand. Notably the various boss fights. All the animations are very good and stay true to the style. Each character has their own personal tech and that gives them even more diversity than just simply different elements and basic attacks. All the showtime attacks look great as expected, and all out attacks are just as satisfying. I don't even NEED to get started on the music. Every track is just so amazing, and best of all you never have to hear the same track over and over since every battle is randomized. All the remixes are fantastic, and a personal favourite of mine is counterstrike. But on that note, I'll complete this miniature review. I'm yet to play New Game Plus, as I am writing this almost immediately after completing the main story. But I can only assume it'll add some bonus content that add a little more spice into a second playthrough. Thank you for reading, and I hope if you buy this game you enjoy it as much as I.

author: a2c9bb26-b789-5ee0-8f76-054a60a2487c
content:
Persona 5 Strikers is the summer vacation I never had. It functions as both a spin-off of a spin-off and a direct sequel to Persona 5. Therefore, I would highly recommend playing Persona 5 before diving into Strikers. Also, be sure to bring your PS4 controller for this one, as I felt the frantic combat feels significantly better on a controller.

Speaking of combat, it amazes me how well the flair and strategy of Persona combat mixes with the frantic, visually-busy Musou combat. The only other Musou game I've played is Hyrule warriors, yet I enjoyed the combat in this game much more. In fact,  it feels more like the combat in FFVII Remake. Button-mashing won't get you far; I had to turn down the difficulty to Easy until I was acclimated with the combat mechanics. Each character and Persona has their own combos, elemental affinities, and spells. Nothing makes me feel more like a badass than mowing down an army of Shadows with the power of friendship and the manifestations of your inner rebel. 

Moving on to the story, it parallels much of the narrative drawn in the original Persona 5. Without going into details, I will say that the first couple Jails serve to introduce you to the mechanics and lore of Jails. The monarchs of said jails are just one-and-done antagonists whose hearts you change. After this, the way the story ramps up parallels Persona 5 rather closely. It should be noted that the story is shorter (with regards to Persona standards). However, this is not an issue and I felt the pacing was actually well-done.

Music in the Persona series is nothing short of exceptional, and Strikers is no different. I did not think it was possible that "Rivers in the Desert" or "Blooming Villain" could be made any more epic than they already are. Later, you can even customize which songs play during battle.

The voice acting is stellar, including those of the new characters. Sophia is such sweetheart; her character growth is well written. As for Zenkichi, his character arc draws parallels to Dojima from P4. He and Sophia fit right into the Persona universe, unlike Lana in Hyrule Warriors, who seemed out-of-place.

With the amount of action going on, the game never dipped in framerate or crashed. One of my favorite changes involves NG+. You get all the characters and equipment from your first playthrough, unlike in P5 where you were limited to certain characters because of the story. It allows for ample time to customize and deck out all the Phantom Thieves with the best gear and moves. 

Overall, there is not much I disliked about the game. The damage sponginess of some of the bosses on the harder difficulties is a bit exasperating (and don't get me started on Merciless...). Nevertheless,  this is definitely worth a purchase if you liked Persona 5.

author: 89b4ee39-1ca2-5648-bc5e-2440bd141f4f
content:
TL,DR: It's not quite as good as the original game, but it's a spin-off, so what do you expect? The style is much more hack-and-slash and doesn't allow for nearly as much sneakery, but I still like it. I think it's easier than the og game, so if you want a challenge, you'll probably need to turn up the difficulty later on. The story is good, but could have benefited from a little more work. The game keeps crashing for me, and it got more frequent after I updated my computer, but I'm only passable with computers, so I don't know what to attribute that to. It could just be my computer, honestly.

Okay, so I really love the game, because I missed Persona 5 and wanted to play it again but I don't own it (I stayed with my cousin and played it while I was there) but recently, it's been crashing about every hour or so so I updated my computer to see if that would help, and it just made the crashes more frequent. Unfortunately, I'm no computer geek, so I have no idea what's going on or why and no way to figure it out because I'm scared of messing stuff up even more and also because I wouldn't know what I'm looking at. I can't tell if this is an issue with my computer, which is a zephyr gaming computer, I think, so it's fairly beefy compared to my old dell, or if it's an issue with the game. The game itself is very good if you're just looking for more Persona 5 content, but this game isn't in the same, turn-based style of gameplay, so be warned. It's a more of a battle royale with fewer options for sneaking around in the shadows. Personally, I've found it much easier than the original game and have turned it up to the hard difficulty, but I enjoy it nevertheless. I haven't finished the game yet, but I've found the story to be quite interesting. Not nearly as complex and planned out as the original game, mind you, but I wasn't expecting it to be perfect. I've been playing the game infrequently, so pardon my lapses in memory. The cooking mechanic is interesting, but they don't offer too many sp items for just one party member. There are several for full party, but the coffee beans needed to make Leblanc's coffee are offered very infrequently. I also feel like the areas you stay at get a little boring after a while, because it does take a good amount of time to beat a Jail (which is the Palace substitute. Jails are more for people with trauma who didn't deal with it in healthy ways and didn't get help, I think). Overall, I think it's a pretty good game with an interesting addition to the view of the Persona 5 Metaverse. It could use some work, but perfection isn't real or a healthy expectation to have. It's best enjoyed if you're just looking for something new to play once you've finished with Persona 5 and want a new story in the same universe. It does keep crashing, but I don't know if that's my computer or the game so I can't really comment on that.

author: 184661b3-8094-5f96-847e-080cf99489c4
content: First off, you will have to have beaten Persona 5 do its ending to understand this game. And that is not a game for the faint of heart, it requires a significant time investment. But damn, is it worth it. And this game stands on its own as a fantastic sequel and spinoff. It is the first truly great Dynasty-Warriors type spinoff I've ever played. All the others have ranged from bad-mediocre. But this game stands on the shoulders of Persona 5 and has a fantastic combat system, story, music, and characters. Only complaints are that the plot takes a little while to get on its feet, some predictability in the plot, the lack of exp for members not in your party leaving them underleveled whenever you want to change your party setup, and the relative simplicity of the individual characters' movesets when compared to other games of this type. Otherwise, a fantastic game. Totally reccomend.

author: 45c14914-998c-55bf-b48a-130229e819c2
content:
Last year, I told myself I wouldn't buy some crummy cash-grab spin-off of Persona 5. I hate nothing more than a series that doesn't know when to just move onto its next iteration in the franchise and instead milk a specific portion of it.

Enter Persona 5 Strikers. Bought on sale with an eye roll and wanting to kill some time before the release of Monster Hunter: Rise. I can safely say they did not skimp on the game by any means. More story for the characters you've gotten to know through Persona 5 (excluding Royale), and a great action-oriented game that manages to hold all sorts of wonderful story beats in the future for you.

Do yourself a favor, if you liked Persona 5 - give this a shot at least. It's good.

author: 43607be9-48fc-59f5-9ed3-fb21179bb1b3
content:
Context: I'm not a big JRPG player though I've played Scarlet Nexus (Kasane playthrough) and Tales of Arise (~50 hours in) and this is my first Persona game as I do not own a PlayStation X. 

Persona 5 Strikers is solid fun. The color design and overall aesthetic is exciting and engaging. The story, comic book-like dialogue and animated cut scenes all offer a solid story and presentation. 

The combat difficulty is very fair w/o being brain dead easy and manages to stay just "fresh" enough. The ability to play as different party members, use various Peronas, Showtime attacks and so forth keeps the gameplay engaging. 

The stealth mechanic + all out attack has gotten a little old at just 10 hours in. The story, overall game aesthetic and other combat mechanics help carry the game through this weakness.

If you have not played Persona 5 check out the P5 Plot synopsis on Wikipedia. This will allow you to better understand why the Phantom Thieves don't like the cops, what a Palace is, etc. With that background you will better appreciate the plot and story of P5S.

Overall I give this game an 8/10.

author: 096bb794-682d-518f-928d-fe47ca041bda
content:
Hello  there  ,  hope you are doing well  . I have finished the game but for some reason I forgot to write a review for this amazing game . So , let me begin by saying that if you haven't played Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal ,stay way  from this game at all costs  if you don't want your experience to be ruined (If you have specific questions about that ask  me in the comments and i will  try to explain  as much  spoiler free as possible) . Since  I am afraid that I might spoil  something and the fact that  English is not my mother tongue language , I will be short  :
Pros  : 
- Soundtrack :  Even though  this is a sequel/spin off and clearly I thought that the budget is gonna be less , I expected that  the quality  would not be as good as Persona 5/Royal , the game absolutely  destroyed my negative expectations . I can safely say that the quality of the different songs of  this game were on par with the soundtrackk of Persona 5 if not better . And  Lyn Inaizumi with her superb tone and really good control on the high notes, a great overall performance as always . Give her some love please on Twitter .
- Engine : I really don't know what Engine did they use on Persona 5 strikers but  the textures for characters ,objects,game terrain are light  years more clean than the  Persona 5 Royal (which have a slight upgrade on it's graphics in comparison with  the vanilla Persona 5) . And  even though this is anime or as some smart people like to say it ''a weeb'' game , the game looks soooooooo good in 4K  60 fps and everything  on the highest  settings to the  point that I could not believe it . 
-Gameplay: At first ,  when it first was announced for the Japanese market I thought that the gameplay will be  broken , poorly made or whatever you want to call . And I was sure (for some reason) that this type  of gameplay will absolutely not  fit well on a Persona game so decided to ignore it since I believed that it won't have a Western release . After some time when the game was announced for the West , I decided  to take the risk (due to my bias towards the Persona franchise and Atlus)  and preorder the digital deluxe . So the early access released  and  I started playing . Not only it is not boring  but it also has so many many creative mechanics that build on the Dynasty Warriors gameplay  formula and make it wayyyyy more fun  than I expected and it  felt so good using the different new  mechanics  .
-Story (SPOILER FREE) : Even though I have the bias i already mentioned above  ,  I never expected the story of this spin off (which also servers a sequel to Persona 5) to be so well crafted . Of course , not as big (that’s what she said) and good as the Persona but so much better than your everyday spinn off 
-Duration/NG+ : First of all , the playtime I currently have is not  accurate because I have spent  1-2 hours looking  at the preorder bonuses . Also this is the duration of my first playthough and I haven't started yet NG+ .  NG+  is neccessary if you want to earn al the achievements . I am the type of player that likes to look every nook and cranny of the game , unlock  all the abilities for the characters , do all the side quests first  and then start doing the main story to unlock new side quests (and repeat ) until I finish the game  . 
 Cons: 
The only  thing I didn't like was the epilogue(it was rushed in my opinion but it probably they didn't have the apropriate budget to make it  smoother , I can't be  sure )  and fact that [spoiler] you can predict after a certain point  in the main story who the main antagonist is so I wish they would have hidden this person  better but it didn't bother me that much . Don't make that stop you from buying it , it is just my personal whining [/spoiler]

Ooof , I wrote more than I expected . Before  I  leave please leave  a comment if you  have anything to ask before buying in the comments . Have a great day and stay safe !!!!!!

author: 1edf1e76-801f-53ba-8e81-26cbb6ce8b5d
content:
- The games is the sequel to Persona 5 / Persona Royal (both currently not available for PC)! (Why Atlus, release a sequel on PC without making the first game available prior to that?) The story therefore starts with all characters from the prequel already knowing each others and hints to the events of the prequel.

- There are no social links like in other Persona games.

+ The combat system is different from the rest of the Persona series (realtime and not turn based), but seems interesting enough at first glance.

- The soundtrack of the deluxe edition is not contained as seperate files, but rather a DRM protected software that allows you to listen to the music. Don't buy the deluxe edition for the soundtrack! It's a trap!

author: 859fb1ef-4640-5ab3-bd99-63c2e37bcc69
content: Satisfying continuation of Persona 5, that comes with everything you'd expect from a game that shares the "Persona 5" namesake. My only complaints with the gameplay were that it played more like a Platinum or Action RPG like the Tales of games instead of a Dynasty Warriors style of game. You're not quite chewing through hordes of grunt enemies effortlessly, but you're also not just focusing combos into a single enemy. It's a hybrid of the two that took a little adjusting to figure out, but the story was quite a trip (pun intended).

author: eae4342f-2d91-5e77-aae9-c1cf4d93598e
content:
this is a far superior game then the original persona 5 or royal's  dating sim that its based on, 

your going to want to swap out your party members since the sp items are not as forgiving as old persona neither is there some full hp and sp recovery thing thats given to you off the bat.

your gonna be swaping out teams while on the go , so get use to there move set. once all your team mates are low on sp thats perfect time to hop out the dungeon,with no morgana telling you its time to sleep joker  .

since you can switch out characters your not trusting the main character to be the problem solver for everything , his mainly to help clean out trash mobs and help with mini boss weakness but his not always going to have enough sp to 1 v 1 boss on his own .

depending on how much money you have you can make simple loop of deleting a high level persona ( letting it go outside the velvet room) to gain xp points for persona you want to focus on .

its got a bit of platforming .

having more then one bgm music helps with the grind .

its basically one piece dynasty warriors 1 fused with persona 5.

the main character choices are still hollow as they where in persona 5 choices  but this game manages to work on them being hollow choice by certain points your dialog will boost your team bonding meter ,this always the thoughtful choices set next 2 choices that are either yes or no or just state the obvious .

unlike in persona 5 , the main dungeon bosses arent just tanks with statues elements and useless stage gimmicks . they are a threat that you need take seriously since there 10 levels above your highest persona . the game will give you a heads up on who to use for the boss fights by simple having that part member interacting with bosses in real life , then you know who else to bring along since persona 5 has techactial element combos  like ice and nuke,fire and wind, fear and psychic . and stage elements that are effective at stopping the boss pattern but might be a 1 time use so you have to be careful (unless your twice as strong as the boss ) 

the arcanas takes a heavy back seat in the game since its not focused on a dating sim but simple these characters spending time with each other .

its best to pace your self with it since your still have to grind with the party .

characters state something that said in a cutscenes is actually useful here if you cant play the movies or just want them off.

they dont hide the best conversions with your team mates on the phone like in persona 5. it simple used as a story based only tool for meeting up .

the only con are : 
 when coming out of battle your in fight mode still, so you have to hide instead of trying to ambush the next enemy whose not interact able until the xp screen goes away. so the enemy could get the jump on you if your not careful .

author: 60adfbcf-cf2c-58f5-8541-e5155fbd5d97
content:
An excellent balance between classic Persona gameplay, and hack-and-slash madness.

I'll won't deny in saying that I never actually played the original Persona 5/Royal, having only watched my friend stream the game. But I can still say with certainty that the flair, writing, and characters feel straight out of the main game. While this may be labeled as a "Spinoff", it is just as much a true sequel to the original Persona 5. (Not Royal.)

Despite being seen as a "Warriors" spinoff of sorts like other series received (Such as Hyrule Warriors or Fire Emblem Warriors), Strikers keeps many of the aspects that make the Warriors games have their flair and charm, while also keeping many story and gameplay aspects that make it feel like a true Persona game as well. The use of skills, weakness exploitation, and even Joker's Wild Card ability are all present, and translated faithfully in the newer hack-and-slash gameplay style. While at the same time still feeling like a dedicated RPG. I'm honestly impressed how well they kept the feel of Persona in the gameplay, not making it feel too alienated as a sequel to P5. (Unlike with my experience with games like Hyrule Warriors, which feels like a Warriors game, but with Zelda characters slapped onto it.) Even so; the gameplay is still very different from regular Persona. It just is faithful in carrying over a lot of signature aspects of the series.

And as for the story; I really enjoyed it as well. I won't go into many details, but I can still say for certain that it feels like a natural progression from the ending of Persona 5.
The characters all feel the same, they all keep their original voices, and some characters who may have been lacking in P5 got more development and purpose in Strikers. (Primarily with Haru.)
Even though there are no longer any social aspects in Strikers, the writing and character interactions still feel like what you'd see in regular Persona, albeit a bit more linear. Which honestly; I don't have a problem with.
I also really enjoyed the new characters added to the game, especially Zenkichi.

All-in-all, P5 Strikers is a fantastic game, especially if you're a fan of P5 already.
My only gripe is that due to being a sequel to P5, you kinda need to see the story of the base game's True Ending to understand a lot of points covered in the story of Strikers. But at the same time; if your there just for the gameplay and not so much the story (Or you just don't mind spoilers), then the game itself has its own content and story to look forward to. Even if you may not pick up on all the references made to the previous game.

Even still; I highly recommend this game. Truly a real treat for me to play this year

author: 3e5e3e0c-a538-5a05-9053-ea3baad93d3a
content:
Great stuff, but you should really play (and like) Persona 5 first. Everything except combat is more of the same in a very good way, fresh and new but familiar. 

Combat is a whole different beast, and while I thought it was pretty shaky at first, I grew to very much enjoy it a couple of levels in. It's reminiscent of a Dynasty Warriors style brawler, but most fights with masses of enemies are very short. Bosses are considerably more durable, and will mash you if you only swing mindlessly. Personally I blew through the early fights until I hit the first real boss, died enough times in a row that the game recommended I switch to easy difficulty (not happening), and went back to the tutorials to really learn all the mechanics. Started having a blast shortly after that.

Characters are charming and engaging, but it does have the hallmark cringe perv scenes endemic to anime (not egregious, but in poor taste).

author: aaba5f8f-c332-5416-b6f0-44486f87d975
content:
Atlus knows how to milk a franchise really well. Instead of creating dairy products that becomes expired even before they are shipped, they ensure that all of their cows are in good health alongside carrying out daily inspections and QC procedures on their machines before doing anything. Almost every single one of their spin offs are made with love and care. 

That includes Persona 5 Strikers. The turn-based + musou hybrid is what I would like to see in future musou games. Although the combos provided for each character are less varied, it does not overstay its welcome as they are also numerous persona skills that we can use to defeat a horde of enemies. On top of that, by utilizing the baton pass from P5, we can control 4 different characters in a single map. Something that most musou titles lack. In addition, the game includes two new playable characters. An AI girl named Sophia and another one which I am not going to mention the name to avoid spoiler territory. Trust me, they fit so well in the phantom thieves gang and each of them will receive their own spotlights they deserve. 

AN IMPORTANT NOTE: 

Do not play this game, if you have not yet play the mainline game or at least watch a walkthrough on youtube. Bits of the plot from P5 will be mentioned a few times so proceed with caution. 

If you love persona 5, then you will surely going to like strikers as well, Don't let the musou tag turn you off, the combat feels natural and not overly repetitive like the traditional musou games. Of course, it depends on peoples' preferences at the end of the day. As expected from Atlus, their remarkable assortment of musical pieces are unique, memorable and well-composed as always. For those who want a fairly lengthy JRPG, then persona 5 strikers is perfect for you too judging by the total amount of hours I spent to complete all 50 side quests which will appear as an achievement if you manage to unlock it + beating the main story. 

*CUTE AI GIRL GO BRRR*

author: 0b457106-56d2-5ba5-bbd4-ae1dd5641d5e
content:
This is definitely for fans of Persona 5. The Musou style combat takes a lot of getting used to, weather or not you're accustomed to Dynasty Warriors or not, it's pretty different, and I had to change the difficulty to Easy until I got the hang of things and then reset it to Normal. 

It has some clunkiness, but the story will keep you going if you liked P5. This is a direct sequel, so definitely play this for the story if nothing else.

Being an action game, you control each Phantom Thief individually, and can freely switch between them. they all fight quite differently and have their own combos/specials, and you'll most likely find one or two that you like and stick with them for most of the game.

You still obtain Personas and Joker can equip/fuse them etc in the Velvet room. But with so many characters to play as (8 other than Joker) I barely found any use in directly controlling Joker. Why use a fire based Persona when Ann can already use fire spells and use her fire whip moves that cost no SP? And same with each other Phantom Thief with their respective elemental spells. It made sense in a turn-based RPG like the original  P5, but here you can just hack/slash/spell cast to your hearts content.

All in all a fun, mindless game that honestly needs tweaking in the combat department, but I'd still recommend this to fans of P5 for the story, and to see these beloved characters return in a new setting.

author: 5e10822d-ada8-5271-ab88-6276a9740fd0
content:
It's hard to say this as Persona 5 and Persona 4 are some of my favourite games of all time, but this game has some below average gameplay. Boss fights can drag on and fights with random enemies are either frustrating or too easy. It seems like I spend most of my time spamming shoot rather than pulling off combos and using magic because enemies do too much damage. SP is much better spent using healing spells rather than elemental or buff / debuff spells because damage is so high. You can use other characters, but why would you when Joker is the best one to be using. Maybe it's because is just came off playing the One Piece Pirate Warriors series but the lack of variety during combat drags this game down. Usually your combo is 1,1,1,2 or 1,1,1,1,1,2,2 (1 being a light attack and 2 being a heavy attack), because those combos use your equipped persona's element (which means you don't have to spend precious SP on offensive magic to hit weaknesses). 

The Velvet Room and persona fusion are cut down and almost a waste of time in this game. You cannot just fuse any two personas anymore. There are set combinations you can use. This is sad because this is what originally drew me to the Persona series in the first place. 

However, combat and the Velvet Room are the only bad things about this game. Just like Persona 5, the UI and design elements to this game are fantastic. Seeing your equipped persona in the bottom left of the screen always looks cool because there is a unique portrait there for every persona. Menu transitions don't get in the way too much and are worth the time they use. 

The main characters are just as I knew them in Persona 5 (with the disappointing lack of Dr. Maruki and Sumi from the Royal version of the game). Yusuke still makes me laugh. Ryuji is still endearingly dumb. Haru gets more screen time (thank god) and Makoto is still best girl. The new characters Sophia and Mr. Bloodborne (forgot his actual name) are lovely and fit in very well with the main group, with Sophia genuinely being my fourth favourite character (behind Yusuke, Makoto and Haru).

Take this review lightly, as I've only beaten the 2nd Palace and I'm working through the 3rd one right now. I just wanted to write down my feelings on this game so far.

author: 3ef197f3-15ce-5bd6-8fc4-25a87db34d21
content:
I am making an edit to my review because I said I wanted a mainline title with this game-play. While this game is fun, there are a few caveats:

* No matter what character you use, combat gets somewhat repetitive after a while. 

* This game is surprisingly long (at least, in my opinion).

* If you want more enjoyment out of the story, you need to have played any version of Persona 5 first.

However, this game has plenty of positives to warrant buying:

* Awesome soundtrack.

* Graphics are fantastic.

* Fantastic boss designs.

* RPG elements present (sort of like Final Fantasy 7 Remake).

* And many more to discover for yourself!


TLDR: A good game with shortcomings.

author: 0e883649-484d-575f-9961-e70dcc0f2245
content:
While this game's combat mechanics are fun and fresh in their divergence from Persona's normal turn-based gameplay, the story (while it has its moments) is a boring retread of material from past Persona games, and apart from the fanservice for players of Persona 5 I can't recommend this game on the merits of its narrative. The character of Sophie and her story arc is basically a recycling of Aigis from Persona 3; Zenkichi is just Dojima from Persona 4, the reprisal of the Persona 3/4 hot springs scene (they are all the same scene) is unnecessary, unfunny, and tired. etc.

I'm a pretty big Persona fan, and I've enjoyed this game. Its story is serviceable, not embarrassingly bad or even unenjoyable. But if you have played a Persona game, and especially if you have played Persona 3 and 5, you have played this game. The only difference is the gameplay, which, again, is still fun. I do appreciate them cutting the social links/calendar bullshit, because that was never really used well in past games, but there is still far too much busywork in between the dungeon crawling and combat

The PC port is fine, at least as far as I've found. It's only crashed a few times for me. But ymmv i guess

Haru also continues to be good.

[b]tldr; good combat, boring recycled story, slightly unstable port. play if you really need that much more persona in your veins, probably buy on a sale, don't expect too much. 3/5 - decent.[/b]

author: 019946ba-0457-5492-9afd-ead277d3903a
content:
Persona 5 Strikers is an excellent spin-off of Persona 5 and an overall fantastic Musou game. Based on vanilla P5, it leaves out  the new stories from Royal. It's unfortunate, but the new ideas they bring are really great, one of the new characters is really compelling and an excellent addition to the cast. It's definitely a game I'd recommend to anyone who enjoyed Persona 5. It's a fun continuation with a good story and the Phantom Thieves hanging out and travelling across Japan. This might seem obvious, but if you weren't a fan of P5 then this game won't do much for you. Long stretches of cutscenes and characters the game expects you to be familiar with won't be too appealing if you haven't been sucked into the world of P5. Only other major complaint is the post-game, or lack thereof. It's disappointing, especially for a Musou game that can usually have you spend over 100 hours trying to complete the various missions. 

Overall though, like I said, Persona 5 Strikers is an excellent game and one that any fan of Persona 5 should play.

author: b3e5d890-c141-5d0c-b89b-751a7b5e7fa2
content:
I loved the regular persona 5, I played it and immediately found myself sucked in by its atmosphere, music, and general ascetic, and had a genuinely great time through the obsession amount of time I spent with it. The characters were all very likable and made you want to spend as much time with them doing meaningless shenanigans with them and wishing you could have had more of them at the end of the game which is what strikers manages manages give you in spades as the game is essentially you and your mates go on a road trip and just get into random shenanigans which is just generally enjoyable.

Along with that this game's combat system is one that manages to be very fast paced and mobile while still maintaining the style and feel that p5 had, overall being honestly more enjoyable to spend time with as it manages not to get repetitive overtime and maintains the vibrant and fast paced feel that it has when you first experience it which is all enhanced by the soundtrack that fits the the designs of the areas they accompany or make you feel invincible as you go through waves of enemies.

All and all I had a blast with this game and would recommend it to anyone who is willing to pick it up.

author: 068934f2-8352-5bda-b319-45c28b4f64b0
content: I was wary of P5S considering I haven't had a great experience with [i]Warriors[/i]-style games in the past, but I'm happy to report that there's far more [i]Persona[/i] here than [i]Warriors[/i]. Additionally, since the game takes place on the road over a short time period with characters you already know, the time management and social links have been replaced by bond skills, which are much simpler and a bit less satisfying. Despite these huge changes to the formula, [i]Strikers[/i] manages to strongly hold on to it's [i]Persona[/i] identity. [i]Persona 5 Strikers[/i] is both a worthy sequel and a blast in it's own right, and I enthusiastically recommend it to anyone who enjoyed P5, and probably to any hack'n'slash/jrpg/arpg fans too. Now if only it's predecessor was available on PC...

author: bb5a65aa-f43f-5f2a-bd3e-fc7aa032f555
content:
Persona 5 Strikers is like what Age of Calamity was for Breath of the Wild: A must-have experience for fans

The whole game feels more like a Persona game than a Warriors one, and the mechanics that Persona fans are familiar with, such as fusing, were greatly improved from even Persona 5 Royal. The things that were changed and made to be different to reflect upon its direction, such as the combat, is incredibly fun, rewards skill, and is something I found myself enjoying over the original turn-based formula that the Persona series is known for.

If you're looking for a less time-consuming Persona experience with a greater development into its combat than with time management around tasks and social links, then this should be up your alley. Despite the feeling of being a Persona-lite title, its gameplay loop is meaty and offers an incentive for fighting battles for stat boosters and a constant means of getting stronger. I'm playing NG+ on the hardest difficulty, and it's still feeling adequately challenging enough to keep me on my toes despite having Personas that would make the previous games into a laughing stock.

If you're unsure about getting it at full price, then be sure to pick it up when it's on a sale. You won't regret it. The Digital Deluxe Edition is worth it for the little extras especially the legacy BGM tracks.

author: 84592481-4a70-5238-aff3-de26caf678f3
content:
10/10 game, now keep it up and bring the rest of the Persona franchise to PC.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

Persona 5 Strikers is a step in a brand new direction for the entire Persona franchise, yet entirely fits all of the knowledge we currently have on the series. Every single translation of a skill from the JRPG format to the Dynasty Warriors format makes complete sense. The combat system feels incredible and flows perfectly with the styles of all of the Phantom Thieves, each of the Thieves' fighting style perfectly matching their character. The game also encourages you to use all of the Phantom Thieves (and no spoilers, you should it helps later on), beyond just using them to hit weaknesses.  The game may feel difficult, as bosses can have an insane amount of health if you don't have maxed equipment or the best Personas, but remember that the game encourages you to spend a lot of time in the Jails and that unlike the original Persona 5/Persona 5 Royal: [b]You can re-enter a Jail as many times as you want on a single day, refreshing your HP/SP every single time.[/b]

[h1]Story/Characters[/h1]

The story is entertaining, and the new characters are welcome additions to the Persona 5 cast. The new Phantom Thieves fit incredibly well with the others, and their additions to the cast prove that it's not just high school kids who can change reality. There's a good balance of comedy relief with serious plot points, and the game knows when to take itself in either direction. Without spoilers, the late-game stuff can get incredibly emotional if you're invested, and again fits with the rest of the series while trying something new. 

[h1]Voice Actors/Thank You[/h1]

The best part of this game is the English VA's. You can tell that every single one of them was having a blast in the recording studio, and became the Phantom Thieves [sttrike]more than any cringy fan on social media ever could[/strike]. It wasn't as obvious to me in Persona 5/Royal, but in this game it was clear that every single voice actor was having a blast and completely invested in their characters, which was something that couldn't necessarily be given during a first game in a series like P5/P5R. As the characters grew, so did the VA's and it really showed in this game. To the English Cast, thank you for an incredible performance, and can't wait for the next one.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

All in all, wait for P5/P5R to come out on PC if you haven't played them already, or play it on PS4 since it's out there now. Persona 5 Strikers was an incredible experience that I can't wait to play over and over again to 100% and the point where I have every Persona completely maxed out. I'm incredibly happy to see that ATLUS doesn't need to make a JRPG to have an incredible entry into the Persona franchise.

author: 1071465d-9557-5743-8a9b-8a0be5b54a66
content: If you're a fan of Persona 5 (don't play this if you haven't played the original Persona 5 or Royal) then you will definitely like this. A chance to see what happens after the events of the main game and an opportunity to go on another mission that expands the wold of the original. The new battle system is top-notch, and resembles the action-oriented battles of Final Fantasy VII Remake. Honestly, I would love if Persona 6 had a more refined version of the battle system in this game. It is so much fun to see the Phantom Thieves move about as they do in the cutscenes of the original game, but this time you're in control. The fusion system has been further simplified in service of removing many hard annoyances, but with the tradeoff of reduced Persona count. I would love to see a sequel to this game with a few small things changed, but as it stands I can heartily recommend this entry.

author: 5092e295-e81d-53eb-bae6-a88c1d2cce86
content:
A very impressive and unique to the incredibly popular Persona 5. Initially seeing that it was being developed by Omega Force kinda put me on guard as I've never been a big fan of the Warriors series of games, but I was still curious. Turns out that this is probably my favorite of their games. Gameplay is a surprising blend of those Warrior games (fight huge swathes of enemies who might throw in a few hits here and there) and Persona's weakness/resistance system. You have your basic combos that develop as you play each of the characters and you can bust out their Persona to do attacks that enemies are susceptible to, to knock 'em down and do an ALL OUT ATTACK that does huge damage to every enemy around. Each character has their own combo strings and variants that they learn as you play as them, so each one feels unique to each other, so try each one and they might fit your play style better than another, aside from worrying about weaknesses.

Presentation is great, aside from some minor jagged edge problems that you can fix if you look up how (I've forgotten how exactly, it's been a while, but it also made everything else a tad funky). The stylization of characters and the world is still spot on to Persona 5 (no surprise), runs mostly well and of course the music is still S-tier at worst. You'll definitely have new favorites after playing through this.

The story and new characters are also pretty solid! I love both Sophie and Zenkichi, they're colorful additions that don't feel out of place with the core cast at all. They're well fleshed-out on top of the main P5 cast getting some more time that they hadn't before and also allowed for some more interactions among each of them. Only issue is that some of the villains of each new zone you get to explore aren't as fleshed out. One being familiar with a teammate and you don't really get much more than "I thought you were good before, but now this happened and you're bad." to "Ah, sorry about the sudden bad. We cool now?" and then you leave. I mean you learn more than that, obviously, but it doesn't hit as strongly as some other characters developments. And those who played any spinoffs or the Royal version: it's focused on Persona 5. Old character portraits are used as opposed to the refreshed ones in Royal, Sumi doesn't exist in this timeline and neither does all the Royal specific changes to the story. Gonna miss Sumi, she was great and hope they push her in likely spinoffs, along with Zenkichi and Sophie but we'll see as unlikely as it is.

All in all, absolutely loved this game so much so I 100% it. A bit easier to do than core Persona 5, and on par with Persona 5 Royal. If you've played Persona 5 and loved it, absolutely hop onto this game. If you've played Persona 5 Royal and loved that, you'll be a bit saddened or confused, if that's the only version you played. Either way, it's excellent!

(PS, IF YOU'RE STRUGGLING: RYUJI IS A POWERHOUSE, UTILIZE PLAYING AS HIM.)

author: e8f6c7e1-801b-5083-9646-4c11737ef7b7
content:
สำหรับใครที่ยังไม่เคยเล่นภาค5หรือภาค5Royalแนะนำให้ไปหามาเล่นหรือไปดูสรุปเนื้อเรื่องมาก่อนครับ มีหลายจุดที่ใช้อ้างอิงเนื้อเรื่องภาคนี้ค่อนข้างเยอะ
- Gameplay
ภาคนี้เป็นจะเปลี่ยนรูปแบบการเล่นต่างไปจากเดิมนะครับจากเทิร์นเบสไปเป็นมุโซ รูปแบบการเล่นถือว่าค่อนข้างซ้ำซากมากแต่ก็ยังสนุกอยู่และจะไม่มีระบบค่าความสัมพันธ์แบบภาค5หรือ5Royalแล้วจะเปลี่ยนเป็นค่าความสัมพันธ์ของกลุ่มแทน ระบบผสมเพอโซน่าไม่ค่อยมีอิสระเท่าไหร่ ฟาร์มเวลยากกว่าภาคที่แล้ว
- Graphics
มันคือภาค5Royalอัพเกรดครับ
- Story
เนื้อเรื่องต่อจากภาค5นะครับไม่ใช่5Royal ใครชอบแนวดราม่าครอบครัวกับจิตใจมนุษย์ไม่ควรพลาดครับ พูดเยอะกว่านี้ไม่ได้เดี๋ยวสปอย
- Art & Level design
บอสภาคนี้ทำออกมาดีใช้ได้เลยครับ การดีไซน์ฉากทำออกมาโอเคไม่แย่ พัซเซิลน้อยไปหน่อย
สรุปเลยละกัน สำหรรับใครไม่เคยเล่นภาค5หรือไม่คิดที่จะเล่นแล้วอยากจะเล่นภาคนี้แนะนำให้รอลดราคา แต่ถ้าใครเป็นแฟนเกมซีรี่ย์นี้ไม่ควรพลาดครับ"ต้องซื้อ"

content:
this game is good ol persona 5 goodness and the best muso game out there. the combat is basic muso press attack and combo into special. each characters moves and animations are true to the characters and they all have their own little changes from the others. the persona abilities stop time so you can  choose what skill to use and where to drop it. they even added to sneak attack into the game so you can get the advantage on the enemy. each character get a special showtime attack thats basically a super, you fill the meter and hit them with the showtime. you are able to hold on to it as long as you want until you leave the dungeon. all in all this game is alot of fun and i highly recommend if you are a persona 5 fan. damn this game is good.

p.s. Makoto is still best girl.

content: With the updates the game has become silky smooth at max settings 4k ( previously it was unplayable on my 2080 even at 1080p in anything but low settings) Now that's 120+ fps i can finally play the game and after an hour i can say its a perfect mix of JRPG and Warriors formula game-play. This might be the entry persona game for players that dont like turn based rpgs but are curious about the persona subverse. Still as an avid Turn based rpg lover I think the pauses for menus and skill usage makes this game keep the charm of turn based rpgs while using action combat. Id give this game a 8 out of 10 as of now.

author: 67115d4f-6be8-535a-926b-eb1ddf07651b
content:
Pros:
- Much needed sequel to the original Persona 5 game!
- Haru gets screen time!
- Fun combat gameplay
- Several Personas to collect and use in battle
- Able to romance the Fluffy Gardener!
- Amazing remixes from the original Persona 5 game!
- You can play as the Harytolagus Okukimongus!
- Unlockable Master Skills for each character.
- Did I mention there's a lovable Floofy girl in this game?

Cons:
- Game is a lot shorter than original Persona 5
- Not a sequel to Persona 5 Royal
- No Akechi or Kasumi

Overall:
- Buy this if you love Persona 5!
- Haru is best girl!
- GOTY 2021!

author: a3388371-398c-57ae-9be5-ee3afb43cc89
content: If you like the "Warriors" games (like Dynasty or Hyrule) and you like the original Persona 5, this is a brilliant sequel. With the best parts from both series, some of which was changed to flow better with the other, the gameplay is excellent. Things to be wary of. Although it seems as if the story is just Persona 5 again, it isn't. Although it does tread over similar ground, the wholly unique aspects and new characters like Zenkichi make up for it. Also, on PC there's a slight chance of infinite load times. That being said however, I personally only encountered it once, so as long as you save frequently (mainly before major events) it isn't a hassle.

author: c7fcfac0-fb9c-5965-935b-b458b26f91c9
content:
It's great to see a Persona game are finally on PC, a huge leap for sure for the direction of the game in the future. The game have some a the greatest soundtrack in a Persona game I have the chances to listen too, they really capture the essence of Persona 5 and brought it forward in this one.

It's also a Great Musou type game which I honestly don't play a lot of but still manage to have fun while playing so. The combination of easy control, fast-paced gameplay,flashy combos and finisher really make the game enjoyable. Well at least for me a Persona fan.

All and all this is just a nice Musou type game with P5 aesthetic slap on top of it, I can guaranteed that you will have fun playing this game.

author: 35fd71ff-b5f8-58d8-b351-00b2292fe39a
content:
Let's be real, it's Persona 5. Anyone who knows me knows I love this installation in the series, and to have a direct sequel to the events of the game is just quite golden. I'm not nearly done with the game, but I've got enough time here to say that I'm pleased with how well this was made.

I never expected that nearly every aspect of the game would be improved upon. The story is rich and drives in more development for the characters, songs have either been remixed and remastered to fit the action style (and nearly all of the new songs added are complete bops), and the style seen in P5 has been expanded upon and grown to a massive scale.

There are only a couple gripes I have. Very minor, but as it affects the gameplay itself, it feels rather sad to mention. I play this game for the story and music, but the gameplay was never all that engaging to me. Each of the fights had meperforming the same tactics, only changed by which boss I was going to face next. The bosses in this game are juggernauts, and it feels like they were only padded out just so that the in-fight dialogue could be heard. It just felt like there was too much health, and sometimes there were some really messed up moments between the AI and the bosses that just left you with almost nothing you could do (Hyodo without any tables left is a notable jerk that's for sure).

Overall I enjoyed it, though. Still trying to get through merciless mode, which is its own can of worms, but I still quite enjoy it.

author: 49eb448a-8d0b-5c79-9e69-6ba895a734d8
content:
If you are a fan of Persona games, pick this up! Does not have all the "slice of life" activities that Persona game's are famous for, but is still story rich. New character "Humanity's Companion" is cute as F***. Not recommended for those just looking for a new hack n' slash, a lot of dialogue disrupts the pacing. Fans are used to it, you have been warned.

Pros------------------------

-Unique Mushou combat experience with Persona 5 theme. All out attacks, Persona System

-Story picks up after events of Persona 5 after one year

-Music is great

-English Va's put on a great performance (subjective I understand)

-Japanese voices are optional if you are not into English dubs 

-New Baddies (I have only fought the first boss so far) 

-Checkpoints are placed pretty well and makes re-entry less of a hassle taking out a lot of backtracking.

-Humanity's Companion > Siri

-Ambushing shadows feels great

Cons-------------------------

- Camera can be wacky

- Game is not good for players who have not played the original. No backstory, no summary of events, no recap of the original game whatsoever. 

- If you have not played the original, you will not be used to dialogue. There is a TON of dialogue. Great if you are a fan, annoying if you are new to the series or are just looking for a hack n' slash.

- Most of the characters you bonded with in last game are MIA if they were not the main cast. Doctor, where you be? :<

- "Stealth"    Yeah, it's pretty whack.

author: 739fc5ec-7ed6-5131-bf56-ecc45ce1935c
content:
P5S is a fun follow-up to P5/P5R in the form of a 3D beat-em-up. Giant waves of enemies come at you and there's occasionally a boss who does big damage yet can be stunned for your own big damage if you hit it's weakness enough. Sounds like Persona/SMT gameplay in an action environment? You'd be correct.

There's balance issues with characters strengths and weaknesses but it never forces you into a unwinnable situation; plus the balance between Persona elements and beat-em-up elements was more important and they succeeded there. You have to keep an eye on your skills mostly for stronger enemies and to improve combos but if you're exceedingly talented at these kinds of games you could ignore it...but the system is fun so there's no reason to. The story is a bit shallow with our returning cast while the new faces (at least the good guys) get character development that's pretty logical and nice, but it probably won't leave the biggest impression on you. It's moreso a reason to see Ren, Ryuji, Yusuke, Makoto, Futaba etc. again and get what would be confidant cut-scenes in P5 but stretched through the whole game. The game is  gorgeous and despite it being frantic I would stop after clearing an area to look around. I was worried when the characters looked a little off when it was revealed but they look fine in-game alongside the demons and levels you'll explore.

It's a fun sequel that doesn't push the envelope outside of introducing RPG menus and abilities to Samurai Warriors like gameplay. If you like Persona 5 it's a great. simple and significantly shorter. It allows extra time with the Phantom Thieves too, especially Haru! and don't worry - one thief won't take up a ton of the main plot this time. Makoto, I'm staring lazers at you. Gameplay design also feels similar despite the new combat style as managing your abilities before heading into a jail is where the real challenge comes in and then using those abilities sparingly. It's fun and enjoyable, do consider getting it!

If you don't like P5...you'll think it's pretty I guess. It's another warriors game with the ability to do an attack from a menu that does more damage. I do think unless you are *really* into the game's art style, you could do better with other games on Steam.

First things first this game is not a sequel to be taken lightly and is far from shallow or "easy going" compared to the original game as claimed by some reviewers. The rest of the Persona spin-off titles pale in comparison to this masterpiece truly worthy of the Persona title. I wouldn't even call this a spin-off but this is a true sequel in my books.

The games "social" system might not be as deep as in the original game but for what it's worth it does its job well letting you do optional quests for your companions and encounter in optional dialouge during your spare time and you'll be constantly interacting with you companions throughout the story.

If you have played the original Persona 5 Game this is a must play. A true masterpiece with a deep plot and good mechanics

overview:
+ Deep and well crafted engaging plot that is simply outstanding
+ Combat is very fun and at times very engaging
+ Persona Creation and modification feature is well crafted and goes as deep as you're willing to go
+ Atmosphere and environments are outstanding
+ soundtrack is excellent
+ Character encounters throughout the game are enchanting and deep
