author: a323e042-f92b-58dc-ba37-f6dcf6dec4de
content:
PREAMBLE:
I Don't think I can judge this game fairly. I Really did not like persona 5, neither it's main story or it's characters. All the problems I had with 5 are pretty much absent here. They don't gripe about adults every 5 minutes, they don't complain about society every 2 minutes and they also don't talk about how much better they are than everybody every second. I don't know if this game is great or if my low expectations after P5 make it seem great, but I do know that I want the combat and the writers back for Persona 6. 

GAMEPLAY:
Unlike P5, this game has active real-time combat as opposed to turn based combat. P5 tried to ad flair and look cool but it fell flat because the characters ended up just standing still and taking turns in combat. The sense of progression and picking the right persona for the job is still here, but with combat that seems to fit the story better. You have basic attacks. You have special persona attacks you can weave in with the basic attacks, and you have your normal persona abilities you know from the mainline series separate from that. This is what persona 5 tried and failed to make you feel, strong and powerful in the face of an army. There are also no more punishments and subsequent incentives to finish a jail in one day. No more time management YAY :D Time management was my biggest gripe with P3-P5, but it's not here.

STORY:
Do you want to go on a cross country summer tip with your friends? me too :,( This is just a group of friends doing exactly that, kinda. Saying it's a rehash of P5's story would be a disservice, but it really does feel like the writers saw the potential in it's story and rebuilt it from the ground up. No more cartoonishly evil villains. All of your "enemies" are all shown to have suffered greatly and as a result their desires have been twisted. In P5 they were "twisted" because the story demanded it. No more "I know whats best for society" main-characters. In P5 they were pretty much just like the main villain, but were never called out on it or made to think about it.
 [spoiler] The main "villain" this time is actually just the Phantom thieves, but on a much larger scale. He points out that they can't help everyone, that even now while they are talking people are suffering. He want's to become a hero for everyone, to help everyone the phantom thieves can't. His way of doing it is to basically brainwash people, and remove freedom entirely (just like the phantom thieves can be argued are doing to their targets) and when it is pointed out to him that he is basically erasing peoples humanity and becoming like the figure who traumatized him he relents. I am a bit sad that no one pointed out to him that he was punishing the innocent majority for crimes committed by the guilty minority, especially since there was a cop there, but compared to P5 it is flawless. [/spoiler] 
The characters never stop interacting with each other, so it really does feel like a friends group out on a trip. P5 did little to make them actually seem like friends that would hang out outside of Phantom thieves business, and while this does little to remedy that, it does pair all of them off to some degree. So while they may not keep contact with everyone, they will at least keep in contact with someone. I can see Ryuji and Yuskuke, Futaba and Yusuke, Ryuji and Ann, Makoto and Haru. Just like a real friends group, some of them seem to hit it off better than others. This felt lacking in P5, but there were at least more contained single stories I suppose.

MUSIC:
Yeah, it's pretty good. Some remixes from P5 to make them fit better with the real-time action combat. The jails all have personal BGM as you are walking around just like P5. The first jail has an absolute banger of a track, while the others do their job of building atmosphere well enough. The last one can be argued is alright. The battle music really gets the blood pumping and get you ready for a fight. It makes what happens on screen just feel that more sick. If you bought the battle tracks from the other persona games as well, then you get a good amount of music to make sure you never really tire of any one of them. 

FINAL RATING:
Standing on it's own: ?/10
Compared to P5: 11/10

author: 031a4d2e-48c4-5682-8ea5-1f544e72ab54
content:
The best Persona spin-off, the best licensed Musou game and a fantastic hack and slash. 

KT, Omega Force and Atlus did an amazing job in striking the perfect balance between mainline Persona's RPG elements and the action gameplay of the Musou series. 

Storywise, the game follows vanilla P5's ending and allows us to see more interaction between the Phantom Thieves as they travel around Japan for their summer vacation. Writing is expectedly weaker than the main game (as is with Persona spin offs), but the new characters and group interactions pretty much make up for it. I'm not afraid to say Zenkichi is one of the best Persona characters and he carried the whole game. Sorry, it's the truth.

Moving on to the gameplay, back when this game was announced, a lot of people were expecting this to be another mindless button masher like a lot of the licensed Musou games are, but P5S is far from that. Battling enemies incorporates P5's dungeon exploration mechanics to present smaller (when compared to a normal musou) but still fast paced encounters between big numbers of enemies. The addition of elemental magic, buffs and debuffs from the turn based games grants the gameplay a new layer of depth and more ways to deal with enemies other than melee attacks. There is some grind, but it never feels like a chore because the combat is really addictive and super fun.

As for the rest of the game's elements: amazing soundtrack (as is to be expected from Meguro) and vibrant and stylish UI and overall presentation. My only complaint is that the antialiasing implementation is terrible and if you don't force it with external tools, the game will look blurry and ugly. The port had some serious issues when it came out but most of them seem to have been fixed with the latest patches.

So, all in all, this is an amazing game. Bit of a hard sell to people who didn't play the original but for those who know what they're getting into, this will be one of the best experiences in the Persona series. Absolutely recommended.

author: 03ab9a58-c08a-5504-81bf-ca5a97394cc6
content:
Persona 5 Strikers is a great game for the fans of the original Persona 5 game (and Royal). It is a sequel, so prior knowledge of Persona 5 is required to get the full experience. Of course, you could still play the game as is, but be warned that there are a few spoilers here and there so I would advise against it.

Gameplay wise, it is different from the traditional turn based style the Persona series is known for, that being Persona 5 Strikers is in a style of a musou game with Persona mechanics. This was my first musou game so it took a while of getting used to, but it was fun steamrolling through waves of enemies, and with Persona 5's flashy style and gameplay mechanics, made it a much more enjoyable experience. 

In terms of story, I'd say it's pretty good although that could be my bias towards Persona 5 in general. I do think that if you enjoyed the prequel, you would enjoy this one as well. (I don't really want to say much as I can't really explain without spoilers, sorry.)

Last of all, I want to talk about the PC port. For me, it ran perfectly fine for the most part, but it could be by many factors such as with the new patch (1.02), my hardware, and etc. 

For those who want to know what my hardware I'm using, I'm using a Ryzen 5 2600 and a RX 580.
The GPU driver version that I'm using is 20.4.2.

Throughout my playthrough the game only crashed 1 or 3 times but they were at minor parts (like an event with hanging out with Ryuji and Ann near the beginning of the game) so I'm glad it was mostly fine for me and I hope your experience goes smoothly. My computer also didn't suffer from the "infinite black screen" bug in the 5th Jail. I would advise to save whenever you can, just to be safe and to keep submitting your game issues to Atlus so that they could look into it and hopefully bring out another hotfix if you are still experiencing issues.

Overall, this is a great sequel to an already great game, and I would definitely say give it a shot if you liked Persona 5 but wanted more content. 

With the success of sales with this game, I hope Atlus and SEGA can continue to bring more of their games on to PC and multiple platforms. I personally do not see the point of having third party game exclusives as bringing games to multiple platforms will not only would bring in more sales, but it can introduce many people to their franchises, and it can make them more popular than they are now.

:D

author: 83795ec9-03da-5611-9b0e-89ed0c8566c5
content:
Persona 5 Strikers is a weird game.  The original game was a turn based rpg but this is a action game with rpg elements.  Think Kingdom Hearts or Final Fantasy 7 Remake.  Strikers is an actual sequel to the story of Persona 5 (not even Royal but the original Persona 5).  Also the original game is still only available on PS4 so if you don't have a PS4 and want to experience all the story before this point you are going to be shit out of luck.

All this weird shit out of the way, the game is pretty dang good.  Gameplay is fast and tactical. Lots of fun combos and can weave in persona abilities in-between them.  The music features some original compositions as well as tracks ripped straight from P5. The remixed battle themes are probably the biggest highlights here.  Story is entertaining but can feel a bit too familiar if you already have played Persona 5 before (even the characters will say, "Hey didn't we do something like this before?")  The new characters for the most part are pretty well written and interesting.   Voice acting is great.

Now for my complaints.  This game can feel a bit too long especially with the story being predictable.  This isn't necessarily a complaint but I felt like more risks could have been taken here.  I also feel like there is not a huge variety of personas compared to all the other games.  There are a lot of cool ones here but it feels lacking.  A lot of the side quests are also pretty bland and lack creativity.  Kill X guys with X character repeat x50.  

So yeah, game is fun.  Kind of a hard recommend if you haven't already played Persona 5 as you will be in the dark in quite a lot of details especially character relationships and words like "Metaverse" or "Palace."  I would definitely recommend if you already played Persona 5 and are open to action rpg games.  7.5/10

Also Atlus just put P5 on steam already.  Why the sequel got here first I will never understand.

author: 51e96e55-46da-5471-a4ce-e2d29549e512
content:
So, I finished this game last month. It was a really amazing ride and took me around 50 hours to beat. 
And well I'll be listing some pros and cons as well as some personal "feelings" down the end. Keep in mind, I'll only list the really important parts in this review. SPOILER FREE REVIEW! 

[h1] Pros [/h1]

[b] * Good story [/b]
The story in this game is pretty damn good and works perfectly as a sequel. 
The Phantom Thieves reunite again to steal the hearts and desires of even more adults on a "roadtrip." That's about what I can say without spoilers. 

[b] * The gameplay and 60fps! [/b]
Unlike all the other Persona games, this one isn't turnbased. It's a hack and slash type of game, but it does it kinda differently. You'll still have to hit the enemies' weaknesses to do more damage and stun them, meaning you still have to think, it'll just be a bit more action-paced. And the combat is also really satisfying. Oh. Did I mention that this game is actually in 60fps? No 30fps cap. 

[b] * Visuals and cutscenes look better than they've ever been! [/b]
[b] * The level design [/b]

[h1] Cons [/h1]

[b] * The repetitive story. [/b]
This story is really good! But! This Persona game does like every other Persona game, it keeps the same formular in the story. For example, in Persona 5/Royal you go and infiltrate palaces, but most of the palaces are made for you to get another teammate on your team. While this game doesn't exactly do this, it does it in a similar way. You go to jail, turn the shadow good, and then leave again, only to do the same process over and over. While this ain't THAT bad, I really hope that the future Persona games will improve on this. This is why the last bosses in Persona are always so good, because they're so different. 

[b] * No social links [/b]
Makes sense, since this is a very linear game in comparison to Persona 5. Still, I've always loved the social aspect of the Persona series. Sucks that it ain't here since it's what made Persona 5 into my favorite game. 

[h1] Thoughts [/h1]
I really enjoyed this game and I think it's a GREAT sequel. (With a few flaws.) If you love the Persona games (or just love Persona 5) You'll like this game, 100%! It might not be AS good as Persona 5/Royal, but it's still worth playing!

author: af9825f6-9c19-58c7-8c8c-d72c7453f3a9
content:
tl;dr 9/10
first half of the game is monotonous and boring with uninspired dungeons that all play out the exact same, but the second half has more uniquely designed dungeons with enjoyable game play and writing that makes up for the weak first half. p5 cast is also just enjoyable as characters which is nice, and the combat is fun.

PROS:
the combat is fun and blends JRPG and warriors style combat together incredibly well

zenkichi hasegawa, sophia, kuon ichinose, and akira konoe were pretty well written and i liked them

most of the soundtrack is pretty good

it gives characters who needed more development and screen time what they need

the writing of the cast was surprisingly fine for a spin off game i personally expected atlus to do the thing where they reduce characters personalities down to just two traits, but theyre pretty fine in p5s.

MIXED: theres no real difficulty in this game, because of the way the jails are designed you can just enter and exit them with no penalty, meaning that loss of SP and HP are meaningless, combined with the fact that due to various upgrades you can end the game with ABSURD amounts of items that can give you much more upgraded healing & support than necessary. this isnt bad to me, as it can allows for more accessibility by default of being easier, but people expecting a challenge will have to go out of their way to make it harder (although i have heard merciless is actually pretty difficult, i have not started a merciless playthrough)

some songs on the soundtrack, although still good, sound more like generic video game music rather than the style p5s was going for, which left me dissapointed as the persona series never fails with its soundtracks.

CONS:
first half of the game. its monotonous and the plot is horribly sluggish.

all of the dungeons felt the exact same in the first half which is never a good thing

most of the villains arent really anything good, which i dont mind the characters that are meant to be important are well written, but i wish theyd be atleast a bit more memorable or a bit more worth being someone im supposed to dislike, but its to be expected, the persona series has never been too good when it comes to any nonmajor villains.

the plot & villains are all just weaker p5, lots of the villains, just feel like weaker versions of the original. p5s's plot isnt even bad, its just that you know pretty much everything thats gonna happen the moment you realize that the story is just trying to copy its original.

overall the game is good and the game is fun. thats what matters. id say around 90% of the time i had a smile on my face, even when in the early half when it did feel monotonous and unoriginal, the p5 cast and the combat always managed to make me have an enjoyable time, but its flaws are definetly existant, and noticable.

author: 2f1bb7ed-a783-52db-bd5a-e99f96a7be8d
content:
Persona 5 Strikers is an ARPG triumph and hopefully a template for more SMT action RPGs in the future (it's been too long since the Raidou games).  They took the rough Dynasty Warriors/Musou template, merged with the SMT framework and Persona 5 specific features (baton passes, One More attacks, etc), loaded up each Phantom Thief with a moveset unique and fitting to them, and set you loose.  Combat is fast and fluid, while still being tactical and having that SMT lethality that you expect.  On an overall systems level, they kept what made sense from the base game, while removing or replacing bits that wouldn't make sense (ex. Social links, strict time scheduling).  The result is a game that's paced well, has a lot of challenging and fun encounters, but rewards your growth and skill over time (and your ability to fuse personas with elemental drains and physical/gun attack skills in tandem).

Plotwise, P5S is a direct sequel to Persona 5 (Royal content notwithstanding) and follows a similar enough trajectory as bit of a mirror to the Phantom Thieves' previous Metaverse adventures.  Strikers has the Phantom Thieves go on a summer road trip around Japan dealing with mysterious Jails that are appearing in concert with minor change of heart outbreaks.  In short, it's exactly what you'd expect from your favorite loudmouthed idiot social reformers on vacation, with some hilarious moments and the usual levels of "Morgana makes stuff up about the Metaverse that ends up being accurate".  Haru in particular is a riot due to not being saddled with the worst introduction plotline in the base game, and the new additions to the roster fit right into the group dynamic.  P5S won't break any new ground, but if you finished Persona 5 and want to spend more time with this group of miscreants, you'll have a good time with them here.

All in all, more than worth the money for SMT/P5 fans; if you're not familiar with P5 but are intrigued by this and don't mind some spoilers to the base game, it's still worth a look.

author: 3a319d11-5326-547b-9f24-438b3863fb1c
content:
Solid Stories. Passable Port. Overall: I'm having fun with no Frustration. [i]-=Recommended=-[/i]

KB+Mouse can Rebind and it works fine. Mouse Camera control has some Acceleration but not a big deal for me. Good thing is you can disable the Auto-Camera (love this option! but it's still have some Auto Center Camera on some Action which is pretty lame)

Note: Lots of dialogue. could be boring for player who hates long down-time. but you can skip/Fast-FWD most of them.

[update: 21 hours-in]
The game screen constantly filled with Chat bubbles, Onomatopoeia (comic effect words), and many type of Anime/Comic Effects. it's quite Messy. I know it's their Theme but it's too messy IMO.

Gameplays: 
[u]Combat[/u]:
Hard to tell when to dodge (partly cause how messy the effects on screen)
You fight with a Party of 1-4 Characters and can switch between them on-the-fly.
But in the end, it boils down to Spamming - Press Action when prompt and Repeat. pretty bare bone.

[u]RPG aspect[/u]:
You can collect Persona and Fusion them to evolve (somewhat like Pokémon) and they have 8 skill slots. They learn more skills and get stronger stats as they leveled up. Main Character (Joker) can switch between several Persona of choice while the Companions have their own fixed Persona.

The item system is overall pretty awful. the game have small list of Weapons, Armors, Accessories, Consumables. it's a pain to run around looking for the item stores and Vending machine, wasting time and 0 fun.

[u]Summary[/u]
The Story each chapter feel pretty much the same. 
1. You go to one town.  2. There's a bad guy. 3. You talk to a few NPC to collect information so you can go to next step. Buy items around the town. 
4. Enter the Jail (Palace dimension) to beat up Mobs, Collect a few orbs.
5. Come back out to fight 1 mini-boss.
6. Go back to fight Main boss. and Move on to next town.
7. Repeat 1-7 for several chapters

The game is getting Dull over time. but the Style does make some good screenshots too bad there's no Photo Mode. 

Not a great / Not terrible game. Passable Port.

content:
I think this game is good like all Persona games. However, there are some problems I have with it, specifically the controls.

1. Although I appreciate ATLUS adding this game to pc, the pc controls are hot garbage and awkward to use without rebinding over half of them.
2. The buttons on the switch pro controller are all jumbled up. You can fix this, again, by rebinding your buttons to the correct layout but you shouldn't have to do this to make your game enjoyable to play. This also changes the visual ques on the screen. If you're already familiar with the game then it's not a problem. But I get confused when the screen tells me to do one thing but the button does something else.

Overall I think the story is good and the game play and mechanics would be good if the controls worked the way they're supposed to. Unless you have an Xbox controller, then none of this really matters then. But I don't so I'm going to complain.

author: 14b1082a-1eaf-5627-ba63-c60952583c32
content:
Hi, I really looked forward to playing this game. Can't recommend it after 10 hours, though. I don't want to continue this. Note: I have not played Persona before, but have watched it on Twitch regularly and roughly know the plot. Also, I'll try to be the devil's advocate here, but don't blame me if I get a little worked up.
Pros:
There's no doubt it has awesome cinematics, cool fighting mechanics and controls well. I like Anime. Occasionally, I'll watch one. It's tiring though, how in every new Anime, most of the same ideas always get recycled. Persona, on the other hand, does a good job to come up with interesting new ideas and the characters all have a unique charme to them.
The palaces are really fun. I like the hidden chests and objects, the relatively unique combat ideas and the Persona system.
I played the game on normal mode and it is very well balanced. Plus, the music is great. I do believe some people are overrating the music, but it's still really spicy.
Cons:
Hear me out; I already mentioned that I like Anime. I, too, can invest lots of my time into deeper story and plot analysis. However, if I wanted to play a visual novel, I just would've. The dialogue scenes are cool at first, but they get so boring. At the same time, neither have any of my dialogue 'decisions' made ANY difference on the plot whatsoever, nor am I really willing to completely 'skip' all of them since then I'd have no idea what's going on. And the plot is what people always praise the series for, innit? I don't think it's bad to have long dialogue sequences, but they really OVERDID IT with the frequency. I've spent less time in dialogue sequences in all Life Is Strange games that have been released...
Furthermore, one is SO limited! I can't underscore this enough. You can't even explore one shop, one sideroad, one small area without any of the characters becoming professor oak lamenting about it 'neither being the right place, nor time'. I have to strictly follow the game's idea of how it wants to be played. It's frustrating. Why, devs? Well, in Pokemon Red (1999) at leat you could enter Pokemarts. Well, ATLUS didn't even bother to animate that in 2021. Again, where is the love? If the game is set in Tokyo, at least try to make it feel like there's a cool shopping experience you can have. The food and medical items you can buy in Persona 5 Strikers are basically all the same (When it comes to TP and SP restoring), they just have different names. By the way, 'Donut-Worry' (restores some health) is the only item/thing in the game that has made me chuckle. Though likeable, the convos are never really... funny. Yeah, the don't have a good sense of humour.
The areas are well designed. The artwork and visuals fit perfectly. In Tokyo and other places like Sendai, however, you'll see the same 9-10 character models all the time. Humans in this game appear to be nothing but strange hollows without even a glimpse of a soul. I just really wish they (the devs) had spent more time creating a world that's actually vivid. I wish they had taken more time to make this a good game.
The skill tree in this game is ridiculously uncomplex (It's the complete opposite to a game like Final Fantasy X). It's not interesting, it's not individual, and it's not really challenging your decisionmaking/brain either. Heck, they don't even make you do a small minigame or the like when you cook for the rest of the party. 
Hyrule Warrios, for anyone who's played that, really sucks at the plot part. But at least I get to PLAY the GAME. And I don't want to wait until I've gained freedom of movement potentially towards the end game. That's simply not a point.
We're in 2021 and still nobody expects your game to be as detailed as, say, the Witcher III (2015). In Contrast, with games like The Witcher existing (not a 60 Euro title by the way), how can you even legitimize putting so few love into your towns that you could basically copy from reality and didn't have to make up entirely.
Conclusion:
I have to add, that the voice acting in this game is superb and the writing too. As english is my second language, I quite enjoy the narrative and style. To be honest, I could probably forget about the cons. Well, if this weren't a 60 Euro game, that is!
I bought this game on Sale (52 Euro for Digital Deluxe) and that wasn't even worth it. I think at it's current state, the game isn't worth any more than 25 Euro, for there is a huge lack in love for the design of player independence. And hence they try to make it seem like your decision matters in conversations, you can't tell me they're not actually trying to establish the illusion that you do have some independence in this game.
Since I'm done with school now, soon to be studying at university and thus am short on money, I'll have to continue this game. I merely don't have the money to buy another one. I'll come back to this review once finished. 
If at all, please keep the comments neutral and respectful. Try convincing me rather than defending your favorite nostalgic franchise.

author: 6195eb6b-9935-507a-9fef-c4a0da53c2c3
content:
[h1] Actual, Super-Serious Persona 5 Strikers Review: [/h1]

[strike] it's ok, i guess. [/strike]



TL;DR: It's a good game, and I don't recommend it for those who haven't played/experienced Persona 5 in any form or fashion.



P5S is a great sequel for both the base and the Royal re-release versions of Persona 5. Admittedly I [i] am [/i] biased, as I fell in love with this game series since Royal's release and quarantine's abundance of free time. 

It has more of the characters that you love and more of the strategies you employed in P5, all wrapped up with fast-paced hack n' slash gameplay and a decent story that adds new characters that I'll refrain from mentioning any further. If this is your first game with the Phantom Thieves, I sincerely recommend that you [i] not [/i] start here, as all the pre-existing characters are already established in this sequel, and the game wastes [i] no [/i] time re-introducing them or their character arcs. If you don't understand what's going on from the beginning, you'll have to catch up on a lot in your own time, or just run around like a headless chicken and beat the h#%l out of the computer pixels with your skillful excellent button pressing.

My first run-through of mastering the game (Finishing the story and completing [b] all [/b] of the requests, side-bosses, etc.) took me exactly 69 [spoiler] nice [/spoiler] hours and so-and-so minutes on Hard mode, though I certainly took my time.

I also went through a Merciless NG+ run (only available after Mastering your first run) to finish my achievements list and unlock more powerful [strike] psychological Pokémon [/strike] Personas, I finished the achievement list at my current playtime (130.0 hours). While I do love this game, I'm not the type to normally enjoy NG+ runs and that more or less remains the same. I wouldn't recommend it, unless you [i] absolutely [/i] thought the game was too easy. Though be warned, it may feel a lot grindier than the normal Easy/Normal/Hard mode runs.

Other notable things worth mentioning:
[list]
[*]I only played on controller, and I recommend you do the same if possible. I'm not familiar with MnK controls, though I hear they're not the best. That preference is up to you, of course.
[*]The music, as always, is a banger. And has been remixed to fit with this game's faster, more action-oriented combat.
[*]The fusion system, the Velvet Room, and obtaining masks work somewhat differently compared to P5/P5R, though personally I didn't find the changes of serious significance.
[*]There are [i] no [/i] Confidants/Social Links, in its place are the traditional RPG-like leveling up of skills, and Combat Mastery by playing different Phantom Thieves.
[*]Speaking of which, you're able to play as any of the Phantom Thieves almost immediately. Each member has their own special variation of combos, and a unique combat skill that can alter your approach to a fight.
[*]Unfortunately, no waifu is canon. But (actual semi-spoiler) [spoiler] a certain 5head bestgirl(?) may or may not get more screentime [/spoiler]. 
[/list]


All in all, Persona 5 Strikers burned my bread, revealed the troof, and stole my heart. I lost the mutual respect of my friend groups after they saw me jump into the Persona sinkhole, and after 100%'ing this game I can tell you I've only sunk in further.

author: b0750583-55e7-5662-be17-53916d4e0ccf
content:
I was pretty hyped to get this game when it came out, in fact it's one of the few games I actually preordered because I knew I was getting it no matter what, since I loved persona 3,4 and 5. Plus I really like hack and slash type games, like Metal Gear Rising and Bayonetta. This however, is neither of those.

This game is a mix of Persona 5 and Musou games. If you like Musou games, you will probably like this, if you don't, but you enjoy persona 5, you might still enjoy it, given that it does differentiate in some aspects

It plays like persona 5 in the sense that you get to wield personas and it adds a somewhat complex layer to the game
However,  it's pretty boring as far as action games go. It's an average at best game covered with persona 5 elements that makes it seem better than it actually is.

 It lacks the polish most persona games have. The bad guys are bland, the main cast interactions feel sameish all throughout the game, the side missions are tedious as all hell, honestly it's a very unrewarding experience. There is no calendar system, there is no confidants, the difficulty is inconsistent... It's just not persona, or a fun game for that matter.

It's not good. It's not bad either, it's just ok! Not worth the $60 price tag, get it on sale.

author: 5545f75e-011c-54b7-9ad0-c09452999c65
content:
So I really like the Persona series and am planning on getting SMT Nocturne when it comes to steam. I will fully admit that I am biased toward this series and ATLUS in general. So instead of listing reasons you should get this game I will do a Pro/Con/Depends list.

Pros: 
- Killer Soundtrack
- Fun Hack & Slash Gameplay
- Good Variety of Characters and Playstyles
- Persona fusing has been changed. It now shows specific recipes for personas, even personas you don't yet own.   

Cons:
- Combat/Combos/Abilities take time to learn and you will be going back to the tutorial menu when you forget which combo casts Zio. 
- No Igor or Akechi :(
- I'll admit I'm struggling with coming up with cons, but I recommend looking at my next list to see if this game is right for you.

Depends:
- Direct sequel to Persona 5. This leaves a nice place for players to return to, but could alienate new players. It is worth mentioning that I tried my best to notice when the game made reference to the original P5 and it wasn't super frequent.
- Shorter than most RPGs. My first run was ~55  hours. Keep in mind I did every side quest I could.

Hopefully this encouraged you to get the game. Overall, very fun hack and slash game that I had a hell of a time with. Don't go in looking for something super groundbreaking. Instead go in for a fun, flashy and fantastical game where a bunch of kids go on a road trip. Takes some getting used to, but if my goldfish brain can have fun with this game, so can you.

author: 00d8b915-838c-531d-81cc-b47801b68346
content:
I will say to get this game if you played the first persona 5 and enjoy the characters and style. It really feels like a natural sequel to the first game which was super nice to come back to characters I loved. I will say the gameplay is super iffy.

At times, its a super fun and competent action rpg. The whole "warriors" type games are not my cup of tea but they did a good job making the whole game feel like its not made by that company.

However they didn't do a good job explaining mechanics of how the action and jrp persona battle mixes in. The game can either be painfully easy or huge diffuculty spikes of trial and error which isn't fun.

Plus the whole thing where characters you dont use dont level up with you until late game is really bad design. They did it in the last game and Royal so I don't understand why they don't do it for this game.

However its a really good game, I just feel the style of game should had either tweaked it a bit more to fit it, or just stayed as a turn based jrpg.

also put persona 5 on steam and switch you cowards.

author: a75119c0-3f4a-573d-8e28-146ecc0e7682
content:
I bought it again despite already having it on Switch thanks to the sale, and I must admit the 60FPS my gaming laptop can muster makes the game feel suprisingly different in a good way!

The game already means a lot to me as the whole setting and idea pretty much broke the chains I had been bound upon in my head by myself during the ongoing pandemic. It even learned me how to control my subconcious mind better along the way.

The gameplay itself is solid. Makes good use of the Persona system and translates it to real-time combat rather than turn-based and even the music remixes are made to complement the change perfectly well! It also just plays a lot better than most Warriors games, with more focus on story to balance out the often repetitive gameplay of these kinda games. It builds more upon a world and its exploration, rather than the 'Select a battle' style most Warriors games have nowadays.

Want a game that can hit you in the feels, and have a amazing soundtrack to go with it along with many other things to love in a RPG, then give this game a go for sure. Switch, Steam, both are good in their own ways.

Oh, and finally: Persona 3 (FES), Persona 5 Royal or just the whole Persona series for Switch and Steam when? I'm not asking this like many others are at every single chance to do so, this is even my first time doing it like this. Persona as a series, despite having watched more playthroughs than actually having played it, still really helped me understand myself more as the games show the way people work very well. Persona 4 touches upon acceptance of yourself and your bad sides, Persona 5 Strikers then goes deeper into that idea and instead goes for the way people become due to traumas or other events they might've gone through in the past and can't let go off.

So another point: If you feel you're struggling with these things, give the series a go (Or a look) and don't take everything at face value. The games have a weird way of showing off the Human mind, but it's actually not all that far-fetched if you really think about.

author: 53c926be-aeda-5796-b4cd-97411369dd39
content:
Worth it at $40 if you like persona 5.

Strikers is fun and good, it suffers from repetition though. Starting with the good:

Story's relatively straightforward, but good enough to keep you strung along. I'm about two thirds of the way through it, so maybe the last bit will blow me out of the water. If you like road trips and mysteries, you might like it.

Graphics/sound/presentation are all amazing. Nothing takes you out of the game, and the music really serves the fights well. Only issues is that you will hear some soundtracks too many times, and there's no ultrawide support :(

Gameplay is where it gets interesting. Imagine hyrule warriors but every enemy has elemental strengths and weaknesses, and you can collect enemies like pokemon and fuze them into different, stronger fighters (called personas). There's also basic enviromental attacks that do elemental damage. Add switching between characters as well, and the result is good fun. There's an additional amount of depth in technicals, ailments, buffs/debuffs, but you don't really need to focus on them, even in hard mode. 

The problem is that it, like other warrior esc games, it gets repetitive. Boss battles are supposed to freshen it up, but they mostly fight like other enemies but with quicker attacks and bigger health bars. So, you're gonna do a lot of swinging, casting a spell at a weakness, and dodging regardless of the fight, and not much else. It really would benefit with much more emphasis on inflicting technicals/ailments and switching to different personas/party members to deal damage. Then each fight requires using your brain a bit instead of how it currently is. 

Unlike persona 5, there's not much side stuff to do, so there isn't really much to take a break from the combat. Side quests boil down to doing combat challenges, fetching items for party members, or both. A lot of them require you backtrack through previous dungeons too. This game is really only playable for the main story.

It's still fun and I enjoy it, can't see it being worth $60 though. Wait for a good sale.

content:
Overall decent game? I was very skeptical about a musou Persona game but this turned out pretty well. 
The core gameplay loop is great, with Persona choices, elemental weaknesses, some cool finishing moves and good ol' All Out Attacks. Narrative is not too bad, either. Just some minor issues outside of the main gameplay loop which really annoy me.

It's like the game really wants you to waste time shopping and navigating their slowly animated menus- you'd likely see some Sophie jokes in the reviews but this is really criminal in a way that is really stupidly inconvenient. 

Also, the investigation phases are really not fun at all- the locations you get to go to all over Japan are really...kinda boring and feel quite token like you're "travelling" all over Japan- but it's really touch and go.

Several crashes to desktop, weird camera angles and some minor UX flaws but overall the game is fine.

author: 1c1e4551-864d-53f5-acd3-d461d3bb0472
content:
I have beaten this game twice. While it may not have been on the steam version, I am working on that right now.
Persona 5/Royal is my favorite game of all time. So when Atlus released this, I was exited as hell. I will now say a few things my sister has asked me about it (Also a persona fan)
Worthy Sequal? Yes
As good as original or Royal? Close but no
Worth it to play on anything its available on? Some better than others but overall yes.

Now onto the actual spoiler-free Review.
While it is different from the Turn-Based battles of the series, it's still a very good game. As I have played some hack and slash games, While I may be a bit biased on this decision, Persona 5 Strikers is my favorite of that genera due to the characters, story, and overall feeling of the fighting. Its nice to have different abilities and still have it feeling like the main series. I still highly recommend playing P5/R before playing P5S if you can.
The controls are easy to understand. I personally played with a controller as thats what I use for hack and slash and persona games in general. (Xbox One and Switch Pro Controller for more background) While I dont think its impossible to play with a keyboard and mouse, it would be harder as you only have 8 ways to move. But play how you want to or have the ability to play with.
Overall, Recommended. With a few aceptions. If you have played or watched a full playthrough of P5/R.

自带中文，而且低价区比港服打折还要便宜，好评！

[Updated after 10 hrs playtime]
After finishing the first part of the story, I have a general grasp on how the game is played and can say more on the performance and gameplay itself.
There are some flaws to the game, including relatively longer load time comparing to other games and to playing it on PS5 (I am running this game also on a high-performance SSD). Especially when I load up the game, it usually takes me 10 to 15 seconds to actually be able to play the game. I am not sure the problem can be fixed, and it is rather minor problem, but this will be frustrating after more hours of playtime, which I know I will be having. Another thing that stands out to me is that although I am playing this game on a controller, the character can only move along the 8 axis using the left stick. This is definitely bad porting, and I haven't experienced anything like this on other ported games like Yakuza series or Atlus' own Persona 4 Golden.

Gameplay is solid so far, but also missing out on a lot of thing that really made persona series stands out from other JRPG games - daily interactions. While the game still using the calendar system like its predecessors, there are less layer to that because you are free to spend however long time you want in one day and do whatever you want. Being able to go and return palace (jails) freely without worrying about time passing is more player-friendly, but it feels like cheating to just freely go in and out to recover your hp and sp.
Up till this point of the game, I haven't had any side stories and bonding time with other characters. The city has much less things to explore and places to go. Although it seems like we got to visit more cities, so that might still be fun.
I guess I just miss the time to spend with all my [spoiler]waifus[/spoiler]friends and school life.
The fighting is fun, and the way the incorporate the old persona system to this musou type game is very interesting.

A solid 8/10 so far. Definitely recommend if you have played Persona 5 before, and worth to play if you haven't and don't mind missing out on some stories or spend time watching the anime series

content:
I really enjoyed Persona 5 Strikers. At first I didn't expect it to work out in this format but in the end it was really fun. The ability to change characters and fight with different styles helps keep the combat a little bit fresh. You might get bored of repetitive combat but it goes by fast. Getting the bonus BGM from the deluxe edition helped with fights to add more variety too but that is more money to be spent.

I did not have any crashing problems as I played like other people seem to have had, the most recent patch might have fixed that. Some of the CG cut scenes in the beginning had some crusty frame rate but towards the end I noticed it got better. Gameplay was smooth the entire time. 

I paid $76 USD for the deluxe edition. I felt like it was worth it for myself, as I am becoming increasingly invested in the persona games. If you're just a casual fan that is not super invested then maybe getting it at $40 or $50 might feel better for you.

It is a direct sequel to Persona 5 though, so you might want to play that beforehand. Currently, Persona 5 / Royal is only available on the playstation. Hopefully Atlus will port Persona 5 to PC later on.

author: 7dda51c9-2aac-597a-87e8-b1fdc0d8af72
content:
Spoiler free.

I think its been stated multiple times, but you MUST play Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal before you play this game. Well, I shouldn't say "must" but the impact and fan service in this title is so spectacular if you've played the first entry in the series. Without it, you will 100% be missing out, both on specific story sections, and character (further) development.

Let it also be noted that this game appears to follow Persona 5 more than Persona 5 Royal, due to missing added characters from P5R and specific portraits pulled from P5 rather than P5R. P5R also had a couple story changes, but nothing that should make you want to play P5 over P5R. Pick either one, play it, and then play this amazing game. Don't let the Musou battle system scare you away. This battle system is miles better than anything Dynasty Warriors has done since its creation.

+ The Battle system is fun and skillful. Each character has abilities to learn and unlock and a specific playstyle. Each playstyle can be extremely useful or largely abused (against you) depending on which and what type of enemy you are fighting
+ Tons and tons of Personas for our Protagonist, just like in P5/P5R
+ Throbbing King of Desire returns. If you're not sure about this reference, avoid looking it up in public
+ Great story. Great Characters. Same feeling and writing style from P5/P5R
+ Same great music
+ Post game content
+ Returning entity from P3 (don't look it up)

- Save Often. Crashes from time to time/infinite loading screens. I think the 1.02 patch fixed most of this (at the time of posting this review 4/27/21) as I was having much less crashing upon it's implementation, but not entirely resolved.

Great take on a warriors style game that exudes Persona's style and charm. This game will definitely be confusing story-wise if you haven't played the original Persona 5 seeing as there are plenty of references to it's predecessor.

*Slight Story Spoilers*

The game follows the same story structure as Persona 5, and will leave any players who played the previous vanilla Persona or Royal with a bit of déjà vu  by the time you get to the climax and ending. And of course, the story uses the very traditional character trope where there is an abnormal teammate who does not know who or what they are (Used in both Persona 4 Golden with 2 characters, and with Morgana in Persona 5). author: 69d2e6ba-7be8-5825-8c3e-ded093447008
content:
It's Persona 5's sequel - Lite Edition.

The gameplay is very much like Persona 5's, with a lot of the same. The game is still split in 2 sections, the Metaverse and the  real world. 

The gameplay in the Metaverse is mostly the same as Persona 5's, except for the combat. You'll navigate around, hide in corners and ambushing enemies the same, but instead of turn-based combat it's a Dynasty Warriors style. The fights don't span the entire map like other entries in the genre, but are instead in small, restricted areas. Most of the Persona fight aspects are still there, using Personas to attack, taking advantage of elements, all out attacks, and the like. Ambushes against weaker enemies usually ends up with an immediate All-Out-Attack and winning immediately, though tougher fights do take more time as expected. While fighting, you have 3 teammates with you, which you can control both in fights and while exploring the dungeons. Each teammate has a unique playstyle too.

In the real world, things are very dialed back compared to the full Persona games. There are no Confidants/Social Links, and most of the confidants from 5 are gone, but not unmentioned. There are no romance options, either. There's no stats to build. There's no time limit on completing the dungeons, you are free to leave and re-enter them as much as you want as opposed to progressing to the next day as is usual. Most of your time in the real world is spent either shopping for items, completing tasks for rewards like new weapons, or just doing story-related tasks such as getting info on the next dungeon boss.

The story itself I have not completed, but from what I have played it is very enjoyable. The game is very much a sequel to Persona 5, the original version, not Royal. It's nice to come back to the Phantom Thieves.

Overall, while the Metaverse side is quite fun and familiar, the real world side feels lacking and leaves me wanting more. However, I'd still recommend this game. It's still a fun game and the team is as enjoyable as ever, but playing the game makes me want to revisit Persona 5.

Great gameplay, awful writing. The dialogue is really uninspired and just seems like it was thrown at the wall to see what sticks. There's no real character or moral development from Persona 5, just more of the same. Our main heroes act like they've never had any life experiences outside of what the game shows you, as if they're just actors in a show. Regardless, the game is fun, I just find myself cringing at the rather second-rate plot points and superficial character development.

EDIT: After completing the game, and likely going on to 100% it, I'll change my review to recommend. The writing and storytelling is still quite sub-par, but the gameplay is still exponentially fun, even as a musou-style.

author: 1232f2f5-ec63-546e-a89a-4aa39c654f97
content:
Kinda late on this since i last purchased but since the game had a patch. I wouldn't know if how much of my criticisms have changed. I think that this game is pretty neat, I wouldn't have had put as many hours as i have put into it if I didn't enjoy it. 

Parts of the game could have been better, though a lot of my criticisms have been already addressed by a lot of people though I'll say that how leaving the dungeon and coming back to restore hp and more importantly sp is kinda dumb that it just doesn't heal automatically, I guess its to have the feeling of during new game plus or whatever the player can feel like they didn't need to come back and rejuvenate but doesn't really feel like its needed aside from possibly needing to stock up on items which could just be done anyways.

The story is fine I liked parts of it can't say I'm too much of a fan though even if it is just mostly dumb fun, I like some of the new characters but that's about it. 

The game would crash on me a unusual amount of times for almost no explainable reason, I detected a pattern some of the time with like traveling between the velvet room and back or like leaving the game on in the background for a realllllly long time and then it would crash after some transition back to the real world, but other times i really couldn't explain why like during story events, so I just got used to save somewhat often since it barely takes that much time.

I got a unusual amount of time trying to assemble some heavy hitting personas (even if lucifer is just the best for dealing with large groups) and figuring out a lot of the different combos that come with those personas and even different party members, its all built pretty well. In the case of joker though being able to switch out to a persona that nulls or absorbs a attack was pretty satisfying though it also kinda feels like there's not really a reason not to freeze time to null a attack instead of like dodging or something, due to how most attacks don't really move when you freeze time and select a different persona, aside from some attacks acting during that time but barely ever happens. I think if a sequel or a different SMT spin off as there could be a lot to expand on here gameplay wise. 

If you like this series there's not really a reason to not get the game but just gonna say I'd wait for a discount because despite all the good I don't think its worth 60 bucks, and I especially don't think it was worth 70 bucks even if I got to access it 3 days early and some music dlc/extras which in all honesty ain't much : P (Or you could just buy it anyways). ~~I'm sure I'll complain about the price of things more as soon as nocturne hd comes out~~

author: e7889f03-8489-50cc-8649-6ba5564fca9f
content: Persona 5 Strikers is still Persona, but instead of Turn based you get Warriors-style hack-n-slash battles. Atlus and Koei really made this game work amazingly, perfectly translating the persona 5 battles into warriors style. The game just as stylish and the writing is just as good, if not better then Royals. All the new music and remixs feel great and unique while still feeling the same. Although the game has some issues running on PC, it still runs well enough to play. The Digital Deluxe in-game DLC I find really adds to the game having the older music from the series' past. Although the Deluxe's bonus content is just a unity project, which means you don't get the soundtrack directly as music files. Atlus actually updating this game on PC to make it more stable is great, just wish they'd fix the optimization issues it has.

author: 9d134a6e-b799-50e7-b644-3acfc77ca167
content:
POST PATCH REVIEW 4/20/2021: It brings me great joy to finally update this review to a storngly recommended, as the newest patch has just released that appears to fix the crashing. I was able to play an additional 2 hours tonight with no crashing, and plan to do a second playthrough on NG+ soon. This game, despite appearances, is not a Warriors game and I mean that in the best way possible. Honestly, this game has no right being as good as it is but honestly it's incredible. Arguably a stronger game, emphasis on game, than the original Persona 5. They've refined nearly every aspect of the combat and Persona fusion systems, and cut a lot of the fat in the social interactions and day-to-day life elements of the game. This is a lean, mean, and extremely enjoyable Persona experience.

The game is also a surprisingly competent action game. I fully believe that a Level 1 playthrough would be possible based on pure skill alone, as every enemy and boss has clearly telegraphed attacks with unique projectile patterns that can all be evaded. The game never forces you to tank damage and heal like most action RPGs because the damage is unavoidable. With that said, it would be extremely tedious to do this because of how little damage you would be doing in return. However, I think it is an accomplishment in game design that I came away feeling this way.

I only have 3 genuine complaints. First, this game honestly is just "Persona 5 Again" in terms of its story. The only surprise you will find here is how blatant the plagarism is. Second, there seems to be a lot of tedious, repetitive, and grindy aspects to this game. However, we all play on PC here and Cheat Engine exists who ultimately you only need to suffer through this if you choose to. Finally, the god damned hooks in Okinawa. You either know what I mean or you will. It's just a terrible decision to make the player wait on this slow hooks in order to progress through the dungeon especially when the characters are clearly able to jump the height required. It's horrible.

I wholeheartedly recommended this game. It's a good deal even at full price, and a great experience for anyone who likes Persona or even Action RPGs.

ORIGINAL NEGATIVE REVIEW: This game is actually incredible, but I cannot give it a positive review until the random crashes are fixed. In my playtime, I have experienced nearly 2 dozen crashes and while with habitual saving the consequences can be mitigated it is extremely frustating. I shouldn't have to play in constant fear of random crashes, possibly even caused by the DRM. Until the crashing is resolved, don't buy this.

author: 57bea2d5-0670-5473-a59d-40b56809f36d
content: I put around 100+ hours into both P5 and P4G respectively, so I have some amount of experience with this franchise.  In short, this game is fun as hell.  Now for the long part.  The combat is fast paced and has interesting mechanics to boot.  You would think that pausing the game in order to select a skill from a menu would be detrimental to the pace of battle, but it actually isn't. Furthermore, every member of the Phantom Thieves has their own unique playstyle, which kind of implies that each PT member has their own situational usage.  Joker has his usual "wild card" sitch, Ryuji is the heavy, Morgana becomes a car, Ann has an enchant, Yusuke is a Fire emblem character, you can finally ride Makoto's bike, Haru is a beyblade, and the two new characters each have their own thing going on too.  Sophia is a great addition to the PT, acting as kind of a Morgana 2.0 from P5, (she navigates the PT to and through the Jails, which are like Palaces from P5, so no Sophia means no game) considering she's an amnesiac who has no clue what her origin is.  However, instead of being quite annoying like our favorite mascot, Sophia ends up being one of the most likable characters in the whole game.  Then there's Zenkichi, who's basically Dojima from P4 [spoiler] but he's a Persona user [/spoiler].  He is also an amazing addition to the PT, acting as a kind of "team dad," who looks out for and genuinely cares about his team, his family, and justice.  The villains in this game are also pretty great.  Instead of being one-dimensional hate sinks like in P5 (not R), these guys have more depth to their actions, usually acting the way they are due to trauma and abuse from earlier points in their lives.  Main bad guy is kind of a toss up though, since I still think Shido had so much going on in P5 that it's really hard to even come close to him, and [spoiler] Konoe [/spoiler] felt less diabolical once you learn his backstory.  Overall, I think this game is great, but I did have some issues with fullscreen and had a few crashes.  Definitely worth the buy!

author: 834088b7-b1de-559a-a56f-86385a00c599
content:
Overall this game is a little hit or miss. It's got some really good ideas and there was clearly a lot of effort put into this game. However, I believe that the game's pacing was rushed to hit a deadline, leading to the game feeling pretty mediocre and stale after a while.

This game is supposedly a direct sequel to Persona 5, and the story itself does feel like it, but it completely disregards any of the events of Persona 5 Royal so whether its canon is entirely up in the air. 

This game's rendering engine could also seriously use some AA as the art style looks totally whack. 

A decent game but not worth $60 (I paid $70) - 6/10

author: b858a1b8-faaa-52ed-be94-42f01af7b5f1
content:
Little late adding this review as I beat the game/post game a while ago, but opted not to go into Merciless Mode. So just to say upfront: Strikers is fucking great. As someone that played a single Dynasty Warrior game like two decades ago, hated it, and never played another, this was an amazingly fun experience. That said, it's defiantly still a Persona game, which is good. Weakness and Technical attacks are the biggest key to actually getting anything done so it's not just mindlessly spamming the same combo every which way the wind blows. Technical hits in particular are vastly more important then in P5/Royal since you can Ailment bosses and especially trigger Technical hits that will chip away at enemy shields (which is necessary for the few enemies with no Weaknesses).

I would only recommend people interested to hold off if they haven't played P5/Royal since it is a sequel. On that note, the events of Strikers seem to be based off the ending of P5 rather then the true ending of Royal. No mention of Yoshizawa.

author: fc4f876e-b8b4-5049-b466-226a198d9de6
content:
I enjoyed the game, but it is not without flaws.
TLDR: The game crashes, save frequently. Combat is fun but some fights can drag on too long. The plot is fine, nothing special but having the gang all together in new places has some great interactions. If you are a fan of the Phantom Thieves and can stomach the potential crashes and gameplay issues, get it. If you aren't invested in the characters, there isn't much reason to get this over other action games.

crashes - In the 60 hrs it took me to beat the game on normal and do all requests, the game crashed several times during loading screens. There are few things more frustrating than beating a tedious optional boss and then the game crashing when you leave the area.

Speaking of bosses, each story boss has a unique design and arena that makes their fight interesting. Mini-bosses not so much, they felt more like tedious resource drains. The optional bosses even more so, spamming skills to destroy their guard just to have your fully upgraded all-out-attack move the hp bar 10 pixels doesn't feel great.

Unlike other musou games, melee kinda takes a back seat. The combination of melee doing small chip damage and 100 things flying around the battle, makes melee risky and unrewarding and persona skills far superior. Other than generic grunts, if you are approximately the same level as an enemy they don't especially care about any attacks that aren't the element they are weak against. Each character has a combo or 2 that deal their element as damage without using sp, but the real deal hits harder. You're gonna want to stock up on sp recovery for challenging fights.

There are some fun character interactions as the thieves interact with each other in new situations and environments. I also love the new characters. There is nothing from royal since the games were being made at the same time, so don't expect 3rd semester character growth to be present here.

author: 30ce393b-e355-56c1-83dc-05c4dd1ccfbd
content:
A hack n slash rpg should be easy to come to grips with, a pick up and play experience.  Persona 5 Strikers is not that.  This game has all the complexity in mechanics and gameplay of the mainline series squished uncomfortably into a far more fast paced game.  You must still juggle multiple persona types and hit weaknesses while making sure to not deplete your SP, but now with the added annoyance of large scale battles where you must also weave and dodge attacks.  Too many times I've lost fights because my team didn't have the correct type matchups, or we burned through all our SP in a single strong enemy encounter.  These are fine in a 100+ hour turn-based RPG, but it feels VERY out of place in a Dynasty Warriors-style hack n slash.  

I loved Persona 5 and there are times when I love Strikers, but it's far too complex to enjoy consistently for me.

author: 0b987259-904b-5e12-bf9a-7965228ac344
content:
If you liked P5 you're probably going to like this game too.

Combat is simple yet incredibly fun. Showtimes and All-Out Attacks are hype af

Story is more linear than the original game but the cast is as enjoyable as ever. Voice acting for the English version is mostly excellent, despite the difficulties they had recording during the pandemic.

Persona fusing has been simplified with less options, which has in turn made that part of the game less enjoyable than mainline persona games. There are also less personas to fuse and collect in total.

The game also suffers a bit from having unbalanced difficulty scaling. It goes from being somewhat challenging in the beginning, to becoming quite easy in the end due to increased HP and SP resources. Merciless difficulty fixes this a bit in NG+, with the consequence of making minibosses too tanky.

But overall I would say that Koei Tecmo has done a great job implementing turn-based RPG elements into an Action RPG. All in all a worthy sequel to P5.

author: 0ee050e7-91d7-505f-9245-ae213f1a2375
content:
Having put well over 300hrs into P5 and P5R, i can tell you that if you loved those two games then you will probably love this game.

However i must warn you it is better played with a controller. You can use any controller you can connect to Steam for this game but you need to launch the game with the controller already in use on the PC. I recommend launching the game from "Big Picture" mode. 

One major issue (at the time of this review 4/13/21) is a crashing issue. My game has crashed when entering Jails (this game's version of a Palace) and during transition sequences within the Jails. So i HIGHLY recommend saving at EVERY possible chance you get or you will lose progress when it crashes.

Music is great, just like in every other Persona game. 

Gameplay is obviously different but once you get used to it you will enjoy it, especially if you like games like Dynasty Warriors. Being able to play as any character in your party is a nice touch and having (almost) every beloved Phantom Thief unlocked right away is a good touch. Joker's Wild Card still lets you get Personas, but now instead of convincing them to join you they will instead sometimes drop masks when defeated. Fusion is more or less the same with some new mechanics that are easy to understand.

Sophia is new best girl?

author: 1a0e6bca-3c16-5d89-aa00-7b7d7fe943b0
content:
I have played through the game enough to now have a better written opinion of it. In general, I think this is a good game and enjoyed most of my time with it. However, there is definitely parts I did not like.

Story:
 For the most part, I thought the story was fun. There were times where it got dull or just felt extremely rushed that I didn't like, but I overall liked the story. There is a decent amount of parts that do feel like reuses of things that happened in the series before, mainly Persona 5. Those didn't really bother me too much except for at a certain point in the story that I just found to be extremely lazy writing. I also found two of the villains to either be too "evil" or not a bad person for the most part.

Gameplay:
 Personally I love the gameplay. I find it really fun and a unique twist on the gameplay style for the type of game this is. If you are not a fan of the beat em up style of Warriors games, then you'll probably not like the gameplay as much. However, there is enough differences in my opinion that would make it worth a shot atleast. It also has the dungeon crawling of a normal Persona game, just not exactly the same. There is more expansive spaces than a typical Persona game.

Characters:
 For the most part I really liked the returning cast and the new cast added to this game. There were some points I found the returning cast used the same jokes too much, but other than that I liked them about as much as in P5/P5R. I honestly loved the new main cast characters. I found their character arcs, story and personality amazing. They were just overall really good characters. There were some not as major characters that I really liked as well. Overall, I just really liked the characters of this game.

Sound:
 I absolutely loved the soundtrack of this game. All the returning songs were great and all the new songs were amazing. There are even remixes of some returning songs and those remixes are so so good. The rest of the sounds were overall pretty good. There were only a few times where I didn't think sounds fit what was going on. As an example, there were some moves that just didn't fit the noise they made and threw me off.

 
 In the end, I still feel this is a really good game and a pretty good sequel to Persona 5. I also think it could fit for P5R a bit more than I originally thought when I got it. However, I'd only really recommend getting it if you're a fan of Persona, specifically Persona 5, and if you like the gameplay style. There is also a decent amount of bugs that have been reported and a few I have had, but they are working on them. Atlus recently put out a hotfix beta that, since using, I have not had any problems with the game.

author: 33107bbf-096a-5546-92b8-7fa797e22f49
content:
Pros
-Actually decent combat system. I actually prefer this than the original. It's weird that after trying this system and going back to the normal turn-based. Not that the turn-based is bad, just that this system is just a lot more fun.
-Standard Persona stuff, honestly do not get this game if you've never played persona 5. 

Cons
-Even though the combat is fun, it's repetitive. After awhile, you can't even enjoy the music since you are way too powerful for the normal minions, Even on hard. Go in, all-out-attack and repeat. The mini-bosses are fun and should be integrated more and much more often. 

-In my 60 hour gameplay, I crashed 5 times. That's not really game breaking but a bit annoying. And it's random too. My pc specs is above average ( ryzen 7 3700x & RTX 3080 ). Your mileage might differ, but 5 times in 60 hrs is kinda annoying since there is no autosave. 
-Why release the sequel on multiple platforms and not the original? really weird decision making.

Conclusion
-For persona 5 players : instant buy

author: 94c6b9c2-b4d9-5c67-ac3a-fb3f86c60559
content:
A fantastic game, but not for the reasons I expected. Let's go over the good and the bad of this game (and it's mainly good) 

1) The gameplay is actually fantastic. 

I was worried when I heard that this was going to have Dynasty Warriors style combat. After slogging through Hyrule Warriors, I expected a lot of dull and repetitive fights, but they really did a great job of converting Persona 5's turn based combat system into real time. You swap between characters with a press of the button, throwing out their abilities and dodging enemy attacks as you keep the combos going. 

The emphasis is still placed on hitting elemental weaknesses, casting buffs/debuffs and all that, but style is the name of the game when it comes to Persona 5. Just like P5, you can end a fight with an equal-level foe in 5 seconds with a nice ambush or stop a boss dead in its tracks with well selected attacks. The flow is absolutely perfect and every "SHOW'S OVER!" splash screen feels well earned. 

There are a few flaws. There's only ONE time in the entire game when you can use all your party members at the same time and the progression of spells (Agi --> Agio --> Agidyne) is rather dull, but it's still a thrilling experience. I would not mind if every Persona game from this point forward used a combat system like this. 

Gameplay: 9/10 

2) The story is pretty cool, though nothing show-stopping. 

At the end of Persona 5, everyone's character arc is pretty much resolved with a clear endpoint. Our entire cast starts the game as a group of well-rounded individuals who have for the most dealt with their inner demons. This means that we're in a situation where a lot of the game is about a group of good friends who are entirely chill with one another going around kicking ass and solving problems. 

Now, this isn't necessarily a bad thing. Essentially, the story is a chance to hang out with eight characters who you already like from the first game for a while. And you know what? That was actually a good feeling. Even during the moments of high drama in the plot, I found it to be a really relaxed affair. There was a certain comfort in being in such familiar surroundings. If you've played the first game, then you've already spent 100+ hours with these people and they're your friends. And being around friends is nice. 

I don't think anyone that hasn't played the first game would like this though. 

Story: 8/10

3) Surprisingly, there's almost no romance stuff. 

The story is a direct sequel to Persona 5, but it's apparently a version of Persona 5 where the player character chose to not date anyone. Or maybe he just chose not to date any of the Phantom Thieves girls and is actually having menage a trois with the teacher and doctor characters. Whatever. 

Regardless, if you were expecting to get some extra scenes with Makoto out of this game, then you'll be unpleasantly surprised to learn that there is a grand total of ONE moment in the entire game where you can ask someone to spend time with you in a romantic context, and even that is just some five minute nothing-happening scene. I was kind of shocked by this. I mean, the waifu stuff has to be about 37% of the reason people like Persona games, right? Why would they just entirely ignore that? I don't understand it.

Waifus: 3/10 

Overall: 8.5/10 Highly recommended, especially for anyone who's played Persona 5. The world needs more Persona games.

content:
OK Persona 5 Strikers, I’m giving you one chance to come clean. Where is my girlfriend and what have you done with her?

I’ll admit, Hifumi wasn’t at the forefront of my mind when I first returned to the world of turn-based Japanese roleplaying game Persona 5. I was more eager to catch up with my friends and fellow Phantom Thieves: Ann, Yusuke, Makoto, Futaba, Haru, Morgana — even Ryuji. Though only six months had passed for them since we attacked and dethroned god, I hadn’t properly spent time with our ragtag group in three years (barring one weird dancing fever dream). I was curious to see what they’d gotten up to in my absence, and how our experiences together might have impacted them.

author: 2c308501-b21d-5a0c-9f9e-5cfb3cc87c94
content:
Having finally finished Persona 5 after playing through it for six months, I decided to hop onto Persona 5 Strikers as soon as I finished. I can't say I have anything substantial to say about it yet, I'm only an hour in and god knows that these games go on forever. What I can give are general impressions that might influence otherwise prying eyes:

- Do I recommend this if you haven't played Persona 5 yet? So far, no. Do I think it's a requirement, though? Also no. The general impression I've gotten so far is that if you haven't had the chance to play P5 yet, it'll be weird hopping into this story with all of these characters you haven't met yet, but if you really don't have any choice, you'll make do.
- If you HAVE played P5, you'll notice that this takes some pretty big departures from what was in that game. Most notably in the combat, which is this game's main selling point, but the area that I think will be the most contentious is that there isn't any Social Link system. P5S is a lot more linear than its predecessor. I don't think that's a bad thing, necessarily; there's so much to do in P5 that I'd happily start a new game if one hundred more hours didn't seem daunting to me. But, if that's what you really loved P5 for, it's best that you set your expectations at the gate before stepping into Strikers. This is a spin-off that acts as a semi-sequel of sorts, but no, I wouldn't call it a full-on sequel.
- The combat is what will make or break this for you. As I said, it's the main selling point and they've stripped out all of the non-linear segments from the original game to focus on it. From what I've played so far, it's pretty typical of a Musou fighter. There's a billion enemies on screen, you have your teammates on the  side, go beat the shit out of everything that you see. They did implement some of Persona's systems, in that you do still have your gun and can cast your Persona onto enemies who might have elemental weaknesses. That's cool, but it doesn't seem very deep so far. Again, these are impressions.
- Other than the combat and lack of the Social Link system, they've managed to maintain the Persona 5 style down to a tee. You have your animated cutscenes, fantastic score, cell-shaded art style, all the way down to the way conversations play out. Pretty impressive, seeing as I was expecting this to just be beating the shit out of everyone on screen.
- The PC for this is... okay? It's not bad, and minus some crashing issues that have been reported, it runs well. If you're going to play this on PC, though, keep a controller on hand. You can rebind the controls, which is neat seeing as the default control scheme borders on being decent to "who the fuck thought this layout made any sense at all?", but it really just works better with a controller.

I hope to write a fully fledged review when I'm done with this, too.

Also, Atlus: [i]bring Persona 5 to PC[/i]. If not Royal, then at least bring the original version over? Like, I get that you're still trying to test the waters and it'll take a little while to optimize your engine to run on PC, that's okay. But releasing the semi-sequel to a game that's exclusive to one platform and having it being a multi-plat title before the original game gets ported to anything else is just kind of funny to me.

content:
Just my two cents rn, I'll update it as I progress

Pros:
- I'm a sucker for beat em ups and got my money's worth; combat was fun, seamless, and intuitive.
- The jails are several steps up from the palaces; they are immersive, lush, and fucking GORGEOUS.
- Soundtrack slaps

Cons:
- Story's kind of a let down; it hits WAY TOO MANY of the original's notes and reduces some characters like Yusuke to parodies. Significant character growth was literally non-existent.
- Copious frame rate drops during jails; could just be my specs but HOT DAMN did they bust my ass.

Verdict: If you're looking for fluid gameplay or just love Persona, you're in for a treat. Storywise, ehh......hold it off until it's on sale.
- 7/10

author: cb6d27f2-d154-5e64-999c-85f7d5621a7f
content:
I haven´t played any Dynasty Warrior games so I cant judge how well this game does stuff compared to comparable titles, so this comes from a guy who just really likes Persona 5.

If you are a fan like me, you should definetely give this game a try! It´s more time with the phantom thieves and their members, which is great. Sure, you dont have to manage school-life or your confidances, and battles are fought in real time, but it still FEELS all Persona 5-ey. If you played the original (or Royal) you know what I mean, the style, the music and the whole atmosphere.
It´s just a bit different, but I would like to stress that that´s not a bad thing. You just feel a different kind of rush and excitement when you have to control the movements of the thieves directly in battle, The change in genre fits surprisingly well (at least for me)! Before you had all these thievy characters in a rather static battle-system, this one allows you to experience much better how the phantom thieves sneak around enemies or weave through them, and it feels awesome.

So yeah, watch Queen screaming FIST OF JUSTICE while the new Last Surprise track is blasting and try to tell me you dont love this. 

10/10, more "For reals"s from Ryuji
11/10 Ryuji drops the f-bomb finally
