author: 4a8b9a46-41b4-5fb6-8532-903b4486a423
content:
Picks up right where Persona 5 left off, which as a returning player from the original Persona 5 feels great. The game will probably make less sense for people who aren't familiar with the original Persona 5, but the gameplay is still solid regardless. 

There are a lot of QoL changes made in Strikers that just weren't there in the original Persona 5, some to accommodate the new Dynasty-Warriors type combat, while others are just generally nice changes (such as no punishment for returning to the real world from the Metaverse). 

Overall if you've played the original Persona 5 and don't mind the switchup in the core combat loop, I highly recommend this game. If you haven't played the original Persona 5, you can still enjoy this game for what it's worth but you may miss out on references made to the original game.

author: bd40c972-7c55-59a9-8bbb-617388a9210e
content:
I only have one question. WHY IS THIS IN THE P5 TIMELINE? I'm genuinely curious why P5R isn't the canonical timeline. If you wanna see your favorite gymnast waifu, and edgey the hedgey detective friend I'm sorry to disappoint. She doesn't exist, and he's still dead the end. Also, there's no social aspect to the game no stats, no confidants, nough problem? 
Now speed round
Story good, but ending is...similar to persona 5's end.
Combat is good, but easily broken with 99 luck and mudo/hama with a mudo/hama boost. At least for mobs.
No romance... HOW DARE YOU!!!
Character well Ryuji must have joined the navy because he's cursin like a sailor otherwise new characters are fine, and old characters are consistent.
Game overall? Well i think it's a  fun concept that needs more polish. I would enjoy seeing another game like this more in line with the classic confidant system, some better "levels/dungeons", and be a little more polished combat wise.
Should you buy this game? Yes, if you're fine with royal not being a thing, turn based combat being booted, and no confidant/social/romance system. It is a genuine good time, and i would recommend it.

While not as great of an addition to the main story as Persona 5 Royal was, Strikers has a lot of good things for fans of the previous games.

The music somehow just keeps getting BETTER, both for new tracks and remixes.

author: 94d4a8e6-68a0-557d-bb13-6dee3e015f17
content:
First things first, do NOT get this game if u have't played/watched Persona 5(royal) becouse its a direct sequel and u will enjoy  the game alot less if u have no idea what they are talking about most of the time.


Story.
Set a Half year after the events of Persona 5(not Royal) the Phantom Thieves come together to plan their one month of summer vacation only to be dragged into another Metaverse adventure as they discover that someone is stealing the desires of people(AKA brainwashing) and with the help of a police detective they go on a adventure all around Japan stealing hearts and kicking ass!

Gameplay.
In one word: Mindblowing.
The switch to realtime is making this game one hell of a slugfest while at the same time keeping the parts what makes Persona games unique in it, like using Persona abilities pauses the game allowing u to aim in piece and it also helps u make sense of it all, couse it can be quite chaotic at times, wich is this game only downside.

Outside of combat u explore the area's u are in, visit shops to buy items or do Requests while in your Hideout(mainly your camper) u can get ready for another  metaverse expidition by Cooking meals that give nice buffs or heals or visit Sophie's shop to get geared up.

All in all the game will take u around 40-50 hours but with New game plus also unlockable as well as Reckless Difficulty u can test yourself to your limits.

Music.
this part deserves special mention since the soundtrack is just unbelieveble good with remixes of various P5 tracks like Rivers in the Desert and Last Suprise and new ones like Daredevil and Grind Your Axe to listen to at just the right times.
The PC version also gives u ALL the previous Persona battle themes all back to persona 1 that u can switch to if u need something new,and u get the Persona 5 and royal tracks when u complete the game as well :)

All in all, this game is a must play for Persona 5 fans and really wraps up their story while also introducing u to some great new ones, and never really gets bored.
So a 11 out of 10 from me!

author: f8364623-bc47-533b-a976-569d2c814d51
content:
This game is great, its very much a mini sequel to P5, the story and all the new characters are all really interesting and kept me looking forward to playing after work each day, I've played a lot of musou type games and this one is a great blend of Personas turn based combat made real time and dialled up to 11, each character has their own style of play and combos then keep it interesting. Baton passes, 1 more attacks and all out attacks are all still there, even fusing new personas and collecting them from combat.

Overall if you enjoyed Persona 5 and/or Persona 5 Royal (this is a sequel to just base 5 though i believe), its well worth a buy if you don't like musou style games maybe wait till it goes on sale and give it a try, I'm having a blast so far.

content:
Persona 5 Strikers is an excellent sequel to Persona 5!
The plot is not as thorough as the original game, but it's still very rich and full with content.
The gameplay, particularly the combat, is very fun and dynamic. The Persona style translated very well into an action RPG hack-and-slash game and its numerous team compositions and individual character builds make the whole game's experience very exciting and worthwhile!
If you played Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal, this game is a must-play. If you haven't played either of them, you should play Persona 5 Royal and then you can come play this game.

author: 8fca3e23-f828-58c1-b3d2-057b3e907dfc
content:
This game is not a spin-off , this is a direct sequel to the original Persona 5.A really good sequel at that.
The story and characters are better than vanilla Persona 5 story (not as good as Royal) in my opinion.
The gameplay surprisingly fits well more than traditional turn-based combat.People say this is like Warriors combat and although that is true , this feels more like a fast-paced Final Fantasy 7 Remake's combat than traditional Warriors game.
Soundtracks are great , combat is fun , bosses require strategy and understanding of the system , characters are fun and the story is really gripping.
But I would not recommend this game to people who haven't play vanilla Persona 5.Since this is a sequel , a lot of the references will be lost to you and you won't be invested in the story and characters as much as those who have played the vanilla.

author: 41c9bd62-19bf-500a-b98c-467e0763052b
content:
[h1]Persona 5 Strikers is a good game[/h1]
[h1]But wait for a sale[/h1]

[u]Pros:[/u]
- All original voices are back (at least in English).
- New characters are good and feel natural to the P5 world.
- Persona collecting somehow still works despite the change in the combat mechanics.
- New locations and dungeons look great.
- Story doesn't completely suck despite it being a spinoff game.
- Zenkichi is best girl

Overall, I enjoyed Strikers a lot. The characters talking with each other felt as natural as it did in 5/Royal. Having the gang travel Japan was also a good decision, as it meant not being stuck in Tokyo the entire time (which they could've very easily done if they wanted).

[u]Cons:[/u]
-From a story standpoint, Royal is never mentioned. At all. Also, all non-party confidants (except three) never appear in the game.
-Game reminds you of romances, but doesn't actually care what you chose.
-Game doesn't do a good job of encouraging you to switch up party members, but still forces some party members in some select fights.
-Game isn't difficult (especially if you find the right item/bond build that allows you to mow over anything in the game).
-Lack of combo depth.
-Music is mostly P5 ost remixes with some new stuff (and overall, not as good as the original).
-Where is Igor?
-Play with a controller.
-Story doesn't understand it's own universe's rules.

To expand upon the last point, there are two times the game contradicts their own rules. First, in the first dungeon, it's shown that, besides the party, people enter the Jails as their shadows. However, the game breaks this rule several times, and doesn't explain why.
The second major gaffe: Morgana mentions at the very end of the game that its the "surprise of receiving a calling card" that causes Desires to manifest, similar to Treasures. This is just a flat wrong explanation of how the calling cards work from both P5/Royal, as well as from the same game.

As to the other points, the combat is basic and easy, and there are ways to break it (hint: Two things break shields. weaknesses and criticals) which makes combat a joke. I used Yusuke the entire game and wasn't really punished for it, which shouldn't be ok in a game that emphasized elemental affinities.

If you can get over these somewhat minor gripes, the game is fun. I would only recommend it if it gets a price cut or sale though.

author: 89f46a2f-6b08-51f3-a914-8e00d66c536e
content:
I would say an 8.5/10. Great game, but I've had my own wave of emotions playing it.

In my opinion, the game plays almost nothing like a normal musuo game. This is *very* Persona feeling, it's just not turned based. Taking advantage of elemental weakness is still EXTREMELY important (like every persona game) and I find myself rarely combo-ing normal enemies and only using it during bosses. Once you have SP items available the combat feels more like Persona 5 completely. Combo-ing becomes near useless.

My thoughts on the story and dungeon designs, I think the first half of the game is considerably better than the end half. There's some depth that is skipped for the last half of the game that makes me feel like things were rushed, or it felt like they had to piece things together in the middle, like they knew what they wanted but needed something there. Especially the final area, it felt SUPER short if you compared it to the first or second. It surprised me how fast I got to the final boss.

I don't know what people mean, I've only ever crashed once while playing the entire game. If you're crashing that often I honestly think your computer just can't handle the game? The game is well optimized in my opinion. The only other issue I had was my controller while playing registered A B and X all as the same input. I had to assign my controller on steam and that fixed it.

author: 8e44bb5f-4e20-5d56-801a-62967599e98d
content:
First of all. [h1] Hoooooo boy [/h1] Props to Omega-Force/Koei Tecmo, and P-Studio for making this game happened, and to Atlus for publishing this game to steam (praise be to Atlus). I will gladly buy any MegaTen related games.

Okay so, I'll make this as concise as possible.
The story (although a direct continuation from the base game) is basically a reimagine of Persona 5's with a bunch of changes specifically for this spin-off. I'm just gonna say it follows the same structure, that's it (for those who have played, you'll know what I mean). It actually reminds me of the movie called HER because of how the plot heavily uses artificial intelligence as its main topic. Expect a lot of dialogue since this is still a persona game.

The gameplay is good no doubt about that, actually great. Who knew that a game that uses the combination between musou combat with persona mechanics would actually work wonders, I never thought it would be this good. Each character you control has different combat style and special ability. It's really the highlight of this spin-off.

Probably the complains I have are the price and possibly, the end game content (I have my doubts on this one though) since when you finish the game, the only replayability value that this game will give you after finishing it are new game+ (you can totally 100% achievement in the 2nd playthrough) and a new difficulty. I really hope Atlus will update this game with new content, although it's unlikely to happen because this game was released in Japan a year ago and (to my knowledge) there had been no update since then.

All in all it's a good game, as expected of Atlus. Even though they really milk this series hard, you can bet the spin offs of each game are done and polished really friggin well. A definite must have for those who enjoy both persona and musou combat type of games.

author: 6255cac3-08f3-5394-b8f6-f8d9ffd7b8bb
content:
Persona 5 Strikers was the perfect sequel to Persona 5, and a great game overall! P5S prioritised the combat, rather then the social aspects of the game and broke the tradition of Persona by giving it an Hack n Slash styled combat system - and it worked well. It feels different in a good way but it still feels like Persona 5 with weapons and personas, fusions, items etc.

The story was just as good as Persona 5 and it was the perfect addition to the Persona 5 storyline.

To whether your an Persona 5 fan, or just starting the series, the game is for you but I highly recommend you play Persona 5 first anyway to understand the lore about the cognition, characters, etc.

author: 7458608c-b89f-5e96-8177-a6a7532ee6b0
content:
Toughest prison to break out is in your mind
Now, when I finished it on hard and started my merciless run I can write this rewiew
My Exp in Persona games consists of P4G, P5 and P5R
So, lets go to the diff, pros and contras

First and the most is new combat system. It's not turnbased. Check it before buying game, and if u dont dislike it just give this game a try. It's really nice!

Second thing you may dislike is new amount of social events. 
Days in P5S don't go one by one, but change, when you progress the story. Therefore there is no time for life events and social links like in normal persona game. 

Third thing, that makes game not so fun is persona fusing, I completely loved the system in P5R, but here your fuses give you less then something
Your personas can not change their combo abilities, there is no res/null/drain abilities, to give them in fusion. 
There is no itemize, but you dont really want to have skill cards, until its passive skill
And I dislike Persona Points, You just always make transition in buy fo yen/sell for points -> repeat 
I understand, that Null/Drain/Repel Yoshitsune completely breaks rules, but cmon. All this fuse circus always was about making incredible power level personas.
Here you fuse them,you can up their stats, but all this is just to don't suck at power level and have personas default drains/nulls.
I cant say that its minus, cos now fights are a little more about your dodges and combos, not about 1st turn hassou tobi. It's still about debilitate/Matarukaja+Masukukaja+Marakukaja, but now it's diffirent. Just give it a try

+++++++++++++++
Cooking and dialogues about food are awesome
Levels are memorable
Music (thanks to Lyn) is absolutely perfect, funky and took my heart

I recommend to buy this game to everyone. who isn't afraid of new combat system and wants to try something new with good old friends

author: 1affd0af-12ef-58d2-a7e8-62d0bb241fab
content:
This game is absolutely phenomenal.

I will start by saying that the Persona series is one of my favorite game series of all time, so it's not super surprising that I love this game. I was concerned at first that it was going to be more musou than Persona (as in, mostly focused on the combat rather than the story), but thankfully those concerns were immediately alleviated upon booting up the game. I'm not a huge musou fan, and I don't think I've ever unlocked New Game+ in a game that required you to do a bunch of extra stuff before, but I loved this game so much that I did every single quest and every single thing to unlock New Game+. The story really draws you in, and seeing all of the characters I love so much again made me so incredibly happy. I absolutely cried during the ending credits. 

The only issue I have with this game is the crashing -- I noticed it always happens for me on loading screens, and it can be extremely frustrating. Make sure you save as often as possible. Other than that, I have zero complaints. I love all of the new characters, the story, the music, the locations, the aesthetics, the cutscenes, everything. In fact, I love it so much that I started a new game immediately after completing everything in my first run! If you love Persona 5, this sequel is absolutely worth it. If you don't like musous, you can play on easy mode so you can just experience the story!

Now PLEASE bring Persona 5 Royal to Steam, Atlus!!!

author: e393b1ed-7ae9-5781-8402-39103004e8d4
content:
Persona 5 Strikers - Review

Holy crap.

Fast paced, 1v1000 battles, with the persona 5 cast is a interesting combination that, surprisingly works well for what it does. 

| THE GOOD

Now, if you want something pretty, I highly suggest you take your time to look around each Jail, examining each little nook and cranny. 

The music is PHENOMINAL. And if you have the extra music pack, that just ADDS more to it. 

The combat is fastpaced, and the difficulty of each encounter just becomes more fun.  (Despite... some issues)

The story in this game matches Persona 5's, as this spinoff follows the aftermath of P5S. 

| The Bad

The scaling of HP of basic trash mobs seems... excessively high. And that's just basically it. 

I am NOT a fan of how many skills that stop you from moving. Specifically, it feels like Bufu/Zio, and the certain debuffs that stun you, need to be nerfed in effectiveness. Also, FUCK YOUR COUCH, Sleep. 

And the biggest elephant in the room?
The crashing. 

Yeah, no. This game has a powerful crashing fetish. 
And the stutters become evident in the game...


|The Rating

While the game has it's flaws, the characters are charming, the combat is exciting, and in general the game feels difficult without being cheap. 

My rating is Four Stolen Desires out of five.

Although we can't get every aspect from Persona, i think this game has enough to satisfy me. The soundtracks are banger as usual, especially the new ones.
 
All in all, Persona 5 Strikers is a solid game. 9/10

author: 0734efd4-0366-5505-9765-347058f18713
content:
Another PC port from ATLUS! It's always great to see!

Persona 5 Strikers is a really unique spin on the Persona series. It takes the awesome world and characters of Persona 5 and mashes it with a real time combat system similar to the Hyrule Warriors series. I came into this game thinking I would be spamming my primary attack button to win, but was pleasantly surprised that it is far more diverse and dynamic than that. The way they crossed the Persona fusion system with all the Persona abilities with the Warriors battle system works so well and makes it way more engaging.

While I have not completed the entire story yet, what I have seen so far makes me feel like I never stopped playing Persona 5. The characters' stories and the voice acting is still the same greatness from Persona 5 and it really almost feels like a true sequel to the game. Definitely would recommend to anyone who has played Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal.

My only gripe with this game.. is the PC Port. Unfortunately, Koei Tecmo was involved in the development of this game, meaning the PC Port is definitely gonna have some issues. For one, the game is capped to 60 FPS, which is an improvement compared to Persona 5 Royal's 30 fps, it is definitely disappointing there isn't a way to uncap the frame rate like in ATLUS's port of Persona 4 Golden. The anti-aliasing is also very lazy and makes the in-game menus look very blurry, and the character models will also look very aliasied unless you turn the Resolution Scale up to 2.0 (in my experience). The game still runs great, but the port itself still feels pretty lazy and feels like they didn't even try to adjust it for the PC like they did with Persona 4 Golden.

author: 2d5d5c33-ddcc-5724-aba3-2af4db9479bd
content:
I have played almost every game after P4G, including all the games that are related to P5. I would say that this is a great spinoff of the original P5 and it is really a great game for fans.

After the boss fight the game crashes suddenly without saving, and there are really a lot of crashes.
I hope whoever has brought the port to PC will really fix the problem.

The game itself resembles the structure of P5 (not p5r) and while it is Persona enough, I wouldn't really consider it a game that is worth the full price tag. Also, while the combat is a great combination of real-time combat and the traditional P5 skills, I do think think that it is somewhat too flashy. 
If you have played P5 before, you can easily tell the similarity and the parallel structure, and I would say that P5S is really an attempt to use the same structure to tell a somewhat different story. It has the core of the later part of P5R and the narrative structure of original P5.

Great music, great artwork, great Japanese VA. There are no complaints about the game itself beside the crashes. It is a solid game when on sale, and the price tag is not fully justified with its current length.

Overall, I would give it s 8/10. Solid for P5 fans, but not so worth the full price otherwise.

author: 59c60019-2906-5e05-982c-7a7d0fc1c8b2
content:
This game isn't just some Dynasty Warriors reskin, it's not a Persona cashgrab, Persona 5 Strikers is a fully fledged sequel to the original Persona 5 with more than enough content to be thought of as a true persona game. After 100+ Hours in this game I can happily say this is another fantastic game by Atlus (and KT this time).

[h1] MINIMAL STORY SPOILERS AHEAD[/h1]

[b] Overview[/b]
The Phantom Thieves are back and they are prepared to journey across Japan. Strikers' world building feels great, even whist travelling from Tokyo to Sendai, Sapporo, Okinawa, Kyoto, Fu.kuoka and Osaka in the space of 1 month and exploring jails as they go. Each city looks fantastic and are all very lively, an improvement on Persona 5. Though the combat may look a little intimidating to long time Persona fans it feels more at home with the actual combat the Phantom Thieves would go through. The beginning, middle and end of the game is consistently great and Atlus & KT gave a masterpiece such as Persona 5 a sequel it deserved.

[b] Gameplay[/b]
This time around the Phantom Thieves are tasked at exploring Jails across Japan, city-sized palaces ruled by some of the most powerful people in Japan. To fit the combat of Strikers, Jails are much larger than Palaces found in Persona 5 but are still filled with small details the can really grab your eye. A lot of enjoyment can be gained from just running around these Jails and mopping up shadows just for fun. 
As I mentioned before the combat is rather different than your traditional SMT or Persona game, but the most pivotal mechanics are still used in Strikers. Every Phantom Thief has their original personas and skills but all have a unique playstyle for you to experience and decide on your 'main'. Joker still has his wildcard ability, but due to the lack of Igor in the velvet room he only has access to half the personas available in Persona 5. Their different weapons and guns make for a whole new experience depending on who you use, and their weapon actually changes in their hand if you buy a new one.
[list]
[*] [b] Joker[/b] - Access to all elements, fast attacks and an all-around beginners character
[*] [b] Ryuji[/b] - Electric user, Slower bat attacks but do much more damage, focus on Physical skills and tanking
[*] [b] Ann[/b] - Fire user, Fast whip attacks and fastest gun (Sub-Machine gun), focus on magic skills
[*] [b] Morgana[/b] - Wind user, Fast sword attacks with a lot or aerial usage, mainly a healer
[*] [b] Yusuke[/b] - Ice user, Normal sword attacks but with flurry combos, crit monster, focus on Physical attacks
[*] [b] Makoto[/b] - Nuclear user, Normal fist attacks, all around nuclear powerhouse, an all-around character
[*] [b] Futaba[/b] - Navigator, non-playable but can provide buffs, healing and protection for the team.
[*] [b] Haru[/b] - Psy user, Very slow axe attacks but with very high damage, focus on gun attacks and combo skills
[*] [b] Sophia[/b] - Bless user, Fast Yo-yo attacks with a Rhythm mechanic, high-skill based character but can be used as a healer[/list]

[b] Overworld[/b]
The lack of 'daily life' of this game may put off a few from picking this game up, but the amount of interaction in the overworld decently makes up for it's absence. Every city has many NPCs to interact with and all shopkeepers have their own dialogue (and there are a lot of shops). After progression in the story the Phantom Thieves may be standing around town with dialogue of their own [strike] unfortunately it is not voiced[/strike]. They may also hand you requests which furthers the level of interaction you get from your long time allies. Every city looks vastly different from the next with their very own top tier theme, which really helps set each city apart from another. 

[b] Music[/b]
C'mon, it's a Persona game, you should know by now that is has fantastic music, and this game is certainly no exception. From the opening theme all the way till the credits song, in my opinion there is no bad or even mediocre track in the entire soundtrack. Every song fits the theme it requires and makes you want to explore each area in depth just to listen to the smooth Jazz. Speaking of which, p5's Jazz theme has not disappeared, though there is a bit of a metal theme for the more intense battles, which fits the high paced combat perfectly. It's another fantastic job by Shoji Meguro, Lyn, and the whole Atlus sound team.

[b] Graphics and Performance[/b]
Strikers is a pretty good looking game, the art style of Persona 5 compliments the gameplay of Strikers, using the bold lines and bright colours doesn't get you lost in the fast-paced gameplay. The menu's are the best Persona has ever done, with smooth transitions and every character having a cameo in different sections of the menu. Unfortunately this game was also developed for the switch, which limited how far they could take the graphical aspect of the game. Also this PC port is not the greatest, the cause is unknown but on some systems certain cutscenes will crash the game if viewed in fullscreen. It isn't very well optimised either, enemies will lag out the game using Agidyne, and text looks grainy due to Anti-Aliasing. Overall this doesn't effect the experience too much but it is something to keep in mind if you are debating between buying Strikers on PC or PS4

[b] Story[/b]
This is where Persona 5 Strikers really surprised me, as a spinoff I expected a toned down story filled with fanservice to keep the players happy but no. Strikers has a very 'persona-like' story, without the social links. Without a need to build characters (except the few new introductions) Atlus was able to fully focus on the story and make it great from the beginning until the end. The story starts a little weak but really picks up and is definitely on the level of a mainline Persona game story. Each new character fits perfectly into the story and each have their own role to play.

[b] Characters[/b]
Since this is a sequel to Persona 5 and not Royal, this game does lack Kasumi and any mention of Maruki, but the rest of the Phantom Thieves make their appearance with a new ally - Sophia, a sketchy detective -Zenkichi Hasegawa and an upbeat woman of tech - Kuon Ichinose.
Sophia is 'Humanity's Companion,' an AI Joker discovers in the depths of a Jail. Her main derivative is to learn, as she lost her memory after being dumped into this jail. She accompanies the Phantom Thieves in their trip, inside Joker's phone.  She's bright and bubbly and quite similar to Aigis from Persona 3.
Zenkichi is an employee of Public Security and has been tasked in researching the 'change of heart' epidemic that has swept across Japan. He may be a friend or foe but one thing is for sure, he'll be on your tail this whole trip.
Ichinose is a quirky tech guru that just loves her coding. She just happens to come across the Phantom Thieves and is a HUGE fan. She happily starts working with them to find the true culprit changing these hearts.

[b] Final Thoughts[/b]
Persona 5 Strikers is a great game to pick up if you're a fan of Persona or hack n slash musou games in general. There is over 100 hours worth of gameplay (including postgame) and it never gets stale. Merciless provides a great challenge in New Game+ and lets you listen to the amazing soundtrack even more.

[h1] FINAL SCORE: 9.1/10[/h1]

author: ca2a51b6-f209-535a-880f-52664f00b6bc
content:
As a fan of Persona 4 and 5, i cannot recommend this. Yes, it is more of a Persona game than just a musou slasher, it has lovable characters, some sort of a plot and the same world we all love.

But.
The game has a clunky combat system (And I MEAN IT, i cannot enjoy the combat after Honkai Impact, a mobile game), mediocre camera, always-tight-and-cramped combat areas, non-intiuitive dodge system that cannot guarantee a dodge, unlikeable healing system. DMG-sponge minibosses that WILL hit you back because dodge is broken.

What's happening on the screen looks like a mess. A magnitude of monsters on the screen, flashes and damage numbers everywhere... you cannot enjoy your characters or cool combat moves because you basically see anything. 

I do not like the way they handled "no time limit" design while trying to squeeze it into the old idea of having a calendar. Basically, you can visit the dungeon as many times in a row as you like. And you do not need to visit the shops or town activities because this time you buy stuff "online" and there's no social progression save for a generic "bond level" for the whole group that gives you skill points. So, my problem with the whole thing is it's ruining the world, your impression and your affection for the game. During the time you are playing through a dungeon, you leave it to replenish HP\SP, you appear in the Cafe with the old man Sakura standing and looking at you, then you immediately go back, manage your inventory via a menu, go to a dungeon, fight, leave, replenish, go to a dungeon, back to cafe.... all in the same day. Completely ruins the Persona mood for me.

And all the game is feeling like it's repetative and trying to waste your time. Yeah, you get "palaces" again, but this time with more of a free-roam. You get your main objective at point A but it's locked and you have to visit locations B,C,D to get some shining orb and fight a miniboss. But guess what, at objective D you need to unlock the last door by ... guess what? Pulling levers E,F,G in location D.

At this point i got bored. If you like this kind of games - give it a shot.

author: 04ad2d25-0606-5e5d-afdf-4d931a9242a3
content:
[h1] Is this game any good? [/h1]

Short Answer: Yes

Long Answer: Holy crap, the game starts out strong and reels you in with a strong start. The music, the visuals, and the combat.

[b] The Combat [/b]

The combat is fun, all characters have their strengths and weaknesses. While some characters might be useful against certain types of enemies, they could also be vulnerable to other types of enemies. Every character also has their own unique moveset and combo list. 

[b] The Music [/b] 

The music is beautiful, the combat themes, the city themes, the Jail/Dungeon themes. Most games always have an outstanding OST, but they are mainly grounded to big scenarios like boss fights, or alike. However, in this game the music is always charming and the smaller tracks are just as good as the bigger tracks.

[b] The Issues [/b]

There is not much to complain about though there are a few mishaps.
For starters, there are a few times where the game crashes and since this game functions on a checkpoint and manual save system it is a bit distressing having to replay an a chunk of the game due to the game crashing.

Also a tiny thing is how every time you begin a battle the combat theme will begin playing, but as soon as you finish the fight and get into another the combat theme will play again from the beginning. Though this isn't all too annoying since this game is a spin off from the Persona series where having to hear the same combat theme is something that always happens, which makes this problem a minor one.

[h1] Final Verdict [/h1]

[b] Zenkichi best girl [/b]

author: 9b937a5e-7908-5b71-a721-9c076460bb03
content:
If you're already a fan of Persona 5 and you're itching for more, this title is worth your time.

This title oozes with the same style and poise that Persona 5 has. The Dynasty Warriors combat mechanics work surprisingly well with the Persona conventions you're used to, so adjusting to this gameplay style is easier than you think. Each character is interesting and fun to play with in their own way, and you're properly incentivized to use all of them in different compositions throughout the game.

Aside from the combat, the rest of the game is familiar territory: Good story, great voice acting and character dynamics, excellent new music (and fantastic mixes on existing tracks), and a few cool surprises. Despite its nature as a genre and studio crossover, this is a genuine Persona game.

If you're [i] not [/i] a Persona fan already, this one might be a difficult game to sell you on. It's a follow-up with a very involved story that demands knowledge of the original to fully understand. If you don't have access to Persona 5, I would greatly recommend holding off until you play that masterpiece (let's hope they port it to PC). This is a sequel and better experienced after the original; it is not a standalone game.

I don't really have much to criticize here. The only minor complaint I had at all was about the frequency of tutorial interrupts toward the beginning of the game. If you're already familiar with the Persona conventions, there should be an option to prevent or skip those kind of pop-ups and show only the ones relevant to new mechanics like the combat. Especially since the majority of players of this game are likely Persona vets.

author: ddbcc7be-2a39-5647-bdcf-e2a3b877a048
content:
Persona 5 Strikers is a fantastic JRPG not just because of how it tells a fantastic story with a set of loveable and memorable characters but also because of how it retains the feeling of playing Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal. The Phantom Thieves, The Mind Blowing Eargasm Soundtrack, the Cinematic Show time and All out Attacks, the Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal design has been also given to Persona 5 Strikers from the layout to the games menu to the animations and cut scenes to the city of Japan to the dungeon which were formally known as Palaces in the meta verse now known as Jails. The Fantastic Story exploring the Meta verse and the "Inside of humanity" also known as their Shadow while life in the real world goes on as the Protagonist and the rest of the Phantom Thieves are on Summer vacation when things start to go downhill. Persona 5 Strikers is as good as a Season 2 of Persona 5 Apart from missing a few signature system such as Social Links from past Persona games.

Story and Game Structure: 
Persona 5 Strikers takes place and continues the story from Persona 5, just pretend Persona 5 Royal didnt happen and i have to pretend i did not romance Yoshizawa Kasumi the new girl from Persona 5 Royal which was not in Persona 5. Persona 5 Strikers continues to explore the world of the Metaverse and the "Inside of humanity" also known as their Shadow. The Phantom thieves are back in action to return the desires that have been stolen to their owners while also problem solving the change of hearts not by done by them to the Citizens of Japan, while the threat of the Japanese Bureau persecuting the group looms around. Given how Persona 5 Strikers has been made to be a 2nd Season of Persona 5, it is impressive that it retains the feel and Atmosphere that Persona 5 has. 

The most noteable change to Persona 5 Strikers is probably the confidance system and the velvet room, the velvet room changes make Persona 5 Strikers persona fusion much simpler but the loss of confidance system and side stories that accompany them is what diverges from what a propa Persona 5 Season 2 might be. Instead you gain bond points from fighting along side with the Phantom Thieves or real time events or cooking. While these bond points allowed me to unlock new passive skills and upgrade them, i miss hanging out with the indivisual members of the Phantom Thieves hanging out with them during free time and seeing their side  PeRsOnA-L stories. Not that i mind spending less than 10 000 hours on a Persona game but i can spend any amount of time hanging out with the Phantom thieves even if it means to stop playing other games

Characters, Soundtrack and Atmosphere:
Throughout Persona 5 Strikers the Phantom Thieves travel to different locations not just in Japan around Tokyo but to Hokkaido and Okinawa during their summer trip plus investigations but also in the meta verse where combat takes place at. The Dugenons formally known as Palaces in Persona 5 and Royal are now known as Jails and they are large and can take hours to complete. Since the jails that you are fighting in transforms the city around you, travelling back and fourth from the Jails and the real world to stock up on items and replenish HP and SP without taking up time in the real world  from previous Persona games has been implemented in Strikers which makes. Exploring different parts of Tokyo and Japan is a lot of fun just like Persona 5 or Royal even if its for the simplest things such as stocking up on items. Both the Duengons and the Map of Persona 5 Strikers are well desgin and made to be memorable. 

The fan favourite Phantom Thieves are back along side new addition Sophia (Rip Kasumi Yoshizawa from Persona 5 Royal) and i don't think there is any game that i have played that has any more memorable characters than those from the Persona 5 series, while also having different personalities they each have something that will make you fall in love with them. The voice acting and animations are also are very well done. Persona 5 Strikers sound track just like any other Persona game i have played is also mind blowing, memorable and just way too good that it gives me and Ear gasm whenever i am listening to it.

Combat:
Persona 5 Strikers introduce a totally different style in combat by making players stratagize the use of their Persona skills and other mechanics that were from Persona 5 and Persona 5 Royal such as the gun mechanics and the cinematic all out attacks and Show Time attacks. Fighting in Persona 5 Strikers feels good as it feels like im playing Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal using my Persona skills but also combo-ing skills with the Phantom Thieves that i choose to play as not to mention the different personallties of each character and variety of skills and combos they have. Making use of the enemys weakness in Persona 5 Strikers and using Persona skills is also a important aspect of Persona 5 Strikers as you will want to do enough damage to their weak point to use a All out or Show time attack especially against Bosses and higher level enemys since they usually have a large health pool and can soak up a lot of damage. Every Phantom Thieve in Persona 5 Strikers is playable and they each have different fighting styles and combos you can have up to 4 members of the Phantom Thieves in your party however Joker must be in the squad no matter who you choose to have along side with him. The strategy base mechanics such as using Persona Skills switching members of your party or switching the Phantom Thieve that your are currently playing as becomes even more important or harder difficulties.

Pros:
-The Story of Persona 5 Season 2
-Retains the Feel of Persona 5 and Persona 5 Royal
-Real time combat with turn base mechanics such as Persona Skils etc while also carrying over Persona 5 and Persona 5 Royal mechanincs such as Show-time attacks, Gun uasge and All out attacks etc
-Mind Blowing Ear-gasm Soundtrack
-Map and Duengon aka Jails Design
-Voice Acting and Characters

Cons:
-Occasional Crashes on patch 1.0
-Unanswered answers for players yet to Play Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal
-No Confidance system
-Slice of Life system from calander has been cut down

Verdict:
Persona 5 Strikers story is what a Persona 5 Season 2 might be making this summer vacation and road trip around Japan fun, memorable and loving for fans of Persona 5 and Royal but confusing for anyone new to it.  Persona 5 is one of my favourite JRPGS, it has a mind blowing soundtrack, its world is immersive and relatable filled with loveable and memorable characters and supporting characters alongside a really rich story. The only let down being the Confidance System and the Slice of Life Calander system from previous titles which was missing.

author: eb0ed969-1bb1-522e-8950-e840aa320a5b
content:
The original Persona 5 is my favorite JRPG of all time, so when I heard that it was getting a Warriors-style spin-off, I was interested but not super excited. I had played Hyrule Warriors and enjoyed it quite a bit but I thought it was lacking in the story department. As more information came out about Persona 5 Strikers (or Scramble: The Phantom Strikers as the fan base knew it before it was localized) it was revealed that it was actually a full-blown sequel to the original game in the style of an action RPG. Now, this was something I could get excited about!

Now that I have finished it, I can say it is a worthy successor to one of my favorite games of all time. Sure, a lot of the social aspects are gone, but that isn't really what Strikers is about. Strikers is a hack and slash road trip for the beloved Phantom Thieves, so if you love P5's cast you'll feel right at home here. HOWEVER, DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME WITHOUT PLAYING PERSONA 5. The game assumes you're familiar with the world of that game, and you'd be doing yourself a disservice by spoiling the plot of the original game. Seriously, either find a PS4 to play it or hold out a bit longer for a PC port.

As for the game itself, I found it plays more like Kingdom Hearts than Dynasty Warriors. The combat is fluid and brain-numbingly fun. Each character has unique quirks that make them exciting and fun to play as. Being able to switch between them at a moment's notice makes the combat constantly feel fresh. My only real complaint about the game is that some of the dungeons feel a little hollow, and I think the story leans too heavily into the themes of the first game. Atlus had the opportunity to do something really interesting here, and they do with the addition of some new characters. But a lot of the plot, especially near the end, feels like a retread.

In short, if you're a fan of Persona 5 this is a must-buy. If not, go play the original game and come back to this. I promise you, the style, characters, and story of these games are so instantly loveable and well worth the time sink.

Until next time, Phantom Thieves.

8/10

author: c7ba42dc-27bc-5a1b-a45f-8da36a904184
content:
A really great game definitely worth your time.

At first glance it seems like a Warriors-style game but truly it's not that simple, in fact it's far more accurate to say it's alike Persona 5 but with the turn based battles changed for action rpg style combat. 
Don't come in expecting to be able to just button spam your way through battles, you're going to need strategy to defeat what comes in your way, and that's playing on Normal difficulty too. 

As for the story it's honestly great, I got this game expecting it to be some minor side thing and I got essentially a sequel game with it's own great story. It doesn't quite reach the level of Persona 5's story, but it's still up there on the story tiers. 

The new music tracks in the game are also fantastic, including adding probably my most favourite new battle theme in the Persona series to date. [spoiler]Counter Strike[/spoiler]

It does seem to have some issues of crashing between load zones rarely and bouts of lag in cutscenes or large areas that tear the audio, though my processor is lower than minimum required so that may be more a me problem than the game. 

Despite those problems, I have thoroughly enjoyed what this game has offered. And as of now still have more content to finish up on it. [i]~34 hours of in-game playtime, many of my steam-tracked hours are idling with game on background.[/i]

author: 35c7eaf3-5c8c-5d00-8813-aec0a4b6c82f
content:
Лично я бы предпочёл оригинал, но и Strikers неплоха.

Новая боёвка, несмотря на какую-никакую глубину со слабостями, иногда превращающееся в бездумное кнопкожмакание. Почти все социальные механики вырезали, остлся только один уровень прокачиваемый соц-ивентами и битвами, который отвечает за улучшение перков команды. Необходимость распределять время исчезла полностью, время идёт только тогда когда это нужно сюжету.

История, как ине кажеться, больше понравиться людям игравшим в оригинал. Так как Strikers довольно редко ссылается на события оригинала, что приводит к сабому раскрытию старых персонажей для новых игроков. Новые персонажи доволно интересные, какими они и должны быть учитывая что иммено на них в конце концов сосредотачиваеться сюжет. Сюжет в начале довольно медленный и на мой взгляд скучноватый, по крайней мере до саппоро.

Также у ПК порта есть несколько проблем на данный момент:
-Антиалязинг который не только почти не работает, но ещё и ломает шрифт.
-Таксебе оптимизация. Я пробовал несколько настроек и на всех получал примероно 45 fps поэтому играл с локом на 30.
-Подлагивание cg катсцен причём аниме катсцены идут нормально, но прирендыры теряют фреймы

Лично для меня Strikers стоит своих денег. И я посоветовал бы игру любому кто играл в оригинал и хочет ещё Фантомных Воров.

author: 78a926c6-182b-5607-ba12-1209b46cff3a
content:
Strikers had a lot to live up to as a sequel to one of the best JRPGs of all time, but it somehow delivered. Even though it transitioned from a turn-based RPG to an action-based musou game, it still feels very much like Persona, with every gameplay staple intact. Weaknesses, technicals, elements, baton pass, and more; all wrapped up in a sexy and stylish art style and UI that's basically Persona 5's trademark. I often get bored of musou games very quickly because of it's extremely repetitive nature and simplistic combat, but Strikers does not have this problem at all since, like I mentioned, it has all of the gameplay staples you'd expect from a Persona game, which wildly varies the gameplay and always keeps you on your toes; especially if you play on higher difficulties. The SP system is also back where you can't recharge SP unless you return to the real world, or use items which are either expensive or hard to come by. This encourage you to constantly swap party members so you keep your gameplay variety fresh and entertaining (along with characters getting new passives or skills the more you play as them).

The only negatives I can really say about Strikers is that there is significantly less real-life activities to do. They are still there, and you can explore and talk to people, but the volume of stuff you can do is significantly lessened from P5. This is because you no longer have a time limit to complete your objective in the metaverse. If you never played Persona 5, this won't really mean anything to you, but to those who have played it, you probably should know that.

author: 2598e861-f38f-561b-a506-a770ffad7912
content:
Highly recommend it. Playing Persona 5/Persona 5 Royal is not necessary to follow the story, but it does enrich the experience. The characters are fun as always - including the new ones - and the combat actually has a fair amount of depth to it. It uses a lot of the Persona from P5 in a sort of action-rpg type of way, slowing down time to allow the player to pick the correct ability. Also, each playable character has their own unique mechanics, so while you can switch freely between each character and know basically how to play them, there is definitely room to improve with them. All the characters are viable, so I found myself switching them to fit the situation.

The music is... [i]chef's kiss[/i]. 

The only gripe I have about the game is the lack of social links, or rather the opportunities they offered to spend time with the characters. The Bond system is sort of the replacement here, with completing certain social activities gives points that are dropped into stat-enhancing modifiers, and the ability to unlock new modifiers by doing requests for different characters.

I hope the release of this game and Persona 4 Golden on Steam are signs that Atlus will be bringing Persona 5 Royal to PC, but in the meantime this will do just fine. P5S stands on its own with a well-written story, gratifying gameplay and a reunion (or introduction) with this series' lovable thieves.

author: ee41125d-f01b-5cfc-bac4-c99c277a9fa4
content:
Haven't finished the game as of this review, but from what I've experienced so far this game has been a lot better than I thought it would be! I've played Personas 3-5, so hearing that Persona 5 Strikers was gonna be a Dynasty Warriors type game, a genre that I've never tried before, I was skeptical but still wanted to experience the story and see the Phantom Thieves again. Everything this game has shown off to me has put a big dumb smile on my face. The great combat system and bond point system, the returning music tracks along with new ones are always amazing, and the new characters that this game introduces are all great. If you're like me and have played Persona 5 but are on the ropes about trying this game, I highly recommend. Do be aware though, this game takes place after the events of the original Persona 5, not Royal. So don't expect there to be any references or any characters exclusive to Persona 5 Royal. I do also highly advise playing the original or Persona 5 Royal before playing this game in order to understand the Phantom Thieves more and so you're not completely confused on the story. Definitely a worthy GOTY candidate.

10/10

author: 82d88fa4-3f7d-5da0-bb7d-73b9f8299dd8
content:
A fantastic game, though not without its flaws

[h1]Story[/h1]

Though the game's story is absolutely great in Persona fashion, it doesn't explore any new themes that Persona 5 Royal hasn't already. It feels like the same story of Persona 5 Royal, only with a different coat of paint. Some of the plot twists in the story (at least imo) can be seen coming a mile away if you pay attention. If you haven't played Persona 5 Royal, I guarantee you'll love this game's story, but if you have, just be warned that it might feel repetitive.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

The gameplay in my opinion is hardest in the midgame, when enemies are becoming difficult and you have to strategize to capitalize on their weaknesses as well as dodge their strong attacks. Lategame just becomes a cycle of spamming effective skills to stunlock, AOA, repeat until dead, top off SP as needed with items. I did play on the normal difficulty however, so YMMV.

[h1]Verdict[/h1]

A great game in the Persona series, though not without its problems and caveats, but if you're willing to overlook them, I guarantee you that you will enjoy this game, provided you enjoy Warriors-style gameplay loops.

Also, Sophie is best girl.

author: 50da0ce9-754e-545d-bb94-f404fa76213e
content:
Finished the game yesterday, would highly recommend to anyone who enjoyed the original game and its characters!

I was very pleasantly surprised by how substantial the game turned out to be -- My save logged 38 hours, and I kinda rushed through the game because I was so invested in the story, so other people might have longer times if they went out of their way to do all the optional content as well.

Loved all the interactions between the original cast, the new additions of Zenkichi and Sophia were absolutely fantastic and played off the main group wonderfully, the soundtrack is phenomenal (as was to be expected, really), the story was fun and in true Persona fashion, the combat was fun and all in all I basically found myself unable to put the game down until I beat it, lol. Speaking of the combat, I really love the showtime and all-out attack mechanics! They're super extra and I love it whenever I get the chance to use one.

The plot of the game may have been a little predictable in some areas *because* it was in true Persona fashion, but it really did not feel detrimental to the game at all and it was still a very enjoyable experience regardless (and it also felt very nice to have a theory forming in your head to turn out to be true too)!

All in all, P5S really felt like a good and proper sequel game to me despite it not being in the classic Persona game format. Fun, flashy and memorable, this game is definitely going to be on my mind for a while.

author: 42be1792-ba5c-5b8d-8ac9-bf02b8e703c8
content: P5R was my first ever Persona game. I had always wanted to get into the series, but just never found the time to until recently, and instantly I was hooked in every aspect. So when I heard that P5 was getting the musou treatment? I just had to buy it. All 29 hours I have so far, and I've only just begun the third dungeon. I love this game to death and will sing it's highest praises to anyone who will listen. My only gripe with it though is that it isn't musou enough for me, and the ambush mechanic seems a tad overpowered in this. A couple of friends have told me that bumping up the difficulty alleviates that some, but I can personally manage. I just wish we could of gotten tons of shadows on screen at once like you do in some fights instead of those you quickly ambush, push one button, and then instantly win the fight.

content: Very fun. Gameplay is super smooth and fast if you know the combos well. I have to say the camera is a little wonky at times but it the combat and story makes up for it. Though I wouldn't recommend anyone buy this game (at full price) if they haven't played Persona 5 yet. There's no big introduction to the main cast and there's references to P5 that you'd have to play to understand.

author: c7b8a14b-156b-512a-ad00-8d8c5180fbc6
content:
This game is a must buy for people who have played the original or the Royal version of Persona 5 (or at least in cases have watched a playthrough). The story is as funny and emotional as ever and there are improvements on almost every level; The music is great, the characters still keep their development from the last game, the UI somehow tops the original, and the combat is very fun and addicting. I would suggest this game for everybody but the characters often refrence moments and characters from the original game and don't explain complex things over again like the metaverse or Morgana.

This section is to grade how worth it the digital deluxe edition is:
The digital deluxe edition is hard to say the quality off. In order to access the content you need to push the Play button specifically in Steam for the game and it will ask whether you want to play the game or the 'app'. The quality of the app is very sketchy as right from the start it has a Unity watermark at the beginning. It gives you a Digital Art Book, A Behind the Scenes Video, and a Soundtrack Player:

Digital Art Book:
The digital art book was disappointing to me. It is nice to see the artwork and some concept art here and there it doesn't have any writing from the artists about what they were trying to do or the challenges they had to face in making it. This is the worst part of the package.

Behind the Scenes Video:
The behind the scenes video is pretty much a non narrated documentary that shows how Lyn and Lotus Juice made the opening song "You Are Stronger". It mostly focuses on the difficulties of having a non native speaker sing english and it really shows how they are masters of their craft, so much so to where Lyn was able to find out that the reason her singing sound off was because the mic was just 2 inches too low, which is very impressive to me. I'd say if you like Behind the Scenes and Filmmakers commentaries you'll like this, however it should be really easy to find it on youtube.

Soundtrack Player:
The soundtrack player is ok. It just feels like a standard music player with a Persona Skin layered over it. The main thing that sucks about it is that you can only listen to the tracks in this player and have to have it open in order to listen to them, no downloads. You're better off just finding the soundtrack on youtube.

The main reason for wanting to spend $10 extra dollars though would be to have the music play in game. You get some in game items that you won't care about but when you get this edition you get the battle themes of every main line persona game!... except for Persona 5 and Royal... from what I heard you have to have save data from those games in order to get those tracks... which means only Playstation players can get them. However, it is really cool hearing music like, Mass Destruction or Reach Out to the Truth play when you start combat, it even has music from Persona 1 as well which I do not know the name of but really like. If you like these tracks than its only 10 bucks and you get to pick which tracks you dont want to here and in each battle they will randomize which track you get.

author: 3da8e22b-9034-532c-b738-5c73e5f1a0b8
content:
Persona 5 Strikers was exactly what I wanted in an action Persona game. It faithfully implements mechanics from the rest of the series in an action combat form. If you play on hard mode, it's a significant challenge and much more fun, as you have to pay attention to what skills the enemies are using on screen.

You probably should play Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal first, as there's a lot of references to it that you might miss. You also won't have context on who all these characters are, as the game seems to expect you to know them already for the most part.

You might think with Koei Tecmo/Omega Force's involvement in development, that this is a musou/warriors game. It is definitely not. It's an action RPG. There are only mini-hordes of enemies, and you actually have to watch what all the little enemies are doing, as the skills they use can cripple you in an instant. You initiate combat on shadows walking around, that burst into multiple enemies. You want to try to be stealthy so you do not end up in a fight you can't win, as well as raising security level in the Jail.

If you like Persona games (or even Shin Megami Tensei games), I highly recommend checking this out. The story can be a bit nonsense sometimes, but is fun nonetheless. There is no calendar time slot system like in Persona 5. The calendar only moves on with certain story events. You can enter and exit dungeons all you want, and the day will still stay the same.

author: c0adecd4-08f8-53e1-be2e-8d421cc5c4bb
content:
*IMPORTANT* 
This game crashes ALOT, at the worst time possible. I'm not sure why; to make things worse, the checkpoints to save the game are quite far in between so uhh, the anxiety of hoping the game won't crash while you're far away from a save point is stressful. So if you're playing, remember to save as many times as possible. Redoing what you did from the past 3 hours is not fun. 

Anyways, Persona 5 Strikers is a nice sequel for fans of Persona 5 (Royal). However, the combat is a musou-type game, being completely different from Persona 5's turn based combat. Although, it is very interesting to see how they incorporated hack and slash with the tactical use of personas & baton passes.

The overworld exploration is satisfying, being able to walk around Shibuya, Sapporo, Osaka, and so on with your pals is a nice feeling. 

One thing to note is how the new Velvet Room functions. With the removal of social links, you can't get bonus exp for your personas from social links. Instead you can level up your personas through the use of PPs (Persona Points) which is a little disappointing but it's fine.

To further explain on the removal of social links, Persona 5 Strikers introduces a mechanic called Bonds to replace it. With bonds, you may unlock certain bonus perks like "Extra Money Dropped Per Battle" & so on. You can get bond points from playing through the game.

It's a game to play if you're interested to see what's up with the Phantom Friends after the first game. Not so for the depth of the combat/gameplay, Persona 5 (Royal) still triumphs on that part. 

Some mechanics from the first game were revamped or changed to be better/worse. It's up to you to make your own opinion on it.

author: 524db83f-b095-566d-a10d-22312eccc5ca
content:
If you're eye-ing this game then that means a few things: you either played Persona 5/Royal and want more of that, or if you're strictly PC, you're coming from Persona 4 Golden and are curious about this game. Overall Persona 5 Strikers is a unique take on the Persona franchise, and a summary of my thoughts on it could be summed up to *almost* more of the same if you're coming from Persona 5, or a somewhat familiar but also not-so familiar experience if you're coming from Persona 4 Golden, even though this installment in the series has wildly different gameplay from both Persona 5 *and* Persona 4 Golden. Details below.

Before I talk about anything else though, discussing the story must come first, as Persona 5 Strikers is set *after* the events of the main game of Persona 5 (NOT Royal, as I believe Strikers was released in Japan before Royal debuted anywhere). Following that, naturally the experience is enhanced if you have played Persona 5 from start to finish, and a few things about the mainline title are naturally spoiled. THAT SAID, Strikers actually does a very good job of being vague to the events of Persona 5 with the least amount of spoilers possible, so you can absolutely get away with playing this without playing Persona 5 first. Just be warned that a few things *are* spoiled, so it's definitely not spoiler free.

Moving right along, the plot is written very well I thought; I went into this not actually expecting much, but I came out of it pleasantly surprised. Strikers' storytelling is identical to that of Persona 5 (surprising absolutely nobody), except this time all of your party members are right there from the get go. ATLUS introduces the new characters very nicely; I was fully expecting the new characters to feel a little awkward and forced, but they quickly found their place within the rest of the cast, and by the end they felt like they belonged and have been there all along. At some points, I felt as if Strikers had even stronger story points than Persona 5.

The gameplay I thought was unique; this game is a full on hack-n-slash beat-em-up type of game, which is very different from the main titles in this franchise. A word of warning that it never really changes its combat up too much throughout the entire game, so it becomes repetitive after a while. I frequently had to take breaks because of how repetitive it can get, and I found myself thinking that taking on additional requests that you get throughout the game to be kind of a chore since there's no real variety in the requests that you get. However, what *is* there is fun; the hack and slash combined with the tried and true persona summons works very well. There are a variety of combos to remember, and each character has their own set, along with their own elemental strengths and weaknesses previously seen in Persona 5. If you've played Persona 5, the old cast will feel pretty familiar as a result. It's worth trying every character out as soon as you're able to as well, since every character plays differently as far as their combos go. Pro tip: make sure you get comfortable with a myriad of party members too. It will not only expand your tool set when confronting powerful shadows, but there's a specific part where you'll have to basically use all of them at some point.

Performance wise, this game runs very well on my GTX 1080; I didn't see a single frame drop, except for one spot in one of the dungeons which turned out to be a complete one off situation. This game is optimized well, but the only problem is that this game has a tendency to crash when loading into and out of the Metaverse. Please remember to save often, as crashing at some points could mean having to redo tough fights. I myself crashed twice at one specific section and had to play the same section three times total before I finally got through it. Those two crashes were the only crashes I had within my 45 hours of game time, however.

Overall, Persona 5 Strikers is a great hack-n-slash game, and is a very good extension to Persona 5. While the gameplay can get repetitive, overall I had a lot of fun with this title and it really quenched the thirst of wanting more Persona 5 that I didn't even know I had. Highly recommended.

author: f3656563-0615-52e7-81b2-a9052dbce5ff
content:
Just wait, guessing SEGA decided that the DRM was more important than the game stability so I have to put down the controller and hop onto P5R while what I'm guessing is the porting team fix their screw-up with the PC version that causes crashing and lengthy load times.

= Do note that the community has already found workarounds to fix just about everybody's issues. I myself used the nvidia control panel fixes (plus setting the exe to run as admin) and it has completely solved the load time and load crash issues I've suffered. (as far as I can tell atleast)

This game isn't for everyone, yes even those that have already played Persona 5. First off this game is fully based on the Persona 5 Original version of the world, not the Royal remake. If this bothers you please keep in mind that this game was released in Japan long before Royal was made. Keep in mind that this game also happens after the events of P5 so I fully recommend you play P5 first unless you came here specifically for the combat system over the story, at that point you'll be fine most of the major plot points revolve around current happenings anyways, I myself came for the story so...

Point on the combat system. If you already played P5 or P5 Royal you might have issue with the combat system as it takes the, beat the life out of waves of enemies with everything you got, approach over the turn-based quality over quantity enemies that the mainline games have. The fusion system is slightly simplified as is the persona strengthening system. You are slightly screwed out of you're previous sources of items, armor, and weapons, but in turn you have and adorable new character who will handle most of your material needs. You also have Joker's awakened cooking abilities and a 100% fixed flow of time, also UNLIMITED TRANSIT between the real world and the metaverse, due to the shorter in-game time you are given to clear the palace. DAYS WILL ONLY PASS ALONGSIDE STORY PROGRESSION. No getting bad ends because you spent to long getting pestered by Mona to sleep. There is also a million other little things you'll learn as you play that differ from the mainline games but you'll learn them fairly easily.

I dearly love the Persona games alongside it's older edgier cousin. And so far the game has been amazing for a spin-off of a spin-off series. You do have to look at it like persona Q in that it is fairly different from the game or games that it spawned from. Igor is once again eating popcorn far away from the side disaster probably drinking tea with his boss. So just, realize that like a lot of games, you won't know how much you'll enjoy a game till you play it or see the systems in action.

author: aa23d421-90dd-5568-82c6-711f8d43e0a2
content:
So... what is Persona 5 Strikers?

Short answer it's Persona 5 the sequel with new flavors mixed in.

Below are my four key points to hopefully convince everyone who is curious, along with a few other bulletpoints.

First and foremost, there are NO SOCIAL LINKS-now, most people would be upset by this, and yes, it is technically a loss for the series as a whole, but it's not quite as big of a deal as you'd might think. You get to interact with the party and the cutscenes you share with the Phantom Thieves are all quite cozy and just plain JRPG comfort food. 

Second, this is NOT turn based combat, it's a sort of spin on Dynasty Warriors, meets active RPG, meets mild turn based mechanics. Sound messy? It is when you first jump in, but after everything is explained to you? You'll be gliding through combat like a beast. Essentially you have buttonmashing combos to take out trash, you can add some spice by changing what buttons you hit for different actions to occur. Whenever you press the "Summon" key (the key to actively bring out your Persona, you are given a list of spells and abilities to select from, time is halted during this. Additionally, there is gunplay, all you do is target enemies with a gun and fire at them--time slows down to like 1/8th speed during this mechanic.I will note that despite this being in the "Dynasty Warriors" archetype of games, I find it an unfitting description. This is still an RPG, and the boss fights DO require some strategy, if you run in mashing you will not have much success on these fights, on top of this, it feels less tiresome because you see when encounters are going to occur as opposed to your map just being flooded constantly with enemies.

Third, ever wanted to play as any of the other Phantom Thieves? Guess what, that's a thing this time. In fact, it's an encouraged mechanic-the Baton Pass system in this one can help you juggle powers by switching characters when prompted-it can get nasty if done right. On top of the Baton passes, each character has a set of "Mastery Skills", and these were just delightful treasures, I remember each time I unlocked a new one for a character (four mastery skills per character)  I couldn't help but laugh and think "That sounds overpowered", oh yeah, they all felt that way-if you know how to play and use the characters skills? You'll turn into a monster on the battlefield. 

Fourth, the freaking music. Dear god. The. Freaking. Music. This game follows the standard Persona series tradition of having music that's just outright amazing-the fact that they give you the soundtrack with this is simply amazing. I cannot endorse this game's music enough. If you've played the series previously, you know what to expect.



A few other things.
-Dynamic artstyle that looks just as flashy as always.
-Lower system requirements, meaning some older rigs out there can run it.
-Japanese and English voice options (both are wonderful, and all voice actors returned for their roles.)
-Game is optimized for any controller type, I normally wouldn't think I'd have to mention this, but I just played another title that was not equipped for all controller types. 



I've bought a plethora of games on Steam, and done a small handful of reviews. (I owe another JRPG a review... better get on that one too.) This is one that I strongly encourage you all to purchase and play. It's a solid experience and worth your time. Ideally, this will also give Atlus the incentive they need to release all future (and perhaps previous) SMT titles on PC so I don't have to own a console for the sole purpose of their games.

author: 06a3dff6-a24a-58e1-9a51-47576aa7bd38
content: If you're a fan of persona but want something faster paced, this is a good pick up.  The game is definitely shorter than the main SMT games, even if you try to 100% the game.  However, in true SMT nature, hard mode has its difficulties, and easy mode makes grinding bareable.  It has all the feels of a post persona 3 game, just condensed, but never had I got the feel that the game felt rushed.  The dungeons are built so that they don't feel repetitive (unless you're looking to 100% the game, in which case of course you'll need to go out of your way to do some side quests).  For a spin off game I'd give this a solid 8/10 objectively, and 8.5/10 as a SMT fan.

author: e9ae814d-ffd8-577a-8897-1dfe9b204142
content:
Pros:
- Good story, worthy of being a great sequal
- Combat is easy enough to get used to
- Both Japanese and English dubs do an amazing job at voicing characters
- 60 FPS is great compared to 30FPS
- Zenkichi and Sophia are great additions to the main cast
- No time progression if you exit a jail, and no deadline to complete anything (aside from treasure demons)

Cons:
- Random crashes, usually in cutscenes/transitions after a jail
- Infinite loading/black screen after you beat the 5th jails boss
- Game can only run FPS up to 60FPS
- 3rd jails boss is a huge difficulty spike
- Maps can sometimes be disorientating
- Not a lot of characters from the first game reappear

Overall, I'd highly recommend getting this game for the great story to finish up the Phantom Thieve storyline, but only once ATLUS have fixed a lot of issues and bugs with the PC port.

author: 27fc5e70-19e6-5885-821c-9db1230d221d
content:
Disclaimer: I can only recommend this game if you have already played Persona 5 (Base or Royal) because knowing the events beforehand is too important.

This game has all the level Persona 5 storytelling and the main cast that you probably enjoy. This game's twist is basically that it turns the traditional turn based Persona system into a stylish and dynamic real-time RPG with some hack-n-slash elements. Also this game is definitely quite easy until the ending where it gets somewhat challenging so I recommend to play on Hard which honestly feels kind of easy for someone new to the genre. Another gripe is that the game right now as a crashing issue and I see other people are experiencing it too - personally I have crashed like 7-8 times during my gameplay (usually when fast-travelling) so I HIGHLY recommend saving whenever you can until this issue is resolved. If you can look past these flaws, The story is solid, you'll get your values worth with ~40 hours of content, and the game is legitimately fun and addicting. 

8/10

author: 2330ba97-d6d5-5190-8d97-ee4b1550ba98
content:
I make this review very subjective as i played all 'Persona' titles and having a certain expectation.

Mainly I feel P5 Strikers lacks of Persona 5 original charm, and i was hoping with P5 Royal like expectation where Royal was extravagant but still delivers 'cool teenager' experience.

I did played musou game like DW and SW, where it makes me as player feel very powerful, but it isn't when i play Strikes. Instead i feel frustrated as the enemies(especially the strong one) are very not balance until i reach 'not fun' point. Fair point i play the game in hard mode, but in Royal i played 'Merciless' difficulty in first playthrough, but it was still very doable and feel very fun. I know it's a different genre, but by holding 'Persona 5' title it should reach a same experience.

P5 Strikes also feels very boring for me. It's repetitive and defeating enemies isn't satisfying. I think it's a problem in UX delivery, where in any original Persona's battle we potentially see something new like new enemy, new potential persona, new item, yada yada yada. Strikes has a contradiction design, while ambushing enemy is using same approach as Persona 5, but then every battle information is using musou game style, for example every item and new persona shown in the mid battle. How the **** i could see that in the mid of chaos, why not just using Persona 5 style T_T where everything we got is shown in the end of battle. This problem leads to I feel I don't get anything and not rewarded, heck i even often didn't know i have a new persona. Fusing a new persona is also not really that exciting, as i know i will be pummeled again by the enemy. It's unfortunate where Persona 5 main strength is UI/UX with their very awesome style.

And lastly no Kasumi is a huge experience gap and it feels strange for me.

author: 058ada4c-a868-5b07-89d9-3a0488caa6a4
content:
As I'm typing this review, I am past 15 hours in my playthrough of this game.
Outside of at least one game crash recently (which i've heard countless horror stories about through the steam reviews with people experiencing more than one crash many times), Persona 5 Strikers has been a consistent fun ride for me.

The characters are still charming as ever, the story is interesting (even if it kinda becomes a bit too familiar in some aspects), and the gameplay, whilst different from the engaging Pokemon-esque Turn Based Combat System from the Original/Royal games in favor of this Psuedo-Dynasty Warriors Action Combat like engine, it actually feels natural with this universe, with it providing more in depth strategy and planning when partaking in fast paced real time combat, especially on the harder difficulties (which is where i believe you'll get the most challenge and content from).

So if you love Persona 5, Persona 5 Royal, and/or anything related to Atlus or Dynasty Warriors, you'll have a fun time with this title. But I can only recommend this game if your PC is capable to run it properly without issue, or if you have a PS4 and/or Nintendo Switch (which i imagine, the console versions run just as good)

author: f5a7c8f7-4e27-5283-bbd0-0e7dd9fc05dd
content:
Technical:
Atlus did a great job in porting that game. It runs smooth with the occasional framedrop below 50 during the animations and cutscenes. I didn't experience any framedrops during battle, which is the most important part to me!

Graphical Setting: Everything on high, resolution scale = 1.5
PC specs: Intel i7 6700k (not OC), NVIDIA RTX 2060 (not super), 32GB RAM, game runs on a SSD.

Loading times are almost non-existent and I haven't experienced any glitches so far.

Gameplay:
That's the other point I can imagine most of you are wondering. Especially since it isn't a turn-based RPG anymore.

I was not sure if I would be able to enjoy P5 Strikers. Especially since I am used to turn-based battles in general.
FFXV really gave me a hard time trying to find some love for the game, without success.

So, here we are at P5S. I started it with the horrible experience I just explained in mind. Watching out that I would still be able to get a refund if it doesn't suit me....And what can I say? Without realizing I already player for 18 hours! :) 
I hope this encourages anyone with a similar experience to mine to give P5S a serious try. I am pretty sure you won't be disappointed!

Edit: After some more playing I can call this game "Japanese food guide 2021" for sure. Every time I play this I get hungry AF.

author: e9b53ae7-8f70-510f-8b9d-00a2e60345d2
content:
Persona 5 Strikers is a brilliant action RPG sequel to Persona 5, it's turn based original. The story, even though it's not at the level of the prequel in my opinion, continues to expand the Persona universe and shows how much effort has been put into the development phase of this game.

There are currently a few bugs that break immersion, such as occasional game crashing, average loading times and being able to challenge the Monarch of Sapporo without sending a calling card, but nothing ridiculously game breaking that makes the game unplayable.

All in all, a perfect sequel to a perfect franchise and I can't recommend this game enough to Persona fans. All we need now is for Atlus to release Persona 5/Royal on Steam for us PC players to enjoy even more!
